text:
In the early days of radio and television, advertisements were produced and aired live or in real time. Some radio and television programs continue such practice. On radio, the program host, announcer-on-board, or disc jockey reads the advertising copy, which can be as simple as incorporating the brand name in the program title, like “The Listerine Amateur Hour,” or adding the phrase “Inihahandog ng …” (Brought to you by …), followed by the name and slogan of the brand. On television, this is a talking head or a close-up of the program host presenting the product or a celebrity casually plugging a brand while delivering a spiel. These formats are sometimes punctuated by sound effects or music.

 

This simple presentation of the marketer’s message changed into more complicated production treatments. Notable among these later formats was the singing of the product jingle; the dramatization of the selling proposition using dialogue, music, sound, and visual effects; and product benefit demonstration—all aired live. Advertisers adapted the format of popular broadcast genres, like narratives, to take advantage of their popularity, consequently capturing the viewer’s attention for their messages. On the other hand, the use of documentary and news formats, as well as the hosts associated with them, provided commercials with the credibility associated with these genres.

 

 

The introduction of more sophisticated audio and audiovisual production technologies permitted the pre-recording of advertising materials that can be aired repeatedly without incurring the cost of hiring talents to perform the commercial live during the course of broadcast. These new technologies included less expensive magnetic tape recording and playback machines for audio materials, film-to-video transfer (telecine transfer), and video recording and editing for audiovisual materials. The formats used in advertising materials, however, remained similar to those of earlier programs aired on radio and television.

 

Music, a popular form of broadcast content, was later employed in selling products. This is the commercial jingle. The jingle of United American Tiki Tiki, a multivitamin for children, was aired on radio repeatedly, giving it a strong brand recall since the 1950s. In the 2000s, the brand used the same melody line for its commercials.

 

 

Some ads became popular because of the slogans or tag lines in their commercials. Examples in the 1970s include “Para kang nakasandal sa pader” (It’s as if you were leaning on a solid wall) of the Philippine National Bank, “Iba na ang matangkad” (It pays to be tall) of Star Margarine, and “E di ibalik ang swerti” (Okay, let’s sweep luck back) by the Philippine Charity Sweepstakes Office. Other notable examples include “Sino’ng best friend mo doon? Siyempre, ikaw lang!” (Who is going to be your best friend over there? Who else but you!) of Nestle Ice Cream in the 1980s and “suportahan taka” (I will support you) of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company in 2001. One advertisement that managed to maintain its slogan over the years is that of Safeguard in which an alter ego of the woman character speaks the line “Ako ang iyong konsensiya” (I am your conscience), which has become a standard in practically all ads of the bath soap from the 1970s until the present.

 

The various styles of dramas, such as soap operas, slice-of-life, situational and stand-up comedy, and vignettes or a montage of slices-of-life, can also be seen in radio and television commercials. Most memorable in the mid-1970s was the Kodak television commercial that used Paul Anka’s song “Times of Your Life” in which actor Mario Montenegro reminisces about his life with his daughter Hanilet who is getting married. The Lumen television advertisement series of the laundry detergent Surf in the 1990s banked on the popularity of serialized soap operas on Philippine television. The Lumen commercials, just like a soap opera, was a series of advertisements that followed the lives of newlywed Lumen, her husband Tonyo, their twins, and her mother-in-law Lola Obang who showed consumers how to save money by using Surf. The slice-of-life Modess radio commercial Kabaliwan, 1993, dramatized the myth that taking a bath when menstruating leads to insanity to promote a shift from a pasador (cloth napkin) to the more contemporary disposable sanitary napkin. Pulutan (Appetizer), 1984, a television commercial of San Miguel Beer, was a situational comedy series featuring comedian Bert Marcelo, singer Rico Puno, horse racer Jockey Eduardo, billiards champion Amang Parica, and boxer Flash Elorde. Set in a drinking pub, these personalities argue on what pulutan to go with their beer and end up with the bright idea of “isang platitong mani” (a saucer of peanuts), which became a household punch line at the time the advertisement was aired. Wit, pun, and smart turn of phrases have also been used in commercials as seen in the 2005 Dolfenal advertisement that featured Dolphy with the lines “Laughter is not the best medicine… Madali pang tandaan (Easy to remember): Dolphy, Dolfenal.”

 

 

The resurgence and popularity in the 2000s of serialized dramas on television, the teleserye, gave rise to the branded content or branded entertainment format of television commercials. Unlike the usual commercials where product features are directly promoted, these dramas, comedies, or miniseries promote a single brand by incorporating images of the product into the story. Branded content is aired as part of a station’s programming and is not interrupted by other advertisements. The short film Karga (Loaded), 2014, included in the 9th GMA Christmas Short Film Festival, tells the story of a Shell gas attendant who returned the money that a customer had accidentally dropped at the station, even if the attendant badly needed the money for his sick daughter.

 

Riding on the popularity of broadcast programs, advertisements use the premise of these programs as a springboard for commercials and appear to be extensions of the popular program. Richard Yap and Jodi Sta. Maria, the lead characters in the highly rated series Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, ABS-CBN, play their roles as Sir Chief and Maya, respectively, in the situmercial—a portmanteau for situation and commercial—for Amaia, a housing development project of Ayala Land in which overseas Filipino workers can invest their earnings. In the commercial, Sir Chief and Maya talk about ordinary people’s dreams of owning their own home, which can be made possible through Amaia.

 

 

Commercials also adopt from literature and events in history. The 1970s Superwheel detergent bar commercial series lampoons Samson and Delilah, Anthony and Cleopatra, Camelot, and the like. The EQ Diaper television commercial, 2014, spoofs the encounter between Lapu-Lapu and Magellan.

 

The documentary genre can also be seen in commercials with real-life events, interviews, demonstrations, and testimonials. Milo’s Gymnast, 1987, documents a day in the life of Bea Lucero as she wakes up, eats breakfast, goes to school, and practices gymnastics. In Joy Dishwashing Liquid commercials, Michael V. interviews housewives and conducts product demonstrations like scientific experiments. Celebrity product endorsers like Boy Abunda, Kris Aquino, Piolo Pascual, and many others can be heard and seen using and endorsing products with their testimonials.

 

In stealth advertising, the news format is adapted in the presentation of the product. Mike Enriquez, in DZBB’s Super Balita sa Umaga Nationwide (Super Morning News Nationwide), which premiered in Jan 2007, uses this news format in endorsing Artho, a food supplement to help ease the pain of arthritis. He integrates this plug in the news program with the following opening spiel: “Alam n’yo, mga kapuso, Enero ngayon, malamig na naman ang panahon. Uso na naman ang aray-tiis. Masakit na naman ang ating mga kasu-kasuan …” (You know, our dear followers, it’s January, the cool weather has set in. It’s again the season of “bearing the pain.” Our arthritis is on the attack.)

 

The advent of the music video in the 1980s gave rise to the jingle-based music video advertisement. The Palmolive Soap with Beauty Cream television advertisement in 1987, which featured Alice Dixson and Sheila Ysrael, showed a combination of song, dance, and special effects—ingredients of early music videos. This commercial ended with Alice Dixson singing “I can feel it” as she shook one shoulder and naughtily faced the camera.

 

The combination of different broadcast genres in a single program can also be seen in radio and television advertisements. Typical is a song interspersed with an announcer’s voice-over. Do, Re, Mi, 1981, a radio commercial of Dequadin lozenges, begins with a tenor singing the two octaves of a musical scale. Before he reaches the last note, an announcer interrupts the singing with “This last note is brought to you by Dequadin.” After the singer hits the last note, the announcer says, “Dequadin. All-out support to take the sore out of your throat.” Labadami-Labango (Heavy Load of Laundry, Fragrant Laundry), 1987, the Mr. Clean advertisement featuring singer Sylvia La Torre, combined celebrity endorsement, interviews with housewives, product demonstration, animation, and a musical number led by the popular singer. Written by Fernando A. Austria, Jr. with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

Sources

Austria 1996; Creative Guild of the Philippines 1995; Madrona 2013; Valisno 2013.

text:
Agriculture programs are educational and informative shows that focus on issues and concerns of the agriculture sector, serving as channels for communicating recent scientific developments, as well as avenues for recommending solutions to the problems faced by rural communities.

 

The beginnings of agriculture programs in the Philippines may be traced to the initiatives in educational broadcasting that were launched during the 1940s and the 1950s. These efforts were conceptualized to use radio as a tool for distance learning for farmers in far-flung areas. In 1952, a pioneering six-month education program for farmers in Iloilo was produced by Pacifico Sudario. Dubbed as the farmers’ school of-the-air, the program was sponsored by the Agricultural Productivity Commission and the Bureau of Plant Industry, and featured broadcasts on farming and community development (Flor 2009).

During the 1960s, several AM stations started to include agriculture shows in their regular programming, usually in early morning time slots, and benefited from the support of institutions like the Department of Agriculture (DA), the University of the Philippines Los Baños (UPLB), the International Institute for Rural Reconstruction, the Philippine Rural Reconstruction Movement, and the International Rice Research Institute. In 1964, the rural educational radio station DZLB, operating under UPLB, went on the air for the first time after its conception in 1962 as an extension tool for disseminating agricultural information. Dubbed “Ang Tinig ng Nayon” (The Voice of the Countryside), DZLB has served as a rural education broadcasting platform for the propagation of agriculture-related information in the communities within and beyond the university (Gomez 1984). Still in operation, DZLB is considered one of the most significant projects realized in the field of agricultural extension.

 

The declaration of martial law in 1972 saw the government’s transformation of mass media broadcasts into instruments for propagating New Society policies through what it termed as development communication. Operating within the ambit of the dictatorship’s rural development framework, these programs occupied a significant place in the period’s mass media landscape, particularly through their presence in radio broadcasting. Among the agriculture radio programs that aired under the dictatorship was Sanggunian sa Himpapawid (Consultation on Air) anchored by Manila-based rural broadcasters of the government-owned DZFM. The program served as the model for one-hour farm broadcasts developed as part of the extensive communication campaign to promote Masagana 99, a national campaign for food sufficiency launched in 1973, which aimed at increasing the country’s rice production (Alvarez 1984). Rural broadcasters enlisted by the Ministry of Agriculture to create and conduct these broadcasts received their training at DZLB.

 

The realization of initiatives in community radio in the late 1980s, marked by the proposal of the Philippine Foundation of Rural Broadcasters and other academics to install radio stations in various remote areas in the country, paved the way for the creation of educational programming geared toward the needs of the locality. Agriculture segments prominently figured in these community radio broadcasts. For instance, DZJO of the Bayanihan Broadcasting Corporation based in Infanta, Quezon, features radio schools that provide information to barrio folks concerning issues like sustainable agriculture, environmental preservation, and livelihood (Tabing 2012).

 

Agriculture programming eventually entered the television broadcasting platform during the 1970s, with radio maintaining a firm hold on its audiences. A popular example is Gerry Geronimo’s long-running Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out), 1974-91, revived in the late 2000s, and aired on different stations. Considered one of the earliest educational television programs for farmers, this weekly show presents various topics on agriculture, agribusiness, and even cockfighting in a magazine format that featured expert interviews and infographics in its presentation of information.

 

During the mid to the late 1970s, the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP) and the Broadcast Media Council (BMC) issued directives that mandated the compulsory radio broadcast of educational agriculture-based programs produced by the government, like the DA’s University of the Air. However, the abolition of the BMC subsequently led to the reduction of farmcasting airtime from one hour to fifteen minutes (Flor 2009). Nevertheless, even in the absence of direct government promotion, the 1990s saw no decline in the emergence of agriculture-oriented television programs in commercial television networks. These programs continued to occupy the morning time slot. IBC 13 aired Mag-Agri Tayo (Let Us Do Agriculture), 1990, which was eventually transferred to and continues to be aired by the government-sponsored PTV 4, while the Technology and Livelihood Resource Center produced Agrisiete (Agriculture on Seven), GMA, and featured experts from UPLB and the Department of Science and Technology. Agrisiete was also notable for having popular celebrity German Moreno host the program in what could be understood as an effort to widen its appeal (Flor 2009).

 

A new brand of agriculture shows emerged in the late 1980s until the early 2000s, with agriculture programs being utilized by civil society groups experimenting on form and expanding the range of topics that can be covered by the genre. The weekly radio talk program Punlaan sa Himpapawid (Seedling Plots on Air), 1987 to late 1990s, on DWBC then on DWAN, produced by the Philippine Peasant Institute and anchored by Eli R. Guieb III, Faith Bacon, and later by Minda Casagan, discussed the sociopolitical context of agrarian reform and related peasant issues. A program which focused on fisheries and community-based coastal resource management and which combined talk, drama, music, and poetry was the daily radio magazine Radyo Lundayan (Lundayan Radio), DZEC, 1991-95, anchored by Guieb and Jingle Enriquez, joined in later by Casagan and Rom Dongeto, and produced by the Tambuyog Development Center. On television, an excellent agriculture magazine show was AgriLink, 1993-99, GMA, produced by Cheche Lazaro’s Probe Productions, and hosted by Luchi Cruz-Valdes. Airing in the 1990s and 2000s were magazine programs solely devoted to cockfighting and gamefowl breeding, like Hataw Pinoy: Tukaan (Go Filipino: Strike with a Peck) and STV: Ang Sabong TV ng Bayan (STV: The Cockfighting TV of the Nation).

 

Regional television stations of giant media companies have also produced and aired local agriculture programs of their own, some of which make use of the regional languages of the communities they target. A successful example is Agri Tayo Dito (Let’s Do Agriculture Here), a weekly program produced by ABS-CBN Davao, hosted by reality television show winner Ruben Gonzaga. Aired exclusively in Davao, the show features segments devoted to several agriculture practices like backyard and organic farming and innovations on farming, as well as inspiring stories of people who found success in their venture in agriculture.

 

In some cases, agriculture-oriented segments are also integrated into other program formats, particularly in morning television shows aired nationwide like Unang Hirit (First Blow), GMA, and Magandang Umaga, Pilipinas (Good Morning, Philippines), ABS-CBN. Features devoted to breakthroughs in agricultural science have also been included even in weekly magazine and lifestyle shows like Korina Sanchez’s Rated K, which premiered in 2004, ABS-CBN. Regional television networks also exemplify this practice of integrating agriculture segments in other programs. For instance, GMA Iloilo’s now-defunct morning show Arangkada (Accelerate) featured the segment “Agring-agri” (Truly Agriculture), which covered updates on the agriculture sector and provided tips to farmers and to whomever was interested to engage in agribusiness.

 

Even with the advent of online programming, agriculture programs continue to be aired on radio, as sophisticated communication technologies remain inaccessible to some rural communities. DZMM’s TeleRadyo (Television and Radio), for instance, features Sa Kabukiran (In the Fields), hosted by Louie Tabing, which revolves around updates on agriculture practices and gives opportunities for farmers to air their concerns.

 

Agriculture programs continue to serve as staple elements in radio and television broadcasts in a country that still relies heavily on the agriculture industry. Agriculture programming has been given incentives by various award-giving bodies like the KBP Golden Dove Awards and the Bright Leaf Agriculture Journalism Awards. Agriculture programs have served as necessary avenues for addressing the concerns raised by the sector, as well as a crucial link between academic and research institutions devoted to agriculture, civil society groups seeking social change, and the target communities of these initiatives. Agriculture programs of late have also been shaped to respond to crucial contemporary issues, particularly climate change and its impact on the sector. Written by Laurence Marvin S. Castillo with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

 

Sources

Alvarez 1984; Flor 2009; Gomez 1984; Tabing 2012.

Agriculture programming eventually entered the television broadcasting platform during the 1970s, with radio maintaining a firm hold on its audiences. A popular example is Gerry Geronimo’s long-running Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out), 1974-91, revived in the late 2000s, and aired on different stations. Considered one of the earliest educational television programs for farmers, this weekly show presents various topics on agriculture, agribusiness, and even cockfighting in a magazine format that featured expert interviews and infographics in its presentation of information.

During the mid to the late 1970s, the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP) and the Broadcast Media Council (BMC) issued directives that mandated the compulsory radio broadcast of educational agriculture-based programs produced by the government, like the DA’s University of the Air. However, the abolition of the BMC subsequently led to the reduction of farmcasting airtime from one hour to fifteen minutes (Flor 2009). Nevertheless, even in the absence of direct government promotion, the 1990s saw no decline in the emergence of agriculture-oriented television programs in commercial television networks. These programs continued to occupy the morning time slot. IBC 13 aired Mag-Agri Tayo (Let Us Do Agriculture), 1990, which was eventually transferred to and continues to be aired by the government-sponsored PTV 4, while the Technology and Livelihood Resource Center produced Agrisiete (Agriculture on Seven), GMA, and featured experts from UPLB and the Department of Science and Technology. Agrisiete was also notable for having popular celebrity German Moreno host the program in what could be understood as an effort to widen its appeal (Flor 2009).

A new brand of agriculture shows emerged in the late 1980s until the early 2000s, with agriculture programs being utilized by civil society groups experimenting on form and expanding the range of topics that can be covered by the genre. The weekly radio talk program Punlaan sa Himpapawid (Seedling Plots on Air), 1987 to late 1990s, on DWBC then on DWAN, produced by the Philippine Peasant Institute and anchored by Eli R. Guieb III, Faith Bacon, and later by Minda Casagan, discussed the sociopolitical context of agrarian reform and related peasant issues. A program which focused on fisheries and community-based coastal resource management and which combined talk, drama, music, and poetry was the daily radio magazine Radyo Lundayan (Lundayan Radio), DZEC, 1991-95, anchored by Guieb and Jingle Enriquez, joined in later by Casagan and Rom Dongeto, and produced by the Tambuyog Development Center. On television, an excellent agriculture magazine show was AgriLink, 1993-99, GMA, produced by Cheche Lazaro’s Probe Productions, and hosted by Luchi Cruz-Valdes. Airing in the 1990s and 2000s were magazine programs solely devoted to cockfighting and gamefowl breeding, like Hataw Pinoy: Tukaan (Go Filipino: Strike with a Peck) and STV: Ang Sabong TV ng Bayan (STV: The Cockfighting TV of the Nation).

Regional television stations of giant media companies have also produced and aired local agriculture programs of their own, some of which make use of the regional languages of the communities they target. A successful example is Agri Tayo Dito (Let’s Do Agriculture Here), a weekly program produced by ABS-CBN Davao, hosted by reality television show winner Ruben Gonzaga. Aired exclusively in Davao, the show features segments devoted to several agriculture practices like backyard and organic farming and innovations on farming, as well as inspiring stories of people who found success in their venture in agriculture.

In some cases, agriculture-oriented segments are also integrated into other program formats, particularly in morning television shows aired nationwide like Unang Hirit (First Blow), GMA, and Magandang Umaga, Pilipinas (Good Morning, Philippines), ABS-CBN. Features devoted to breakthroughs in agricultural science have also been included even in weekly magazine and lifestyle shows like Korina Sanchez’s Rated K, which premiered in 2004, ABS-CBN. Regional television networks also exemplify this practice of integrating agriculture segments in other programs. For instance, GMA Iloilo’s now-defunct morning show Arangkada (Accelerate) featured the segment “Agring-agri” (Truly Agriculture), which covered updates on the agriculture sector and provided tips to farmers and to whomever was interested to engage in agribusiness.

Even with the advent of online programming, agriculture programs continue to be aired on radio, as sophisticated communication technologies remain inaccessible to some rural communities. DZMM’s TeleRadyo (Television and Radio), for instance, features Sa Kabukiran (In the Fields), hosted by Louie Tabing, which revolves around updates on agriculture practices and gives opportunities for farmers to air their concerns.

Agriculture programs continue to serve as staple elements in radio and television broadcasts in a country that still relies heavily on the agriculture industry. Agriculture programming has been given incentives by various award-giving bodies like the KBP Golden Dove Awards and the Bright Leaf Agriculture Journalism Awards. Agriculture programs have served as necessary avenues for addressing the concerns raised by the sector, as well as a crucial link between academic and research institutions devoted to agriculture, civil society groups seeking social change, and the target communities of these initiatives. Agriculture programs of late have also been shaped to respond to crucial contemporary issues, particularly climate change and its impact on the sector. Written by Laurence Marvin S. Castillo with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

text:
Aksiyon (action) is a narrative genre in which physical combat sequences play an integral function in the story. On radio, actors’ performance, sound effects, and ambient sounds are crucial to achieving thrill and tension. On television, the genre relies on live and special effects, stunts, fight scenes, explosions, and chases to create a visually compelling spectacle. Since the narrative is stretched into various episodes, an overarching storyline becomes necessary. Generally, characters are pushed to their limit as they face challenges. The defeat of the hero or the hero’s kin or friends at some point in the story is necessary to make the character stronger. One has to fight, seeking an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth, and good triumphs over evil in the end.

 

The action genre in Philippine broadcast is mainly a morality play nuanced by sociopolitical conflicts, which the protagonist resolves by facing and overcoming a series of challenges and physical conflicts to restore the peace and order in the community (Tope 2013). Broadcast audiences can easily relate to the plot because it tells the story of their plight. It narrates a society ravaged by corruption, greed, poverty, and the culture of impunity. It is an attack on politicians who wield guns, goons, and gold; the power-hungry bureaucrats; and the elite who will do everything it takes to protect its self-interest. Amidst the many ills of society, the protagonist, who comes from an oppressed class, emerges to protect and fight for the oppressed, seizing every opportunity to seek revenge and make the antagonist pay for what is owed.

 

The genre can be traced to the emergence of postwar radio drama serials, which were mostly localized versions of foreign comics and novels that featured crime-busting heroes. During the 1950s, DZRH introduced the weekly fantasy action radio series Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), created by Leonardo Abutin and patterned after the American comics hero Captain Marvel. The Filipino version centers on the action-packed adventures of a kindhearted young man who transforms into the eponymous crime-fighting superhero endowed with great strength and the power to unleash lightning by the lightning god Zeus. Tatlong Limbas (Three Birds of Prey), a localized radio version of Alexandre Dumas’s The Three Musketeers, follows the thrilling exploits of the trio Isagani, Rolando, and Tito in their crime-fighting missions. Interestingly, even the original works during the period bore visible influences of foreign action and adventure genres. Reminiscent of prewar metrical romances and chivalry tales, the immensely popular DZRH radio serial of the 1950s, Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), adapted by Clodualdo del Mundo from the original komiks serial of Mario del Mar, follows the comedy-laden exploits and combats of the title character in a European medieval kingdom. Kapitan Bagwis (Captain Wings), touted as DZBC’s answer to DZRH’s Prinsipe Amante, is a seafaring adventure series inspired by the swashbuckling Hollywood films of Errol Flynn (Aniceto 2007). In the early 1950s, DZBB produced Tony Narra, voiced by Phil Delfino and considered the first Filipino detective-type radio program.

 

Local television shows in the late 1960s that imitated American and British action shows were ABS-CBN’s Agent 69 and Kwatro Bidas (Four Heroes), which was considered unique as it was a serious drama that featured four known comedians—Doro de los Ojos, Teroy de Guzman, Cachupoy, and Ading Fernando—as special law enforcers who were experts in martial arts.

 

Imported action programs continued to be shown on television in the 1960s and the 1970s. Examples include the serialized westerns The Wild, Wild West and the adventure series Tarzan on ABS-CBN, war dramas like Combat and detective programs like Mission Impossible on GMA, spy programs such as The Saint on RMN-IBC 13, and the mystery anthology Alfred Hitchcock Presents and the Japanese television series The Samurai on Channel 5. Importing canned action programs continued into the 1980s with westerns like Alias Smith and Jones, Bonanza, Gunsmoke, and Lancer, and police and detective shows like Cannon, Dan August, Hawaii Five-O, and The Mod Squad.

 

While the action genre gained greater success in films during the subsequent decades that marked the rise to superstardom of action film stars Fernando Poe Jr and Joseph Estrada, the action genre on television in the 1970s copied the martial arts cinema of the likes of Bruce Lee, such as Bertong Dragon (Berto the Dragon), 1979, GTV 4, played by Ramon Zamora (TV Times 1979). An attempt at detective drama on TV was Bakit (Why), 1978, IBC 13, directed by Tony Llenes (TV Times 1978). Some of the films of action stars eventually migrated to television through reruns and screenings, like FPJ sa GMA (FPJ on GMA), which aired from the mid-1980s to the mid-1990s.

 

 

The contemporary boom in the production and consumption of local drama series further allowed the predominant deployment of action and adventure genre conventions on television. While the 1990s were marked by the eventual decline of the action movie genre, a number of drama series beginning in the 2000s made action sequences integral to their narratives. Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You), 2003, ABS-CBN, starring popular soap actor Judy Ann Santos and action film actor Robin Padilla, can be considered one of the earliest examples of what was dubbed as action-serye—a drama series that fully appropriates and absorbs the conventions and structure of the action genre. The narrative centers on Ambet Catindig (Padilla), a veteran NBI agent, and his rookie partner, Princess Gonzales (Santos), a young law graduate embarking on a search for her father, a former NBI agent, who mysteriously disappeared. They are given tasks of solving various cases under the NBI crime-busting Eagles squad. The series swiftly moves from case to case in weeklong episodes that brim with action-filled sequences ranging from fistfights to shoot-outs, while charting the deepening romantic involvement of the two leads. Another example is Asian Treasures, 2007, GMA, topbilled again by Padilla, this time with Angel Locsin. Weaving folkloric elements into historical fiction and the treasure hunt narrative, this primetime series follows the exploits of the lead characters as they embark on a search for the treasures of the legendary datu (chieftains) of Panay. As evident in these two action series, the presence of the female action hero is noticeably more pronounced, deviating from the typically male-centered narrative with which the action genre has been identified for so long.

 

In spite of being dominated by macho men, the action genre in the Philippines showcased female characters as powerful leads in history-fantasy-action dramas. Encantadia (Fairlyland), 2005, GMA, topbilled by Iza Calzado, Diana Zubiri, Sunshine Dizon, and Karylle Tatlonghari, tells a story of four diwata (goddesses) tasked to protect and keep the balance of four kingdoms in Encantadia. Although the characters can control the four elements of nature (earth, wind, fire, and water), the women characters fight best with their sword, dagger, and spear. Other shows that had female leads are Krystala, 2004, ABS-CBN, and Amaya, 2011, GMA.

 

 

Interestingly, the emergence and popularity of fantaserye (fantasy series) provided opportunity for the further deployment of action and adventure genre conventions, particularly in both the afternoon and primetime slots. Radio pioneered in this genre, the most popular of which is Zimatar, written by Pedro Tiangco, which started its run in the 1970s and went on air for two decades on DZRH. It is about a young prince searching for his lost mother and whose kingdom is threatened by a rival kingdom. On television, Pintados (Tattooed), 1999, GMA, regarded as the earliest fantasy series, foregrounds combat sequences in telling the adventures of five young characters who are enlisted to become members of a clandestine crime-fighting unit formed to protect humanity from the evil forces of the Philippine supernatural underworld. Another successful fantasy series in which action plays a significant part in the plot is Mulawin, 2004, GMA, which revolves around the war between two opposing factions of winged humans: the kindhearted Mulawin and the evil Ravena.

 

A significant number of fantasy television shows, which commonly feature superheroes engaged in a series of battles against the evil creatures that populate Filipino folklore, are adaptations from other forms. After several big-screen adaptations, the famous Filipino komiks superheroine created by Mars Ravelo, Darna, was adapted twice by GMA, featuring Angel Locsin in 2005 and Marian Rivera in 2009. Darna is the story of a young lady who, upon swallowing a magic stone, transforms into a heroine endowed with great strength and fighting skills that she uses to combat evil creatures. Another legendary Mars Ravelo superhero, Captain Barbell, was adapted by GMA Network in 2006. Incarnated in the big screen by action film actors Fernando Poe Jr and Ramon “Bong” Revilla Jr,Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), a komiks series created by Carlo J. Caparas about a blacksmith who uses his magical sword to fight evil supernatural creatures, was first produced on television as an animation by Gerry Garcia in 1986 on RPN 9, then adapted for television by ABS-CBN in 2005. The story of the komiks hero Palos (Eel), a secret agent armed with professional fighting skills who aims to avenge his mother’s death, was loosely adapted for television by ABS-CBN in 2008. Some action-adventure series also took after action-adventure films. ABS-CBN, for instance, unveiled a series based on the fantasy adventure movies of action film star Ramon Revilla titled Agimat: Ang Mga Alamat ni Ramon Revilla (Amulet: The Legends of Ramon Revilla), which is about the adventures of different heroes who use the supernatural abilities bestowed upon them by their amulets to fight evil creatures. Following the traditions of the Filipino epic and similar to Ang Panday was Juan de la Cruz, 2013, ABS-CBN, starring Coco Martin, about an orphan boy, half-human, half-demon, who was brought up by a priest and is tasked to protect humanity from wicked nonhuman elements that threaten to dominate society.

 

 

Some action series are also localized versions of foreign shows. An example is Lupin, 2007, GMA, a loose adaptation of the eponymous French crime fiction series, which was later adapted into a Japanese anime series. In this version, Lupin is a professional thief whose plan to leave a life of crime and settle down is foiled by the active machinations of his father who trained him in the art of theft. Another example is Zaido: Pulis Pangkalawakan (Zaido: Space Police), GMA, a spin-off of the Japanese superhero series Space Sheriff Shaider, which centers on the alien-fighting adventures of armored space soldiers enlisted by the Galactic Force to protect the world.

 

Action genre conventions are also a staple in contemporary nonfantasy drama series, particularly with the integration of scenes of abduction, police rescue, gunfights, and fistfights. There are, however, contemporary series with a more pronounced link with the action genre than others. For instance, Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum (My Hoodlum Brother), 2011, TV5, the television remake of the 1991 blockbuster romantic action film of the same title, features mixed martial arts fight sequences in a story about a con artist who crosses paths with a sheltered heiress. Huwag Ka Lang Mawawala (Against All Odds), 2013, ABS-CBN, starring Judy Ann Santos, weaves the theme of female empowerment with the narrative of a battered wife who decides to improve her fighting skills to take vengeance on her abusive husband. Undercover, 2013, TV5, follows the path to vengeance treaded by an investigator who is mysteriously abducted and tortured by unknown villains on his wedding day.

 

While action cinema has currently been making a slow revival in the independent film movement, television reruns of past Filipino action films and drama series that contain action elements have somehow assured the continued presence of the action genre in the popular cultural realm. Other than the pleasures offered by thrilling fight scenes and adrenaline-pumping physical combat sequences, the appeal of the action genre has been understood to lie precisely in the allegorical possibilities that it offers for the depiction of the violent struggles and triumphs of a people perpetually enduring and braving the assaults of social and political crises. Written by Laurence Marvin S. Castillo, with notes from Mark Lester Oliver and Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

Sources

Aniceto 2007; Sinag Tala 1950; Tope 2013; TV Times 1978, 1979.

text:
Animation programs on television feature narratives using predominantly animation techniques. Animation is a visual technique of photographing successive drawings to create an illusion of movement. Its application in Philippine television broadcast materials and programs is an offshoot of cartoon and comic illustrations commonly featured in local magazines, newspapers, and comic books as early as the 1920s. Foreign animation programs imported into the country, developments in technology in the 1960s, challenges offered by digital software in the 1990s, and the expansion of broadcast platforms in the 2000s have significantly informed the form and content of animation on Philippine television and related media. Animation in Philippine broadcasting comes in the form of advertising, opening, and closing credits in TV shows, special effects, full programs, and films.

 

A notable comic book illustrator, especially before and after World War II, was Jose Zabala Santos who illustrated comic characters, such as Titina, Lukas Malakas, Popoy, and Sianong Siano for Sampaguita and Liwayway magazines. He pioneered the slice-of-life cartoon before Larry Alcala popularized the style (Orellana 2014). It was as a staff in the art department of the Manila Advertising Agency when he first ventured into animation as applied to commercial advertising. In 1955, while working on a project for the Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC), now known as Procter & Gamble, he and Francisco Reyes, also a comic artist, created the six-minute, 35 mm animated film Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), intended to advertise Purico, a PMC product, but which was never shown in theaters or on television. But the very first Filipino animated cartoon on film that influenced animation on television was made in 1953 when cartoonist Larry Alcala did a black-and-white exercise in movement on regular 8 mm film of a girl jumping rope and a boy playing yo-yo.

 

 

 

A figure in cartooning and animation who emerged in the mid-1960s was Zabala’s nephew, Severino “Nonoy” Marcelo, who studied animation in New York. When he came back, Marcelo and Zabala were commissioned by presidential daughter Imee Marcos to create the 48-minute Tadhana (Destiny), 1978, the first Filipino animated film-for-TV, which was based on the Philippine history book written by then president Ferdinand Marcos. Tadhana was aired only once on RPN 9 on 21 Sep 1978, the sixth anniversary of the declaration of martial law. Imee’s children’s TV show Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), 1978-89, RPN 9, featured in one of its episodes in Sep 1978 a teaser of Tadhana, which was the sequence of Magellan invading the Philippine islands using the tune of Yoyoy Villame’s novelty song “Magellan.” On 21 Sep 1979, RPN 9 aired a two-hour special, the animation version of the Iluko epic Biag ni Lam-ang (Life of Lam-ang), written and co-directed by Marcelo with Salvii Casino. In 1982, Marcelo did short animation segments featuring livelihood skills, such as hog raising, for Sandiwa (One Consciousness), a livelihood television series produced by the National Media Production Center.

 

An enterprising cartoonist of the 1980s was Gerry Garcia, a charcoal portrait artist who did a cel-animation of the popular Fernando Poe Jr film  Ang Panday (Blacksmith), which was based on a comics character created by Carlo J. Caparas and illustrated by Steve Gan. Started in 1985, the first episode of Garcia’s Ang Panday was aired on RPN 9 on 21 Nov 1986. It was the first Filipino television animated series. It was aired in the evening prime time, a deviation from the common morning or late afternoon programming for animation programs mostly coming from the United States, the United Kingdom, and Japan. RPN 9 produced and aired two more animated series by Garcia from two Filipino comics novels by Mars Ravelo: Captain Barbel, first illustrated in 1963 by Jim Fernandez in Pinoy Komiks, and Darna, first illustrated as Varga in 1947 by Ravelo himself in Bulaklak Magazine, and re-illustrated in 1950 by Nestor Redondo in Pilipino Komiks. Garcia made more animation programs for television, like Isko: Adventures in Animasia, 1995, and Ibong Adarna (Adarna: The Mythical Bird), 1997, based on the classic korido (metrical tale).

 

Also in the late 1980s, the Alcazaren siblings Mike, Johnny, Gabriel, and Marita experimented with clay animation for Van Melle’s television commercial Fruit-tella candy, which won Best Animation in the 1990 Ad Congress. This was followed by more stop-motion clay animation works for Sime Darby, Ramcar International, Consolidated Foods Corporation, Unilever, and the Central Bank, which were recognized in Ad Congresses, Araw Awards, Creative Guild Awards, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards (Alcazaren 2012). In 1993, their animated ad series for Pepsi won first prize in the HOW Magazine International Design Competition. The Alcazaren Brothers did animation works for children’s television programs Batibot (Small but Strong), 1984-2000, and 5 and Up, 1992-2002, where they experimented on other animation techniques using paper cutouts, collage, and chalk, and the opening billboard of the public affairs program The Probe Team, 1988-2010. The chalk animation title sequence for 5 and Up won in the New York Animation Festival in 1995.

 

The children’s program Batibot employed animation, especially cutouts, in many of its modular lessons, educational music videos, and storytelling sequences. Its animation “Nguyamyam” (Devour), about humanity’s destruction of the earth, won the gold medal in the New York TV and Film Festival in 1992. Other educational TV programs followed Batibot’s use of animation for many of their segments, such as Sineskwela (School on Air), Math-tinik (Math Genius), and Epol Apple, all in 1994, by ABS-CBN Lingkod Kapamilya Foundation, and Batang Bibbo! (Bright Child!), 2009, GMA.

 

From the 1990s onward, notable independent groups were Top Peg Animation & Creative Studio Inc and Gecko Animation, under the creative direction of Marie Grace Dimaranan, who produced Tutubi Patrol (Dragonfly Patrol), 2003, ABC 5. The television animation series was based on a 1994 children’s book of the same title. Main characters of the series were Tobi (blue dragonfly) and Yobi (yellow dragonfly), who serve as reporters of problems in the animal and plant kingdoms. It was awarded an Anak TV Seal in Feb 2006.

 

ABS-CBN put up its own animation department in 2005 under Enrico Santos and Guia Jose. The unit created the television action-fantasy series Super Inggo, 2006, and Super Inggo at ang Super Tropa (Super Inggo and the Super Troupe), 2009, which were patterned after the Japanese anime. Both series used the Adobe Flash animation software.

 

Independent Filipino animators and producers ventured into 3D Flash animated television productions, like BIDA: Batang Iwas Droga (Protagonist: Children Against Drugs), 2003, NBN 4, produced by the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation, the Government Service Insurance System, and the Philippine Charity Sweepstakes Office; and Barkada Trip (Friendly Gang Trip), 2005, Studio 23. These works served as testing grounds for producing 3D Flash animation films, such as Mike Tuviera’s Urduja, 2008, produced by APT Entertainment, Seventoon, and Imaginary Friends; Robert Quilao’s Dayo: Sa Mundo ng Elementalia (The Wanderer in the Land of Elementalia), 2008, by Cutting Edge Production; and Luis Suarez’s RPG Metanoia, 2010, by Ambient Media, Thaumatrope Animation, and Star Cinema.

 

A good short animation feature was Ramon del Prado’s Egg, 2005, GMA. Other formats made use of animation, such as Ka-Blog (Blog Mate), 2008, GMA, a magazine program hosted by four teens who discussed adolescent life and featured computer gaming and the latest technological gadgets. Animated music videos performed by Filipino bands included Sama Na (Join Us), 2006, by Chillitees, and Pugad (Nest), 2008, by Sugarfree. TV shows also make use of animation to show special effects. Some TV series that focus on fantasy themes, like Rounin, Mulawin, and Encantadia (Fairyland), used computerized animation effects as part of producing the episodes. Advertisements make use of animation usually when demonstrating the visualization of how the product works, or when a brand mascot is shown. Usually, these are shown in commercials that feature cleaning products in general, like Surf and Safeguard.

 

Noteworthy storyboard animations that were uploaded onto virtual websites included Siopawman (Siopao Man), 2007, produced by Tony Gloria for Toon Manila, directed by Kinjo Estioko and Pete Jimenez, which was based on Larry Alcala’s comic strip character created in 1946 that was first serialized in Halakhak Komiks; Combatron, 2007, produced by Unitel and Toon Manila for Optima Digital, based on a superhero cyborg character created by Berlin H. Manalaysay that was first serialized in Pilipino Funny Komiks in 1990; Insanigans (Cousin Friends), 2006, about a 13-year-old artistic boy who has powers that can destroy evil technologies; and Libingan (Cemetery), 2007, a 20-minute animated drama by Tuldok Animation, a trailer of which was shown in the same year on Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho), GMA. These animation works were intended for broadcast but they were never shown on television.

 

As a major industry, animation agencies started to be set up in the country beginning in the 1980s, some of which include Burbank Animation Inc, Asian Animation, Fil-Cartoons, Toei Animation Philippines, Roadrunner, Toon City Animation Inc, and Tuldok Animation Studios. Most animation studios in the Philippines have been subcontracting animation work from studios abroad, mainly from the United States and Europe.

 

Animation works produced for Philippine television, while distinctly creative and Filipino-inspired, hardly recovered their production costs and found it difficult to commercially compete with foreign animated broadcast productions and films. Current government support, through the Animation Council of the Philippines Inc (ACPI) and the Information Technology and Business Process Association of the Philippines, is not enough to cover local animation production works, which are more costly than producing live-action films. However, short animation works as applied to television programs for children and commercial advertising remain the commercially viable style and form for television broadcasting.

 

Today, ACPI annually holds its annual Philippine Animation festival known as Animahenasyon, a portmanteau of animation, imagination, and nation. In partnership with Hero TV, a Filipino cable television channel showing primarily Filipino-dubbed anime/animation programs, entries in the Animahenasyon festival, with interviews with the animators, are featured in its broadcast programs to inspire budding artists to create original animation works. Written by Mae U. Caralde, Eulalio R. Guieb III, and Thea Claudette R. Castañeda

 

Sources

Alcazaren 2012; Dimaranan; Orellana 2014; Philstar.com 2011; Sanchez 2011; Sketchpride 2008; Vera 2009; Wikipedia 2015a, 2015b.

text:
Arts and culture programs highlight a people's way of life and its expressions in art for radio and television audiences. This way of life encompasses language, traditions, beliefs, religion, social norms, and the arts. Distinctiveness in the characteristics, practices, and artistic expressions provides the motive for the creation of the culture and arts show. The show may be presented in various formats like magazine, documentary, educational/tutorial, art appreciation, travel, talk, debate, or a mixture of the aforementioned types.

 

The balagtasan or poetic joust, usually about a social issue or a cultural tradition, is one of the early forms of the arts and culture show on radio, which began in 1934. The first balagtasan on air, a debate on the topic "Sino ang higit na dapat mahalin: ina, asawa, o anak?" (Who deserves greater love: mother, wife, or offspring?), pitted the abilities of Fernando Monleon, Francisco Paño, and Emilio Mar Antonio with the third emerging as the winner. The balagtasan as an art program enjoyed wide radio listenership up to the 1960s when it also invaded television programming (Philippine Literature Portal 2015; Jimenez 1996).

 

Another type of arts and culture program is the classical music program pioneered by the Far East Broadcasting Company (DZFE) in 1954. Its first broadcast aired western classical music and My Nipa Hut, a Filipino musical. Since then, DZFE has specialized in classical music appreciation (98.7 DZFE 2015). The Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC) DZRH in the mid-1950s promoted the appreciation for harana or serenade tradition through Serenatang Kumbidahan (Serenade by Invitation) hosted by Dely Magpayo until its final episode in 2005 (Enriquez 2005). The same format was revived in 2006 in a program titled Harana ng Puso (The Heart's Serenade), hosted by Michael Coroza on Philippine Broadcasting Service DWBR FM and DWRB Radyo ng Bayan AM. A typical episode of the weekly program features intertextual performances in poetry and kundiman (love song) with live accompaniment (Coroza 2011). In 2007, MBC launched Art 2 Art on DZRH with a simulcast on RHTV cable channel and DZRH online live streaming. Its host, ballet dancer Lisa Macuja, interviews artists who have contributed to society with their artistic pursuits and advocacies in the 30-minute talk show (Art2Art 2014).

 

Balintataw (The Mind's Eye) is a TV program that aired from 1967 to 1972 on ABC 5, produced by Cecile Guidote, who also founded the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) at around the same time. The 60-minute weekly drama anthology was supported by a creative team from the literary and theater fields namely, Alberto Florentino, Mauro Avena, Nick Lizaso, Lino Brocka, Elwood Perez, and Joey Gosiengfiao and the young theater artists of PETA. Hosted by Robert Arevalo and directed by Lupita Concio, the anthology was based on original scripts including those written by Florentino, Avena, Elwood Perez, Ninotchka Rosca, and Tony Perez; as well as adaptations from literary works of Jose Rizal, Nick Joaquin, Bienvenido Santos, Wilfrido Nolledo, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Kerima Polotan, and Gilda Cordero-Fernando. The drama program also introduced to the Filipino audience the works of foreign literary writers like O. Henry, D. H. Lawrence, and Tennessee Williams (Santos 2008; Matignas 2012, 21-44).

 

Leading government institutions in arts and culture have produced programs to promote their mandate since the 1970s. During the martial law period, media and culture bureaucrats of the Marcos regime promoted the classics among the common people through open-air performances with free admission in Concert at the Park at the Rizal Park, Puerta Real Evenings in Intramuros, and Paco Park Presents in Paco Cemetery. The shows featured ballet concerts, orchestra music, piano, and violin recitals, and soprano and tenor performances. The taped-as-live performances were aired and rerun over the government TV station (Hila 2007).

 

Armida Siguion-Reyna produced Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), which ran for 35 years starting in 1970. Siguion-Reyna is one of the prominent producers of TV shows on art, history, and cultural heritage beginning in the martial law era until the early 2000s. Aawitan Kita aired on TV stations ABS-CBN, RPN 9, and ABC 5. Shot on lyrical and romantic locations with meticulous production design that generally evoked nostalgia, it showcased Filipino musical forms like the kundiman and the balitaw (courtship song). Filipino musicians and artists who rendered their talents in the show include Ric Manrique, Diomedes Maturan, Lirio Vital, Restie Umali, Levi Celerio, who was later named National Artist for music, and Atang de la Rama, who was later proclaimed National Artist for theater (Tupaz 2006; Protacio 2014). Siguion-Reyna also pioneered in historical movies for television, which were produced as Aawitan Kita TV specials. Among these was Dung-aw (Lament), 1975, directed by Lino Brocka and scripted by Mario O’Hara. This historical and musical film depicts the heroism of Gabriela Silang, portrayed by Siguion-Reyna herself (Pandayang Lino Brocka 2011). Another was Ang Lakambini at Ang Supremo (The Muse and the Supreme Chief), 1975, about Gregoria de Jesus, the lakambini, and her husband Andres Bonifacio, the supremo of the revolutionary Katipunan. It is the first film for television about Bonifacio’s trial and execution perpetrated by his rival leaders in the Katipunan. The lead actors in this historical drama are Siguion-Reyna as Gregoria de Jesus, Robert Arevalo as Andres Bonifacio, and Eddie Garcia as Emilio Aguinaldo (Melcore 2010).

 

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) produced Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), hosted by Mon Ilagan. The weekly radio program aired over DZRV Radio Veritas in 1986-92, and then transferred to the Philippine Broadcasting Service DZRM Radyo Magasin until 1996. The segments of the magazine program highlighted music and theater, discussions on issues in arts and culture, and balagtasan on current sociopolitical issues. In 1990, the CCP Public Relations Division partnered with 98.7 DZFE to produce Culture Carousel hosted by Irene Rada. The weekly radio program features upcoming CCP music artists, interviews with members of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO), and PPO recorded performances. The program also airs interviews with visiting artists from other countries with samples of their music. It presents not only classical musicians but also artists in ballet, theater, and visual arts. The show usually ends with an enumeration and description of forthcoming CCP events.

 

Radio can be utilized as a means to revive the art of storytelling for children. The CCP, in cooperation with the Alitaptap Storytellers Philippines, the Philippine Board on Books for Young People, and DZAS radio produced a 30-minute program titled Wan Dey, Isang Araw (One Day) from 2005 to 2013. The program, hosted by Luis Gatmaitan, featured works in classical and contemporary Philippine children’s literature that were considered outstanding, including stories written by Rene Villanueva, Christine Bellen, Gatmaitan, and Grace Chong. Despite its many awards, insufficient funding caused the production to fold up (Rada 2015; Tresvalles 2015).


The CCP also ventured into the production of TV programs to promote Philippine arts and culture. One of these was Pinoy Eh, a magazine show produced in 1990 and telecast over ABC 5. The show consisted of 13 episodes directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya and hosted by Ces Quesada. It discussed the Filipino language, music, cinema, architecture, literature, and dance. It also featured episodes on the Filipino observance of Christian rituals like Holy Week and Christmas, as well as on special topics like the Aeta ethnic group and the town of Angono (Sulicipan-Vibal 2015). Another CCP drama production for television was Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1992, based on Jose Rizal’s novel. The series of 13 episodes continue to enjoy reruns on local television. Directed by Eddie Romero, later proclaimed National Artist for film, it starred Joel Torre as Crisostomo Ibarra, Chin Chin Gutierrez as Maria Clara, and Tetchie Agbayani as Sisa (Filipinas Heritage Library 2015).


The National Commission for Culture and the Arts as the main government agency on arts and culture is also a producer of significant arts and culture shows, especially on television. Tipong Pinoy (Filipino Style), produced in 1998, consists of 26 episodes hosted by Wency Cornejo and Susan Calo-Medina. The 30-minute magazine show enjoys repeat airings on IBC 13 and the Knowledge Channel. It tackles Filipino customs, beliefs, spirituality, religion, and the arts. Sa Sariling Lupa: Cultural Tourism Documentaries (In One’s Own Land: Cultural Tourism Documentaries), 1999, was broadcast on PTV 4. The show was a joint project with the Department of Tourism, the National Historical Institute, and the National Museum. The episodes present the idea of traveling to Philippine destinations, such as Rizal, Laguna, Davao, Cebu, Baguio, Banaue, Laoag, Vigan, Bohol, and Palawan, in order to experience Filipino culture and arts. ArtTalk: Beyond Entertainment was aired on NET 25 in 2012, hosted by Gemma Cruz-Araneta. Discussions in the 30-minute talk show reflect on questions like the cultural roots of discrimination and corruption. Other topics include explorations and opinions on the role of artists and cultural workers from among the Moro, Christians, and Lumad. Art Republik was produced in cooperation with the Asian Christian Arts Association Inc, a nongovernment organization. The 30-minute show was first aired in 2012 on cable station Knowledge Channel. It features profiles of artists and highlights Filipino cultural values and traits like close family ties, bayanihan (community spirit), perseverance, and courage (NCCA Annual Report 2012,11; Inquirer.net 2012).

 

IBC 13 produced Cooltura (Cool Culture) in 2011-12 with repeat airings in succeeding years. The magazine show, hosted by Cathy Eigenmann and Pat Natividad, featured topics with a popular treatment. Segments essayed subjects like Philippine architecture, traditional rituals like the sanghiyang (dancing on fire), belief in anting-anting or talisman, local winemaking, Filipino-Chinese arts and culture, unique soil painting of an indigenous group, textile making from native fibers, and local coffee culture. IBC 13 made a full-length Cooltura TV special to commemorate Philippine independence titled A Taste of History: Isang Malinamnam na Kalayaan (A Taste of History: A Delicious Freedom). article.value: Arts and culture programs highlight a people's way of life and its expressions in art for radio and television audiences. This way of life encompasses language, traditions, beliefs, religion, social norms, and the arts. Distinctiveness in the characteristics, practices, and artistic expressions provides the motive for the creation of the culture and arts show. The show may be presented in various formats like magazine, documentary, educational/tutorial, art appreciation, travel, talk, debate, or a mixture of the aforementioned types.

The balagtasan or poetic joust, usually about a social issue or a cultural tradition, is one of the early forms of the arts and culture show on radio, which began in 1934. The first balagtasan on air, a debate on the topic "Sino ang higit na dapat mahalin: ina, asawa, o anak?" (Who deserves greater love: mother, wife, or offspring?), pitted the abilities of Fernando Monleon, Francisco Paño, and Emilio Mar Antonio with the third emerging as the winner. The balagtasan as an art program enjoyed wide radio listenership up to the 1960s when it also invaded television programming (Philippine Literature Portal 2015; Jimenez 1996).

Another type of arts and culture program is the classical music program pioneered by the Far East Broadcasting Company (DZFE) in 1954. Its first broadcast aired western classical music and My Nipa Hut, a Filipino musical. Since then, DZFE has specialized in classical music appreciation (98.7 DZFE 2015). The Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC) DZRH in the mid-1950s promoted the appreciation for harana or serenade tradition through Serenatang Kumbidahan (Serenade by Invitation) hosted by Dely Magpayo until its final episode in 2005 (Enriquez 2005). The same format was revived in 2006 in a program titled Harana ng Puso (The Heart's Serenade), hosted by Michael Coroza on Philippine Broadcasting Service DWBR FM and DWRB Radyo ng Bayan AM. A typical episode of the weekly program features intertextual performances in poetry and kundiman (love song) with live accompaniment (Coroza 2011). In 2007, MBC launched Art 2 Art on DZRH with a simulcast on RHTV cable channel and DZRH online live streaming. Its host, ballet dancer Lisa Macuja, interviews artists who have contributed to society with their artistic pursuits and advocacies in the 30-minute talk show (Art2Art 2014).

Balintataw (The Mind's Eye) is a TV program that aired from 1967 to 1972 on ABC 5, produced by Cecile Guidote, who also founded the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) at around the same time. The 60-minute weekly drama anthology was supported by a creative team from the literary and theater fields namely, Alberto Florentino, Mauro Avena, Nick Lizaso, Lino Brocka, Elwood Perez, and Joey Gosiengfiao and the young theater artists of PETA. Hosted by Robert Arevalo and directed by Lupita Concio, the anthology was based on original scripts including those written by Florentino, Avena, Elwood Perez, Ninotchka Rosca, and Tony Perez; as well as adaptations from literary works of Jose Rizal, Nick Joaquin, Bienvenido Santos, Wilfrido Nolledo, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Kerima Polotan, and Gilda Cordero-Fernando. The drama program also introduced to the Filipino audience the works of foreign literary writers like O. Henry, D. H. Lawrence, and Tennessee Williams (Santos 2008; Matignas 2012, 21-44).

Leading government institutions in arts and culture have produced programs to promote their mandate since the 1970s. During the martial law period, media and culture bureaucrats of the Marcos regime promoted the classics among the common people through open-air performances with free admission in Concert at the Park at the Rizal Park, Puerta Real Evenings in Intramuros, and Paco Park Presents in Paco Cemetery. The shows featured ballet concerts, orchestra music, piano, and violin recitals, and soprano and tenor performances. The taped-as-live performances were aired and rerun over the government TV station (Hila 2007).

Armida Siguion-Reyna produced Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), which ran for 35 years starting in 1970. Siguion-Reyna is one of the prominent producers of TV shows on art, history, and cultural heritage beginning in the martial law era until the early 2000s. Aawitan Kita aired on TV stations ABS-CBN, RPN 9, and ABC 5. Shot on lyrical and romantic locations with meticulous production design that generally evoked nostalgia, it showcased Filipino musical forms like the kundiman and the balitaw (courtship song). Filipino musicians and artists who rendered their talents in the show include Ric Manrique, Diomedes Maturan, Lirio Vital, Restie Umali, Levi Celerio, who was later named National Artist for music, and Atang de la Rama, who was later proclaimed National Artist for theater (Tupaz 2006; Protacio 2014). Siguion-Reyna also pioneered in historical movies for television, which were produced as Aawitan Kita TV specials. Among these was Dung-aw (Lament), 1975, directed by Lino Brocka and scripted by Mario O’Hara. This historical and musical film depicts the heroism of Gabriela Silang, portrayed by Siguion-Reyna herself (Pandayang Lino Brocka 2011). Another was Ang Lakambini at Ang Supremo (The Muse and the Supreme Chief), 1975, about Gregoria de Jesus, the lakambini, and her husband Andres Bonifacio, the supremo of the revolutionary Katipunan. It is the first film for television about Bonifacio’s trial and execution perpetrated by his rival leaders in the Katipunan. The lead actors in this historical drama are Siguion-Reyna as Gregoria de Jesus, Robert Arevalo as Andres Bonifacio, and Eddie Garcia as Emilio Aguinaldo (Melcore 2010).

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) produced Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), hosted by Mon Ilagan. The weekly radio program aired over DZRV Radio Veritas in 1986-92, and then transferred to the Philippine Broadcasting Service DZRM Radyo Magasin until 1996. The segments of the magazine program highlighted music and theater, discussions on issues in arts and culture, and balagtasan on current sociopolitical issues. The program also airs interviews with visiting artists from other countries with samples of their music. It presents not only classical musicians but also artists in ballet, theater, and visual arts. The show usually ends with an enumeration and description of forthcoming CCP events.

Radio can be utilized as a means to revive the art of storytelling for children. text:
Balagtasan programs feature the traditional Tagalog verse debate on radio or television. Balagtasan, considered to be the Philippine contribution to world literature, is a poetic debate named in 1924 after Francisco Balagtas, author of Florante at Laura and regarded as the most prominent Filipino poet. Taking from earlier forms like the duplo, it involves a poetic joust between two poets who take opposing sides of an issue, with a mediator called lakandiwa if male and lakambini if female and a team of judges who select a winner. The issues debated on, often posed in the form of a question and a choice between two contrasting or conflicting alternatives, ranged from the political to the social and philosophical. It is a public display of wit, intelligence, eloquence, and poetic ability as well as an entertaining theatrical performance.

 

The first balagtasan was held on 6 Apr 1924 featuring three debates, from which Jose Corazon de Jesus aka Huseng Batute and Florentino Collantes aka Kuntil Butil emerged as winners and crowd favorites. They were hailed as the first kings of balagtasan as the form gained wide popularity. The verse debate became so famous that the Kapampangan created their own poetic joust called crissotan, in honor of their major writer Juan Crisostomo Soto, while the Ilocano had bucanegan, after Pedro Bucaneg, who wrote the epic Biag ni Lam-ang (Life of Lam-ang). Spanish and English versions followed suit.

 

De Jesus recorded some of his poetry, including Ang Manok Kong Bulik (My Black-and-White Chicken), Ang Pagbabalik (The Return), and Ang Pamana (The Legacy), which aired on prewar radio. Two years after his death in 1932, the program Balagtasan on the Air began airing on KZRM, sponsored by Elizalde and Co. It was the idea of Elizalde’s advertising manager Pedro Teodoro, who supported Tagalog as the Filipino national language. Collantes, Emilio Mar Antonio, Domingo Carasig, and Epifania Alvarez were frequent debaters (Jimenez 1996, 33B). In one episode, the poetic joust answered the question, “Which affords greater pleasure: a married life or a life of singleness?”

 

Balagtasan disappeared on radio during World War II. In the early 1950s, DZRH, the successor of the prewar KZRH, now under the ownership of Elizalde, brought balagtasan back on the air. Emilio Antonio defeated Fernando Monleon and Francisco Paño after debating on the issue “Sino ang higit na dapat mahalin: ina, asawa, o anak?” (Who deserves greater love: mother, wife, or offspring?). He was then named Prince of Balagtasan by the Kapisanan ng mga Makata at Mambibigkas in 1951 while Collantes was named King of Balagtasan after debating over “Dapat bang pairalin ang import control sa Pilipinas?” (Should import control be allowed in the Philippines?). Antonio then became the administrator and mediator of the balagtasan on the air.

 

In the 1960s, Tino Estanislao wrote and directed Oras ng Balagtasan (Balagtasan Hour) for DZRH, Sundays, 9:00-10:00 pm. The program was produced by Jose Espinol, who was also its recording technician, and featured mambabalagtas (poetic debaters) Tony Raymundo and Ophelia Angeles who debated on themes like “Alin ang higit na mas matimbang: puso o utak?” (Which is weightier: the heart or the mind?), “Ano’ng pipiliin mo: dalagang makaluma o dalagang makabago?” (Which do you prefer: a conservative or a modern maiden?), and “Sa kasal ng babae, ang kaniya bang pagluha ay sa kalungkutan o kaligayahan?” (When a woman marries, are her tears of sadness or of joy?). In Aug 1973, Rudy Cruzado and Betty Desquitado Camaligan replaced Raymundo and Angeles, until the program’s end in 1976.

 

In 1986, Camaligan produced and directed Balagtasan ng Lahi (Balagtasan of the Race) with her husband Rafael Francisco Roxas on Philippine Broadcasting Service DZRB Radyo ng Bayan 738 on AM, Sundays, 8:00-9:00 pm. Nicknamed “Prinsesa ng Balagtasan” (Princess of Balagtasan), she debated on the air with Apollo Marquez aka Makata ng Maynila, with Berting Suallo as lakandiwa and C. C. Marquez, nicknamed “Hari ng Balagtasan” (King of Balagtasan), as writer. Susan Buniel was one of its recording technicians. Some of the topics debated on were “Sino’ng sasagipin: ang ina mo o ang asawa mo?” (Who would you save: your mother or your wife?), “Alin ang dapat gamitin: ang pangaral o ang pamalo?” (Which should be used [to discipline a child]: moral lecture or corporal punishment?), and “Alin ang mas masakit: ang hagkis ng dila o latay sa katawan?” (Which hurts more: a biting tongue or a whipping?).

 

After the EDSA Revolt of 1986 and in pursuit of its new thrust toward Filipinization and democratization, the Cultural Center of the Philippines produced a weekly radio program called Kultura ng Bayan (The Country’s Culture) over DZRH, 1986-92, and on DZRM, 1992-96, which aired original Filipino music and held a balagtasan on current sociopolitical issues, like the US Bases Treaty.

 

Balagtasan ng Lahi folded up in Sep 1995 but Camaligan Roxas revived balagtasan initially for Filipinos living abroad by airing Awit, Tula at Balagtasan (Song, Poetry, and Poetic Joust) on the government shortwave station DZRP Radyo Pilipinas of the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS) beginning Feb 1996, Sundays, 2:00-3:00 am. A year later, the program was also carried by two other government stations on the AM band, DZRM Radyo Magasin, Sundays, 8:00-9:00 pm, and DZRB Radyo ng Bayan, Sundays, 9:00-10:00 am. In 2013, when Camaligan Roxas retired from the PBS, the curtain went down as well on balagtasan on the air. Written by Victor Emmanuel Carmelo D. Nadera Jr

 

Sources

Enriquez 2008; Jimenez 1996; Literary Song-Movie Magazine 1941, 23.

text:
Children’s programs are programs on radio or television whose target audience are 18 year-olds and younger. The subject matter of these shows, which are often educational, are presented in formats and styles that children can comprehend, using either children or grown-ups or both as hosts. Different ages require the development of different subject matter, and genres bleed into one another in an attempt to capture as large an audience segment as possible.

 

Before television mesmerized children with imported syndicated animated shows beginning in the late 1950s, radio aired programs for children as early as the American colonial period. These were mostly magazine programs where an adult host, introduced as everyone’s aunt or uncle, presided over children singing. During the Japanese occupation, a program featured a Japanese teacher teaching Filipino and Japanese children Japanese songs (Enriquez 2008, 92, 203). After the war, quiz programs attracted children and teenagers, such as Radio Schoolhouse, hosted by Ira Davis, and Spell to Win, hosted by Norman Reyes and Hal Bowie, both in the 1950s. From the 1960s to the 1970s, the musical shows Eskuwelahang Munti (Little School), hosted by Tinno Lapus, Operetang Putol-Putol (Operetta in Pieces), hosted by Manolo Favis, and Tita Betty’s Children’s Hour, hosted by Betty Mendez, nurtured children aspiring to become singers and actors. Eskuwelahang Munti later went on television and a film was produced based on it.

 

Children’s shows on radio began to disappear in the 1970s as television became the preferred medium for such programs. The programs range from cartoons to live action skits, magazine programs, talk shows, and game shows. Many are syndicates imported from other countries, such as Sesame Street and The Muppet Show, Disney cartoons, and robot cartoons like Voltes V, Mazinger Z, and Daimos. An early and enduring local production was the weekly Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club on RBS Channel 7 beginning in the 1960s until the 1990s, hosted by Bob Stewart, who took on the persona of a cheerful uncle who entertained kids with activities, toys and games, and musical numbers on the air. In 1984, the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation produced Batibot (Small but Strong), the first Filipino educational television program for kids.

 

Beginning in the 1990s, television program producers began to stop seeing children as one homogenous group but as having different needs according to age, culture, and even class. The audience identified as “children” was then segmented into preschool, school-age, juvenile, tween, and other brackets. Required by the law to devote a percentage of their programming to local programs for Filipino kids, networks expanded into educational programs, such as Mathtinik (Math Wiz), Sineskwela (School on Air), ATBP (Etcetera); drama programs such as Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), Bayani (Hero), and Pahina (Page); magazine shows such as 5 and Up, Chikiting Patrol (Children’s Patrol), and Yan ang Bata (That’s the Kid); art shows such as Art Angel, Art Is Kool, Art Jam, Sining Gising (Arts Awake), and Tropang Potchi (The Potchi Troop); and gag and variety shows such as Ang TV! (The TV!) and Eh Kasi Bata (Because It’s a Child). Written by Daphne-Tatiana T. Canlas
