text:
Advice on romance, relationships, marriage, and family problems is one of the most in demand of consulting services. Programs on radio and television that give advice or opinion to direct the behavior of counselees are called counseling programs.

 

The staying power of radio and TV counseling programs is strongly attributed to the counselor’s ability to give advice. This is demonstrated by the on-air counseling career of Dely Magpayo aka Tiya Dely, which spanned over 60 years. She was given the break in 1953 to start a DZRH radio counseling program titled Ang Kasaysayan sa mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (The Stories behind the Letters to Aunt Dely). It was inspired by the overwhelming success of American radio counselor Dorothy Dix at the time. The format of the program revolved around letters sent by listeners. Tiya Dely knew nothing about counseling at the onset but learned on the job by reading 20 to 30 letters every day, doing research on specific issues of letter senders, and giving practical advice. Moreover, there was the big chance for a serendipitous solution due to radio’s broad listenership. Such was the case with a teacher’s unwanted pregnancy that Tiya Dely “solved” by introducing her to listeners who happened to be a childless couple (Philstar.com 2000; San Diego 2005).

 

The radio advice program Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) in 1955 on DZXL propelled the broadcasting career of Eddie Ilarde, which extended to over six decades. The program centered on letters from listeners about romantic problems. The show’s catchphrases like “Dear Kuya Eddie” (Dear Brother Eddie) and “Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie” (It Hurts, Brother Eddie) elicited empathy from a broad audience. Kahapon Lamang became a top-rating TV drama in 1976-86 on GMA 7. Napakasakit Kuya Eddie was produced as a drama show in 1986-88 on ABS-CBN.

 

Similarly, problems of letter senders were discussed on DZBB’s Lovingly Yours, Helen. The radio program that started in the 1970s was simultaneously produced as a Sunday TV show on GMA 7 and on BBC 2 from 1980 to 1992. Each episode in the TV drama anthology focused on a letter read by radio-TV host Helen Vela. The background music “Ballade Pour Adeline” was played as Vela read the letter sender’s predicament before it was dramatized by famous actors. The same melancholy music was repeated as Vela gave her advice in the end. Lovingly Yours, Helen ended with Vela’s untimely death. It made a successful TV comeback with Vela’s daughter, Princess Punzalan, as host from 1992 to 1996 (80’s Pinas 2009).

 

Also in the 1980s, Joe d’ Mango started a long career in counseling through a 15-minute gimmick launched by FM station DWTM Magic 89.9 every Friday morning. Dubbed as Love Notes, it was a surprise hit among office workers. Love Notes was subsequently produced as a drama anthology aired on ABC 5 in 1992-96 and a movie in 1995. Joe d’ Mango’s Love Notes was relaunched on DZMM 630 and ABS-CBN TeleRadyo in 2011, with a more interactive approach that allows the audience to share their own love quotes and to dedicate songs to their loved ones(Jarloc 2011).

 

 

 

The Love Clinic on DWRX 93.1 with Dr Love in the early 1990s allowed listeners to express their lovesick feelings on air through the pager. Carlo Sanchez as Dr Love would read a love letter and play a love song that suited the romantic issues of the letter sender. This created a cathartic effect that proved to be more effective than giving straight advice (Dipasupil 1994, 18). Twenty years later, Tom Alvarez as Dr Love has maintained the audience support of the one-hour program with the same formula of reading emotional letters, followed by soothing advice, and capped by a sentimental love song. Listeners may text through cell phone, comment on Facebook, or tweet messages (Bubblenews.com 2014).

 

The moniker Dr Love is also used on DZMM 630 by Bro Jun Banaag, Third Order of the Order of Preachers, who has given advice to phone callers about their problems on relationships since the late 1990s. He gained audience support by the disclosure of his own infidelity and subsequent repentance that resulted in reconciliation with his wife. As one who has “sinned and repented,” the audience perceives him as a truthful and approachable counselor (Choa 2013).

 

In 2004, a new trend in radio counseling programs was developed by two radio talents who started as wacky partners in traffic reporting. The rapport between Chris Tsuper and Nicole Hyala prompted the management of Manila Broadcasting Company to give them a daily morning show on DZMB, an FM station with the nickname 90.7 LOVE Radio, and on cable station RHTV. Funny admonitions using gay lingo and pop expressions are the counseling techniques adopted by Tambalan ng Isang Balasubas at ng Isang Balahura (A Swindler and a Filthy Tandem). Capitalizing on the Filipino’s penchant for laughing at his/her own misery, the hosts read texters’ problems on romance, self, or family in a comic manner. Both listeners and counselees know that the tandem’s pieces of advice are not to be taken seriously. In spite of criticisms over how they flippantly treat the texters’ predicaments, the tambalan have fans called tambalanistas. By the time they celebrated the program’s 10th anniversary, Chris Tsuper and Nicole Hyala had launched a book, produced a song album, and signed up for several product endorsements (Maaño 2011).

 

 

Another self-styled counselor who has droves of loyal listeners on DZMB 90.7 LOVE Radio is Papa Jack, aka Papa ng Laging Saklolo (Father of Perpetual Help). He gives lengthy advice on air to phone callers through his program True Love Conversation and Wild Confessions airing late on weeknights up to early morning. Letters may be sent through an online entry form via official LOVE Radio e-mail, with a chance to be featured in the segment called “The Letter by Papa Jack.” The success of the show gave way to a book launched in 2013 titled Everything I Need to Know about Love I Learned from Papa Jack.

 

Radio and TV counseling formats also include medical, legal, and other professional advice regulated by the 2007 Broadcast Code of the Philippines (KBP 2007, 17-18). The code stipulates that any medical, legal, and other professional advice given on radio and TV must come from authoritative, identified, and reliable sources. Professional advice on sexual behavior is also included in this category. Sex therapist Dr Margarita Go-Singco Holmes is a professional psychologist, author, and academician. In the 1990s, Holmes hosted No Nonsense with Dr. Holmes, the pioneering show that openly tackled taboo subjects like sexual behavior and relations, including homosexual relationship. Holmes also hosted the counseling segment “Magtanong Kay Dra. Holmes” (Ask Dr Holmes) within the ABS-CBN program Teysi ng Tahanan (Tessie of the Home), 1991-97. These counseling shows legitimized sex as an important topic in broadcast media (margaritaholmes.com 2014).

 

Counseling programs enjoy a big audience share because of the savvy and popular appeal of the counselors. It is noteworthy that majority of radio and TV counselors are not professional psychologists but media practitioners who have a good sense of what the audience wants. However, most importantly, the program type has maintained audience support throughout the various epochs of Philippine broadcasting because it responds to the basic human desire to find happiness, love, self-worth, inner peace, and harmony in human relations. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

 

Sources

80’s Pinas 2009; Bubblenews.com 2014; Choa 2013; Dipasupil 1994; Jarloc 2011; JobsDB.com 2010; KBP 2007; Loveradio.com 2014; Maaño 2011; Margaritaholmes.com 2014; The Philippine Star 2000; San Diego 2005.

article_title: Dokyu, Investigative Report, and Talk Public Affairs

photos.desc:
Dong Puno, host of Dong Puno Live, 2003

(Photo courtesy of ABS-CBN)

Randy David and Katrina Legarda, hosts of Off the Record, 2002

(Photo courtesy of ABS-CBN)

text:
The dokyu or documentary and the investigative report are presentational reports, expository narratives, and argumentative exploration of actual events, peoples, and places caught on sound and video in their almost natural state or under minimal directing to achieve the desired statement of the broadcast program. A talk public affairs show is a commentary or discussion of current events, with the host all by himself or herself, or with an interviewee or a panel of guests who are deemed knowledgeable about the subject under examination. These programs propose an argument or an opinion about the topic.

 

Before documentaries and investigative reports became popular, the talk program was the most common, especially the scripted and rehearsed interviews on the Voice of the Philippines, KZRM, KZRH, KZRC, KZRF, KZEG, KZIB, and KZKZ, from the late 1930s until the outbreak of World War II. Propaganda talk commentary was the main feature in the station Voice of Freedom, the program Tinig ng Kalayaan (Voice of Freedom), and the Japanese-controlled KZRH during World War II. Pre-martial law radio commentators who gained credibility and popularity were the hard-hitting Rafael Yabut in Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw (Wake Up at the Break of Dawn), DZRH, and Damian Sotto in Mangatwiran Ka (Reason Out), DZAQ. Print journalists had their television talk programs, such as Luis “Louie” Beltran in Straight from the Shoulder, 1970-72, MBC, and 1987-94, GMA 7; Maximo Soliven in Impact, early 1970s, ABS-CBN; Teddy Benigno in Firing Line, 1992-99, GMA 7; and Malou Mangahas in Investigative Documentaries, premiered 2011, GMA News TV. Personalities from other disciplines invaded the current affairs talk show. Lawyer Ricardo “Dong” Puno had Viewpoint, 1984-94, GMA 7; Dong Puno Live, 1995-2000, and Insider, 2005-6, both on ABS-CBN; Viewpoints, 2006-7, ANC; and Dong Puno de Kalibre (Quality Dong Puno), 2011-14, ABC 5. Lawyer Oscar Orbos and the University of the Philippines (UP) economist Solita Monsod had Debate with Mare at Pare, 1998-2006, GMA. Monsod hosts Bawal ang Pasaway kay Mareng Winnie (Mareng Winnie Prohibits Troublemakers), which premiered in 2011, GMA News TV. UP sociologist Randy David had Truth Forum, 1986-89, IBC 13, which was retitled Public Forum; Randy David sa Public Forum (Randy David on Public Forum), 1991-95, ABC 5; and Public Life with Randy David, 1997-2000, GMA. David also had a talk show with lawyer Katrina Legarda, Off the Record, 2001-2, ABS-CBN. The talk public affairs continues to be a popular format on radio.

 

 

 

A few significant documentaries were produced on radio. Examples are Sa Likod ng Balita (Behind the News), 1991-95, DXND-Kidapawan, Cotabato, which critically assessed both local and national political issues through the lens of culture; and Yaman ng Lahi (Bounty of the Race), 1992, DWLC Philippine Broadcasting System, which focused on the relevance of regional culture. DYFM Radyo Bombo Iloilo City came out with a series of magazine and public affairs documentaries in the 1990s that tackled how national current events shape the local history of the region.

The most common format of the documentary and the investigative report is that which involves the reporter who acts as the host who appears on camera, conducts interviews, investigates in the field, and does the voice-over of the narrative. An excellent example is Probe, later renamed The Probe Team, 1987-2010, hosted by Cheche Lazaro with her team of young broadcast journalists like Maria Ressa, Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Tony Velasquez, Judy Torres, and Angie Ramos. The weekly public affairs magazine program, which initially aired on ABS-CBN before it moved to different networks and is regarded as the first investigative broadcast journalism program in the country, critically examined the deeper aspects of socially important topics. Following the same format were programs from ABS-CBN, such as Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), 1988-2005, The Inside Story, 1990-98, and The Correspondents, 1998-2010; from GMA Network, such as i-Witness, which premiered in 1999, and Reporter’s Notebook, beginning in 2004; and from GMA News TV, Investigative Documentaries, which premiered in 2011.

 

 

 

Some aspects of the cinema verité tradition in filmmaking, which has less overt involvement of reporters and more cinematic approaches to camerawork and editing, have recently been adopted by broadcast documentaries, such as Reel Time and Front Row, which both premiered in 2011 on GMA News TV.

 

A few investigative reports employ stylized reenactments of events, like Imbestigador (Investigator), which premiered in 2000 on GMA Network, and Storyline, which premiered in 2008 on ANC and DZMM TeleRadyo.

 

The documentary is sometimes used as an introductory segment of any type of program, usually a talk show. In these documentaries, a narrator reads and records the script, but the reader is neither knowledgeable about the topic nor is involved in the writing of the script. Some have the voice of the program’s anchor, in which case the reader is familiar with the topic.

 

 

 

There are also single-airing documentaries, which are often political, such as those produced by Asia Visions during the martial period, which include The Arrogance of Power, about the rising protest against Marcos; Lakbayan: Lakad ng Bayan para sa Kalayaan (March of the People: Long March for Freedom), about the nationwide march of farmers and workers; and Beyond Prison, about political prisoners (Tiongson 1984). These were not aired in commercial broadcast stations but in alternative places to escape from the claws of the dictatorship. Documentaries of this type began to be aired on commercial networks during the post-martial law period, the most excellent examples of which were Ceasefire, 1986, IBC 13, which looked into the possibility of a ceasefire between the military and the underground National Democratic Front–New People’s Army; Ramut: The Roots of Revolution in the Cordillera, 1986, IBC 13, which traced the history of the struggle of the peoples of the Cordillera; Tiempo Muerto: Crisis and Poverty in Negros (Downtime: Crisis and Poverty in Negros), 1986, IBC 13, which looked into the situation of the sugar workers in central Philippines and the struggle for emancipation from hunger and feudal values (Tolentino 1987); and Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan (Dear Sam … Yours, Juan), 1989, which highlighted the protest movement and the art forms that critiqued the presence of US military bases in the country. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III w ith notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

 

Sources

CCP 1988-97; Tiongson 1984; Tolentino 1987.

Pre-martial law radio commentators who gained credibility and popularity were the hard-hitting Rafael Yabut in Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw (Wake Up at the Break of Dawn), DZRH, and Damian Sotto in Mangatwiran Ka (Reason Out), DZAQ. Print journalists had their television talk programs, such as Luis “Louie” Beltran in Straight from the Shoulder, 1970-72, MBC, and 1987-94, GMA 7; Maximo Soliven in Impact, early 1970s, ABS-CBN; Teddy Benigno in Firing Line, 1992-99, GMA 7; and Malou Mangahas in Investigative Documentaries, premiered 2011, GMA News TV. Personalities from other disciplines invaded the current affairs talk show. Lawyer Ricardo “Dong” Puno had Viewpoint, 1984-94, GMA 7; Dong Puno Live, 1995-2000, and Insider, 2005-6, both on ABS-CBN; Viewpoints, 2006-7, ANC; and Dong Puno de Kalibre (Quality Dong Puno), 2011-14, ABC 5. Lawyer Oscar Orbos and the University of the Philippines (UP) economist Solita Monsod had Debate with Mare at Pare, 1998-2006, GMA. Monsod hosts Bawal ang Pasaway kay Mareng Winnie (Mareng Winnie Prohibits Troublemakers), which premiered in 2011, GMA News TV. UP sociologist Randy David had Truth Forum, 1986-89, IBC 13, which was retitled Public Forum; Randy David sa Public Forum (Randy David on Public Forum), 1991-95, ABC 5; and Public Life with Randy David, 1997-2000, GMA. David also had a talk show with lawyer Katrina Legarda, Off the Record, 2001-2, ABS-CBN. The talk public affairs continues to be a popular format on radio.

article.value: A few significant documentaries were produced on radio. Examples are Sa Likod ng Balita (Behind the News), 1991-95, DXND-Kidapawan, Cotabato, which critically assessed both local and national political issues through the lens of culture; and Yaman ng Lahi (Bounty of the Race), 1992, DWLC Philippine Broadcasting System, which focused on the relevance of regional culture. DYFM Radyo Bombo Iloilo City came out with a series of magazine and public affairs documentaries in the 1990s that tackled how national current events shape the local history of the region.

The most common format of the documentary and the investigative report is that which involves the reporter who acts as the host who appears on camera, conducts interviews, investigates in the field, and does the voice-over of the narrative. An excellent example is Probe, later renamed The Probe Team, 1987-2010, hosted by Cheche Lazaro with her team of young broadcast journalists like Maria Ressa, Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Tony Velasquez, Judy Torres, and Angie Ramos. The weekly public affairs magazine program, which initially aired on ABS-CBN before it moved to different networks and is regarded as the first investigative broadcast journalism program in the country, critically examined the deeper aspects of socially important topics. Following the same format were programs from ABS-CBN, such as Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), 1988-2005, The Inside Story, 1990-98, and The Correspondents, 1998-2010; from GMA Network, such as i-Witness, which premiered in 1999, and Reporter’s Notebook, beginning in 2004; and from GMA News TV, Investigative Documentaries, which premiered in 2011.

article.value: Some aspects of the cinema verité tradition in filmmaking, which has less overt involvement of reporters and more cinematic approaches to camerawork and editing, have recently been adopted by broadcast documentaries, such as Reel Time and Front Row, which both premiered in 2011 on GMA News TV.

A few investigative reports employ stylized reenactments of events, like Imbestigador (Investigator), which premiered in 2000 on GMA Network, and Storyline, which premiered in 2008 on ANC and DZMM TeleRadyo.

The documentary is sometimes used as an introductory segment of any type of program, usually a talk show. In these documentaries, a narrator reads and records the script, but the reader is neither knowledgeable about the topic nor is involved in the writing of the script. Some have the voice of the program’s anchor, in which case the reader is familiar with the topic.

article.value: There are also single-airing documentaries, which are often political, such as those produced by Asia Visions during the martial period, which include The Arrogance of Power, about the rising protest against Marcos; Lakbayan: Lakad ng Bayan para sa Kalayaan (March of the People: Long March for Freedom), about the nationwide march of farmers and workers; and Beyond Prison, about political prisoners (Tiongson 1984). These were not aired in commercial broadcast stations but in alternative places to escape from the claws of the dictatorship. Documentaries of this type began to be aired on commercial networks during the post-martial law period, the most excellent examples of which were Ceasefire, 1986, IBC 13, which looked into the possibility of a ceasefire between the military and the underground National Democratic Front–New People’s Army; Ramut: The Roots of Revolution in the Cordillera, 1986, IBC 13, which traced the history of the struggle of the peoples of the Cordillera; Tiempo Muerto: Crisis and Poverty in Negros (Downtime: Crisis and Poverty in Negros), 1986, IBC 13, which looked into the situation of the sugar workers in central Philippines and the struggle for emancipation from hunger and feudal values (Tolentino 1987); and Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan (Dear Sam … Yours, Juan), 1989, which highlighted the protest movement and the art forms that critiqued the presence of US military bases in the country. text:
The broadcast drama is a narrative play that refers to a fictional or true-to-life story that is often melodramatic. It is infused with or incorporated into other genres, such as the comedy, horror, action, fantasy, detective, and historical narrative.

The drama in Philippine broadcast has many types: the serialized daily soap opera, the weekly anthology, the single-airing narrative, and the telenovela or teleserye. The drama in Philippine broadcast airs in both the afternoon and evening time slots.

 

 

The radio drama during the American colonial period, especially in the mid-1930s until the outbreak of World War II, consisted mainly of readings of American and English literature (poetry, prose, drama). Lux Toilet Soap Theatre of the Air featured dramatizations of excerpts from movies sponsored by a brand of bath soap. KZRM’s Newsreel of the Air presented the news in drama form, with Francisco Trinidad and Lamberto Avellana dramatizing the news by impersonating the voices of important political personalities from around the world. In 1938, an early model of the Tagalog soap-opera-cum advice program, Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok (The Thrifty Madam Juana), hosted by Lina Flor, debuted.

 

The genre called soap opera flourished after World War II. They were called soaps because the first such productions in the United States were sponsored by soap products. DZRH produced the first postwar soaps in 1949: Ilaw ng Tahanan (The Light of the Home), written by Liwayway Arceo, and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fortune) by Lina Flor. Both aired daily for 15 minutes and were about the highs and the lows in the lives of ordinary Filipino families and their friends. DZRH dominated the production of famous radio drama serials in the 1950s, such as Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), a komedya-type story written by Clodualdo del Mundo; Ginang Hukom (Mrs Judge), a legal drama by Lina Flor; and Gabi ng Lagim (A Night of Horror), a horror drama. Genoveva Edroza-Matute’s Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), also on DZRH, can be considered the first radio novel, a limited run of unique stories that lasted only months instead of the usual years of a typical melodrama. Other memorable soaps of the period include DZPI’s child-oriented Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), based on Severino Reyes’s serial on Liwayway magazine, and Clodualdo del Mundo’s Recuerdo (Memento) and Mercedes Cruz; DZBB’s Tony Narra, which was the first detective type of narrative on Philippine radio, Gloria Villaraza-Guzman’s love stories Mga Lihim ng Puso (Secrets of the Heart), and Camay Theater of the Air, a Sunday-night, 60-minute reenactment of an upcoming Filipino movie, with the film actors coming to the studio and reenacting the movie dialogue live; DZBC’s Panata ng Puso (Heart’s Promise) and Digmaan ng Damdamin (Battle of Emotions), both written and directed by Artemio Marquez, and the horror drama Sepulturero sa Lumang Libingan (Undertaker in the Old Cemetery); and Fundador Soriano’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) and Flordeluna (Aniceto 1997; Enriquez 2003). The latter first aired on Cebu radio and was later translated to Tagalog and produced for Manila television audiences in the late 1970s (Enriquez 2003).

 

 

Dramas in English were on the air until the 1950s, produced by college dramatic guilds such as Cathedral Players on DZRH, managed by Ateneo de Manila’s James Reuter; Bedan Barristers on DZPI, made up of thespians of San Beda College led by Noe Nebrida; and Republic Players on DZBB, composed of several stage actors, directors, scriptwriters, and producers transitioning to radio, television, and, later, film (Aniceto 1997).

 

The daily soap remained as the most popular format during the post-World War II period until the early years of the post-EDSA Revolt. The soaps were either serials with no end in sight or short stories aired as the episode for the day. In the 1970s until the 1980s, from DWWW came Maja Vida (Pleasant Life) and Kapantay ay Langit (As High as Heaven); from DZRH were Kasaysayan ni Aida Nuñez (The Story of Aida Nuñez), True Confessions, Pinagpala (Blessed), Love Story, and Bukang-Liwayway sa Takipsilim (Dawn at Dusk). DZXL had Di Ko Malilimot (I Will Never Forget), Alaala ng Isang Awit (Memory of a Song), Hibik ng Puso (Lamentations of the Heart), and Lumipas na Madaling Araw (Forgotten Morn) (Nofuente 1986). A hit melodrama that came out in 1973 and is still airing on DZRH is the daily soap Ito ang Palad Ko (This Is My Fate). The soaps of Radio Mindanao Network continued their popularity during the post-martial law period in Visayan-speaking audiences in the Visayas and Mindanao. Examples are Kun Ako ang Pasultihon (If I Were to Speak), an advice comedy drama; Kini ang Akong Suliran (This Is My Problem), which dramatizes legal and medical issues sent by listeners; and Handumanan sa Usa ka Awit (Memories of a Song), stories of love based on songs sent in by listeners (Mindanao Examiner 2012).

 

 

On television, the soap first appeared on ABS-CBN through the horror drama Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato (Mystery at the House of Stone), 1963-64. Others followed suit, such as Flordeluna, first on radio, then on television, 1979-84, RPN 9; Anna Liza, 1980-85, GMA; Valiente, 1992-97, ABS-CBN, then GMA; Villa Quintana, 1995-96, GMA; Mara Clara, 1992-97, ABS-CBN; Esperanza, 1997-99, ABS-CBN; Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 1997-99, ABS-CBN; and Kung Mawawala Ka (A World Without You), 2002-3, GMA. There seems to be no end in the stories in these soaps. They usually end when the program’s popularity begins to wane.

 

Most melodrama anthologies on television are family-oriented or are about romantic love, are mainly focused on women, and feature women actors as the lead. Examples include Santa Zita and Mary Rose, 1960s, ABC 5; Salamisim (Reflections), 1966-68, ABC 5; Panagimpan (Dream), 1968-72, ABS-CBN; Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), 1979, BBC 2; Rosas (Rose), 1979, Babae (Woman), 1979-80, and Lino Brocka Presents, 1977-80, all on GTV 4; and Alindog (Allure), 1978-79, Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), 1978-80, and Katha (Fiction), 1978, all on GMA. Some anthologies of this type carry the lead actor’s name in the program’s title. Examples are Tina Revilla’s Christina and Vilma Santos’s Dulambuhay ni Rosa Vilma (Life Story of Rosa Vilma), both in the 1970s and on BBC 2; Nora Aunor’s Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), 1970s-80s, RPN 9; Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, 1977-81 on GMA 7, then 1984-89 on RPN 9; and Maricel: Regal Drama Special, 1987-90, and Maricel Drama Special, 1990-97, both on ABS-CBN.

 

Some drama anthologies serve as counseling programs that feature real-life narratives of listeners or viewers who send in their stories, such as Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely (This Is Your Aunt Dely), 1953, DZRH, considered the pioneer in this format of the drama, hosted by Fidela Magpayo aka Tiya Dely; Fundador Soriano’s Kahapon Lamang, 1950s, which Eddie Ilarde would bring to television, on GMA, from 1976 to 1986; Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1980-96, GMA, hosted by Helen Vela; Ulila (Orphan), 1978-79, BBC 2, by Rosa Rosal; and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1991-present, ABS-CBN, hosted by Charo Santos-Concio.

 

 

There are also dramas that are realist in approach. Prominent among these is Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1968-71, ABC-RTV5, which adapted award-winning Filipino novels, short stories, and stage plays for television. Others in this tradition are Anino (Shadow), 1974, Huwaran (Model), 1974-80, Lino Brocka Presents, 1977-80, Tipanan (Rendezvous), 1979, and Neneng Magtanggol, 1979, all on GTV 4; Alindog (Allure), 1978-79, Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), 1978-80, and Katha (Fiction), 1978, all on GMA; Tanghalan (Stage), 1974 on GMA, then 1975 on GTV 4; and Anak (Child), 1979, and Hiyas (Gem), 1986, on IBC 13.

 

Drama anthologies that feature adaptations of short stories, novels, or stage plays are Dahong Ginto (Golden Leaf), 1973, IBC 13; The Palanca Memorial Awards Theater, 1978, RPN 9; and Fr James Reuter’s Family Theater, early 1960s, Obra Maestra, late 1960s, and Pahina (Pages), 2000-01, all on ABS-CBN. On radio, foreign fairy tales are adapted as oral reading pieces in the daily 15-minute program Mga Kuwento ng Dutch Milk (The Stories of Dutch Milk), 1959, DZWS (Manila Times 1959).

 

Political dramas became prevalent during the early days of the Corazon Aquino administration up to the end of the Estrada presidency. Examples coming from civil society groups were the weekly anthologies on radio, such as Pintig ng Konsyumer (Pulse of the Consumer), DWXI, about consumers’ issues produced by the Citizens’ Alliance for Consumer Protection; Punlaan sa Himpapawid (Seedling Plots on Air), 1987 to mid-1990s, on DWBC, then on DWAN, produced by the Philippine Peasant Institute, about peasant issues and agrarian reform; Radyo Lundayan (Lundayan Radio), DZEC, 1991-95, produced by the Tambuyog Development Center, about the political ecology of fisherfolk concerns; and Pitlag!: Kuwento ng Buhay, Isyu ng Bayan (Jolt!: Narratives of Life, Issues of Community and Nation), 2000-2006, first on Radio Veritas then on RMN, produced by Pathway Productions, about corruption issues that hounded the presidency of Estrada and other national issues like the social cost of the war in Mindanao, the struggles of indigenous peoples, the death penalty, and child labor. Pitlag! was the first radio drama program in the Philippines that won an award from the New York Festivals. On television, the Task Force Detainees of the Philippines produced Melinda, 1995, GMA, a single-airing drama about the rape of young student activists by the military; and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) created Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA), 1990-92, and PETA-bisyon (PETA Vision), 1993, PTV 4, then RPN 9 and ABC 5, which examined relevant sociopolitical issues.

 

The telenovela has become the most popular form of the drama beginning in the 2000s. The word comes from the Spanish words televisión, or the Portuguese televisao, and the Spanish and Portuguese word novela. In the Philippines, it is also called teleserye. A long story or a novel is watched in episodes, each lasting 30 minutes to one hour. The most popular telenovelas come from Latin American countries, such as Brazil, Mexico, Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, and Colombia. Telenovelas may be in the form of drama, fantasy, and action. Drama, however, is the usual fare. Melodrama, to be specific, is the usual format, wherein a happy ending caps the whole series of struggle and suffering of the main character or characters. A lead character, for example, or a star-crossed young couple, ends up in a happy wedding. The kontrabida (antagonist), who causes all the woes of the bida (protagonist), is jailed or dies.

 

In the 1970s, Mexico pioneered in airing highly popular telenovelas. Mexican telenovela produced a phenomenon in the Philippines with its show Marimar, 1996, RPN 9, starring Thalia. Marimar was so popular at the time that the world seemed to come to a temporary stop whenever it was shown on Philippine television. Marimar has left its mark. Its most obvious influence on Philippine teleserye is in the use of crosscutting, where scenes simultaneously happen. It also changed the programming landscape of Philippine television.

 

The early daily soaps in the Philippines can be considered telenovelas. Unlike current telenovelas, however, these drama serials spanned as long as they were rating and as long as there were sponsors. The current format of the telenovela, on the other hand, is a limited-run drama serial. The first telenovela in the Philippines with a limited-run format is Malayo Pa ang Umaga (The Morn Is Yet So Far), 1979, RPN 9, based on the novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947, by Stevan Javellana and produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna.

 

ABS-CBN contemporary blockbuster teleseryes include Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000; Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001-03; Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You), 2003-04; Sa Piling Mo (With You), 2006; Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 2006-07; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009; May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10; Magkaribal (Rivals), 2010; Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Her Mother’s Daughter), 2012-13; and The Legal Wife, 2014.

 

Very few are in the vein of comedy such as Betty la Fea (Ugly Betty), 2007, GMA, or action/adventure like Asian Treasures, 2007, ABS-CBN, starring Angel Locsin and Robin Padilla. Most are drama or melodrama. Most revolve around the family, dealing with the personal and with strong emotions. Conflicts usually arise from love triangle, poor vs rich, child oppression, siblings separated at birth, and the probinsiyano (from the province) vs the city-bred.

 

Recently, unusual or taboo themes were successfully tackled in GMA Network’s My Husband’s Lover, 2013, which is about a married man in love with a male lover, and The Rich Man’s Daughter, 2015, about a lesbian who is matched by her parents to a man but continues to love another woman. The political drama Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2011, TV5, starring Nora Aunor, reflects the dirty politics in the country.

 

The multi-awarded actor Coco Martin, dubbed the “prince of telenovelas,” starred in famous teleseryes on ABS-CBN, such as Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 2011; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012, a remake of Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s movie Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven); Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014; and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), starting in 2015.

 

Telenovelas have also given rise to a “new image” of the modern woman. The female kontrabida appears to be a more rounded character, more alive, more intelligent and witty, and more interesting than the trite and boring goody-goody bida. For this reason, young female viewers tend to identify themselves with the kontrabida. Most telenovelas, of course, have the stamp of escapism.Written by Marra PL. Lanot and Eulalio R. Guieb III w ith notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

 

Sources

Aniceto 1997; Enriquez 2003; Manila Times 1959; Mindanano Examiner 2012; Nofuente 1979, 1986.

Prominent among these is Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1968-71, ABC-RTV5, which adapted award-winning Filipino novels, short stories, and stage plays for television. Others in this tradition are Anino (Shadow), 1974, Huwaran (Model), 1974-80, Lino Brocka Presents, 1977-80, Tipanan (Rendezvous), 1979, and Neneng Magtanggol, 1979, all on GTV 4; Alindog (Allure), 1978-79, Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), 1978-80, and Katha (Fiction), 1978, all on GMA; Tanghalan (Stage), 1974 on GMA, then 1975 on GTV 4; and Anak (Child), 1979, and Hiyas (Gem), 1986, on IBC 13.

Drama anthologies that feature adaptations of short stories, novels, or stage plays are Dahong Ginto (Golden Leaf), 1973, IBC 13; The Palanca Memorial Awards Theater, 1978, RPN 9; and Fr James Reuter’s Family Theater, early 1960s, Obra Maestra, late 1960s, and Pahina (Pages), 2000-01, all on ABS-CBN. On radio, foreign fairy tales are adapted as oral reading pieces in the daily 15-minute program Mga Kuwento ng Dutch Milk (The Stories of Dutch Milk), 1959, DZWS (Manila Times 1959).

Political dramas became prevalent during the early days of the Corazon Aquino administration up to the end of the Estrada presidency. Examples coming from civil society groups were the weekly anthologies on radio, such as Pintig ng Konsyumer (Pulse of the Consumer), DWXI, about consumers’ issues produced by the Citizens’ Alliance for Consumer Protection; Punlaan sa Himpapawid (Seedling Plots on Air), 1987 to mid-1990s, on DWBC, then on DWAN, produced by the Philippine Peasant Institute, about peasant issues and agrarian reform; Radyo Lundayan (Lundayan Radio), DZEC, 1991-95, produced by the Tambuyog Development Center, about the political ecology of fisherfolk concerns; and Pitlag!: Kuwento ng Buhay, Isyu ng Bayan (Jolt!: Narratives of Life, Issues of Community and Nation), 2000-2006, first on Radio Veritas then on RMN, produced by Pathway Productions, about corruption issues that hounded the presidency of Estrada and other national issues like the social cost of the war in Mindanao, the struggles of indigenous peoples, the death penalty, and child labor. Pitlag! was the first radio drama program in the Philippines that won an award from the New York Festivals. On television, the Task Force Detainees of the Philippines produced Melinda, 1995, GMA, a single-airing drama about the rape of young student activists by the military; and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) created Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA), 1990-92, and PETA-bisyon (PETA Vision), 1993, PTV 4, then RPN 9 and ABC 5, which examined relevant sociopolitical issues.

The telenovela has become the most popular form of the drama beginning in the 2000s. The word comes from the Spanish words televisión, or the Portuguese televisao, and the Spanish and Portuguese word novela. In the Philippines, it is also called teleserye. A long story or a novel is watched in episodes, each lasting 30 minutes to one hour. The most popular telenovelas come from Latin American countries, such as Brazil, Mexico, Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, and Colombia. Telenovelas may be in the form of drama, fantasy, and action. Drama, however, is the usual fare. Melodrama, to be specific, is the usual format, wherein a happy ending caps the whole series of struggle and suffering of the main character or characters. A lead character, for example, or a star-crossed young couple, ends up in a happy wedding. The kontrabida (antagonist), who causes all the woes of the bida (protagonist), is jailed or dies.

In the 1970s, Mexico pioneered in airing highly popular telenovelas. Mexican telenovela produced a phenomenon in the Philippines with its show Marimar, 1996, RPN 9, starring Thalia. Marimar was so popular at the time that the world seemed to come to a temporary stop whenever it was shown on Philippine television. Marimar has left its mark. Its most obvious influence on Philippine teleserye is in the use of crosscutting, where scenes simultaneously happen. It also changed the programming landscape of Philippine television.

The early daily soaps in the Philippines can be considered telenovelas. Unlike current telenovelas, however, these drama serials spanned as long as they were rating and as long as there were sponsors. The current format of the telenovela, on the other hand, is a limited-run drama serial. The first telenovela in the Philippines with a limited-run format is Malayo Pa ang Umaga (The Morn Is Yet So Far), 1979, RPN 9, based on the novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947, by Stevan Javellana and produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna.

ABS-CBN contemporary blockbuster teleseryes include Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000; Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001-03; Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You), 2003-04; Sa Piling Mo (With You), 2006; Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 2006-07; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009; May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10; Magkaribal (Rivals), 2010; Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Her Mother’s Daughter), 2012-13; and The Legal Wife, 2014.

Very few are in the vein of comedy such as Betty la Fea (Ugly Betty), 2007, GMA, or action/adventure like Asian Treasures, 2007, ABS-CBN, starring Angel Locsin and Robin Padilla. Most are drama or melodrama. Most revolve around the family, dealing with the personal and with strong emotions. Conflicts usually arise from love triangle, poor vs rich, child oppression, siblings separated at birth, and the probinsiyano (from the province) vs the city-bred.

Recently, unusual or taboo themes were successfully tackled in GMA Network’s My Husband’s Lover, 2013, which is about a married man in love with a male lover, and The Rich Man’s Daughter, 2015, about a lesbian who is matched by her parents to a man but continues to love another woman. The political drama Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2011, TV5, starring Nora Aunor, reflects the dirty politics in the country.

The multi-awarded actor Coco Martin, dubbed the “prince of telenovelas,” starred in famous teleseryes on ABS-CBN, such as Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 2011; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012, a remake of Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s movie Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven); Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014; and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), starting in 2015.

Telenovelas have also given rise to a “new image” of the modern woman. The female kontrabida appears to be a more rounded character, more alive, more intelligent and witty, and more interesting than the trite and boring goody-goody bida. For this reason, young female viewers tend to identify themselves with the kontrabida. Most telenovelas, of course, have the stamp of escapism.Written by Marra PL. Lanot and Eulalio R. text:
Educational/instructional programs are mainly curriculum-based and have a defined goal or objective and a set of procedures to achieve these goals. It can be a lesson like learning a language, a how-to of a craft, a description of an object, or a discussion that aims at bringing about identified cognitive, affective, or behavioral changes of a target audience.

Government support for educational-instructional programs during the American colonial period came through Act 3997 in 1932, which created the National Radio Broadcasting Fund. KZRH’s broadcast from 1939 to 1941 carried educational-instructional programs, foremost of which was to teach the proper diction and pronunciation of American English. During World War II, the Japanese-controlled KZRH aired deportment lectures aimed at women and children, and lessons on the Nihongo language given by Japanese broadcasters and on the Tagalog language given by Lope K. Santos, who later would be recognized as the “Father of Tagalog Grammar.”

 

 

 

In the 1960s, DZFM of the government-owned Philippine Broadcasting System had educational broadcast for its main programming, with shows like Nacida Program, SEATO Calling, UNESCO Features, and PBS Final (Tagumpay Magazine 1963). It aired programs for farmers, usually at 5:00 am, which discussed ways of increasing agricultural productivity. Beginning in 1964, DZLB, the radio station of the University of the Philippines Los Baños (UPLB), aired programs targeting rural communities surrounding the campus. In 1968, the Ateneo Center for Educational TV, under the directorship of Fr Leo H. Larkin, SJ, began transmitting televised lessons to schools through two modes: the closed circuit transmission to two experimental schools and the open transmission via a microwave link to IBC 13 to elementary and secondary schools in Manila and nearby provinces (Herald Midweek Magazine 1968).

 

During the martial law period, educational programs were produced to push the concept of development communication, with a focus on messages about agriculture, health, family planning, discipline, good citizenship, and family morals. On radio, an example was the hour-long program Lingap ng Pangulo sa Barangay (The President’s Care of the Barangay), a nonformal educational series that all television and radio stations were required by the government to broadcast. School-on-the-air programs that targeted rural audiences became one of the trends, a forerunner of which is DZLB of UPLB. Examples on TV include the agriculture program Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out), and the entrepreneur show Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), both aired on KBS-RPN 9. Similar programs that appeared after martial law were Negosiyete (Business on Seven) and Agrisiete (Agriculture on Seven), both on GMA 7, and Agrilink (Agricultural Link), ABC 5.

 

Development communication shifted to distance education using broadcast in the aftermath of the EDSA Revolt. New information and communication technologies provided greater opportunities in delivering alternative learning delivery schemes. Digital classrooms started to become sites of the active interaction of teachers and students mediated by multimedia technology.

 

 

 

 

The educational-instructional approach is often used by other types of broadcast programs. Many children’s programs are mainly educational. The most successful and highly popular is Batibot (Small but Strong), 1984-2014, created by the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation, which discussed literacy, numeracy, interpersonal communication, good manners, and the Filipino language, culture and heritage, employing modular lessons, music videos, animation, and puppetry. Pin-Pin, 1990-94, propagated Chinese-Filipino culture in the Philippines, especially lessons on Hokkien (Fukienese) among Filipinos in the Philippines with Chinese roots. PTV 4 aired in the 1990s three TV courses for teachers of elementary science, chemistry, and physics under the Continuing Education Program for Science via Television, a project of the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports, the UP Institute of Science and Math Education, and the Philippine Normal University.

 

Quiz shows have an educational orientation. Examples in the 1960s include Radio Schoolhouse on DZPI, Knowledge Unlimited on DZRH, and Professor Quiz on DZMB. Student Canteen, especially its broadcast from the 1970s until the late 1980s, had the quiz competition segment “IQ 7.” In the 1990s and on through the 2000s, the most popular were Battle of the Brains, RPN 9 and then PTV 4, and Digital LG Quiz, GMA 7.

 

ABS-CBN Foundation produced many educational-instructional programs for children and teens—namely, Sineskwela (School on Air), 1994-2001, a daily, curriculum-based science program; Bayani (Hero), 1995-2000, a weekly history program, which disseminates a nationalist consciousness through the stories of Philippine national heroes and characters from precolonial Philippines; Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 1995-2003, a fairy-tale series of journeys to magical places with a focus on values formation; Math-tinik (Math Genius), 1997-2003, about elementary mathematics; and Epol/Apple, 1999-2003, teaching basic literacy on the English and Filipino languages. For radio, ABS-CBN Foundation produced the science and technology weekly discussion program Bago ’Yan, Ah! (That’s New), 1997-2013, DZMM.

 

Three innovative educational-instructional programs on radio, which began airing in 2011, come from DZUP 1602. The Psych O’Clock Habit of the UP Psychology Department, explores curriculum-based lessons on behavior, learning, insights, emotions, and other related issues. Go, Teacher, Go!, produced by the UP National Institute for Science and Mathematics Education Development, provides elementary and secondary school teachers with innovative teaching strategies and learning activities to aid them in their classroom teaching. Radyo Edukado (Educated Radio) is a radio-based literacy program that covers the course content of the National Training Service Program of the UP College of Education. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III w ith notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

 

Sources

Herald Midweek Magazine 1968; Tagumpay 1963.

text:
Faith-based programs are shows that uphold a particular system of religious belief. They are produced by an organization or an individual that adhere to a particular religion. They air on the organization’s own network or are programmed by commercial stations as blocktimers. Early and contemporary programs of this type operated not for profit but for evangelization. These shows would later on take a more public service orientation. Recent faith-based programs, however, have creatively combined commerce and religion into their formats. In the Philippines, faith-based programs fall under several types and formats, such as evangelism, the devotionals, talk-public affairs, counseling, public service, news, music, variety, children’s show, and drama. Groups produce and air these programs in stations they own, or buy airtime as blocktimers in commercial or in government-run broadcast networks. In many cases, nonreligious stations themselves produce these shows, and many of these shows are now on electronic media.

 

The earliest radio station that propagated the owners’ brand of faith was DZAS, 1948, on KZAS 680 kHz, later 702 DZAS, under the then newly established Protestant Far Eastern Broadcasting Company. The Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) established the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation in 1968 and began its broadcasts on DZEC. The Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines tapped radio for evangelization beginning only in 1969 when it began operations of DWRV Radio Veritas. The government of Ferdinand Marcos during martial law did not seem to be too strict on these stations. Maintaining good relations with established religious groups made it easier for Marcos to run the nation under an authoritarian regime. Immediately following the ouster of Marcos through the EDSA Revolt in 1986, ownership of the new free TV network, VHF station Channel 11, was contested by two religious charismatic groups: the Jesus Is Lord Movement (JIL) of Brother Eddie Villanueva and the El Shaddai of Brother Mike Velarde. Through the years, religious programs paved the way for either the propagation of new faith or the strengthening of their respective religions.

 

 

 

Faith-based programs on television during martial law were imported canned shows programmed during Sundays, and later in the daily evening time slot. Examples were The 700 Club and The Rev. Ernest Angley Hour, both on GMA 7; Rex Humbard World Outreach Ministry, Jimmy Swaggart, and The Baptist Hour, on IBC 13; and Gospel Crusade on GTV 4, which also aired the local program The Sunday Mass.

 

The 1980s saw the more pronounced incursion of religious groups into both radio and television to reach a wider audience. Among them are The Lord’s Flock of Fr Sonny Ramirez, the JIL of Villanueva, the El Shaddai of Velarde, the 700 Club of Pat Robertson, and the Iglesia ni Cristo. Their programs on television combine preaching, testimonies of religious experiences, inspirational music, masses, the recitation of the rosary for Catholics, and healing sessions. There are religious programs on the Eternal World Television Network, such as the popular talk show of Mother Angelica (Panopio and Santico-Rolda 2007).

 

Evangelization shows that persuade non-adherents to convert run on religious stations operated by the groups themselves. These are Inspirations Unlimited and Day by Day, DZAS; Ang Tamang Daan (The Right Path), which analyzes scriptural passages while junking the doctrines of other religions; Ang Pagbubunyag (The Revelation), a Bible study program, Ang Aking Karanasan (My Experience), about dramatized stories of former members of other religions who have recently converted to INC, and Ang Iglesia ni Cristo (The Church of Christ), all on INC-TV and Net 25; Ang Dating Daan: Bible Exposition (The Old Way: Bible Exposition) and Itanong Mo kay Soriano (Ask Soriano), on UNTV and La Verdad 1350 KHz; and Oras ng Himala (Miracle Hour) on government-run stations PTV 4 and IBC 13.

 

 

 

Catholic evangelization programs that air on Catholic broadcast stations include the Bible study shows Gabay sa Bibliya (Bible Guide), Mabuting Balita (The Good News), Alay kay Inang Maria (An Offering to Mother Mary), and Kristo: Liwanag sa Dilim (Christ: Light in Darkness), all on DZRV. TV Maria airs The Word Exposed, Preachers in Jeans, and Kerygma TV. Some Catholic evangelism shows are on commercial stations, such as Salitang Buhay (Living Word) and Usapang Kapatid (Fraternal Talk), both on DZMM.

 

Some faith-based programs are devotionals, either as a program in itself or as fillers during breaks. TV Maria broadcasts The Family Rosary Crusade, The Angelus, and novena prayer segments. Commercial radio and TV stations air The Three O’Clock Habit. The annual Lenten program Siete Palabras (Seven Last Words), on air since 1983 and first aired on BBC 2, anchored by Father Ramirez, reflect on Christ’s death on the cross. ABS-CBN, ABS-CBN Sports+Action Channel 23, PTV 4, and IBC 13 air Sunday Eucharistic celebrations. Commercial stations broadcast these as well, especially masses held in Quiapo, Baclaran, and the EDSA Shrine.

 

Many faith-based programs follow the format of talk-public affairs that discuss relevant day-to-day issues infused with religious themes and aired on commercial broadcast stations. Diyos at Bayan (God and Country), 1998-2005, by Villanueva, on RPN 9, PTV 4, and then on GMA News TV (GNTV), covers sociopolitical issues in its discussion. The 700 Club Asia, also on GNTV, tackles current events with guests.

 

Some talk programs are more political than religious. The Sulu Council of the Muslim Women Peace Advocates in Jolo launched the weekly program Women Talk Peace in a local radio station in 2004 to discuss peace and human rights from the perspective of Muslim women and Islamic faith (PCID 2012). Salam Radyo (Radio Salaam), DZUP, on air since 2010, produced by the University of the Philippines Institute of Islamic Studies, hosted by Julkipli Wadi, highlights Moro issues and aspirations.

 

Many faith-based shows offer family, legal, health, and livelihood counseling to their audiences. Family and relationship counseling programs include Family and Marriage and Pamilya Mo, Pamilya Ko (Your Family Is My Family, Too) on DZRV, Family Matters on DZAS, and Dr. Love with Bro. Jun Banaag on DZMM. Legal counseling programs include Magkabiyak sa Batas (Partners in Law), DZRV; Gabay, Batas at Serbisyo (Guidance, Law and Service), DZEC-TV Channel 49; and Law Center ni Kuya (Big Brother’s Law Center) on UNTV Channel 37. Health counseling programs include Kapanalig sa Kalusugan (Brothers in Health) and Kalusugan at Kabuhayan (Health and Livelihood) on DZRV, Doctors On Line on DZAS, Health Matters on INC-TV, and Clinic ni Kuya (Big Brother’s Clinic) on UNTV. Livelihood counseling programs include Kalusugan at Kabuhayan (Health and Livelihood) and Agri Troubleshooting at Kalusugan (Agriculture Troubleshooting and Health), both on DZRV; EntrePinoy (Filipino Entrepreneur) on DZAS; Agree sa Agri (Agree on Agriculture) on INC-TV; and Job Fair ni Kuya (Big Brother’s Job Fair) on UNTV.

 

Religious public service programs offer concrete actions to address the needs of their audiences. Some of these shows are Buhay Marino (Mariners’ Lives), where grievances of seafarers are resolved; Pulis ng Pilipino (Filipino Policemen), where listeners can report civil and criminal problems; and Caritas sa Veritas (Charity in Truth), which encourages Filipino Catholics to support the charitable institution Caritas Manila.

 

An example of a program that is news in format is Church News, about the actions and the administrative functions of the hierarchy of INC. Children’s programs with segments in animation that discuss the Bible are Kawan ng Cordero (Flock of Sheep), UNTV, and Mustard TV, TV Maria.

 

Religious programs that are music and variety entertainment include Sing for Joy, DZFE; A Song of Praise: Music Festival, a talent competition inviting amateur and professional songwriters to compose songs in God’s honor, UNTV; and Religious Music on Catholic Media Network’s (CMN) DXVP-AM “Virgen del Pilar” Radyo Verdadero in Zamboanga. DZFE 98.7 encourages meditation of the Scriptures with classical music. An interesting gospel music program for the youth was Mag-Smile Club Na (Join the Smile Club), 1996, IBC 13, starring PY Nakar.

 

The drama is also used by this type of programs. The 700 Club offers short documentaries and drama reenactments to visualize the situation it presents. Programs that are nonreligious but take on the religious stance are the noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Peek-a-Boo!), which regularly produces dramatized stories for its Lenten offerings. Mario O’Hara’s Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Himala? (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), 1979, BBC 2, is a television adaptation of the Spanish novel Marcelino, Pan y Vino, 1952, by José María Sánchez-Silva, about innocent faith. ABS-CBN’s hit telenovela May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10, talks of everyday miracles at a time when some Catholic priests were under fire for alleged involvement in child sex abuse cases.

Faith-based programs have also been the subject of inquiry by the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB). Episodes in 1992 of the weekly TV program Iglesia ni Cristo (Church of Christ), produced by the INC, received an X rating from the MTRCB because of the program’s criticisms of the veneration by Roman Catholics of the Virgin Mary. Eli Soriano’s Ang Dating Daan (The Old Way) went off the air in 2004 when MTRCB suspended it for three months following complaints by INC ministers, who were the target of invectives by Soriano on national television.

 

Broadcasters Kata Inocencio, Alex Tinsay, Carlo Lorenzo, and former Myx VJ Kristine Camille Antonio provide a fresh look on faith-based programs thatdeviate from the dry and didactic tone of most religious programs. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo and Eulalio R. Guieb III w ith notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Marinela M. Aseron

article.value: Faith-based programs are shows that uphold a particular system of religious belief. They are produced by an organization or an individual that adhere to a particular religion. They air on the organization’s own network or are programmed by commercial stations as blocktimers. Early and contemporary programs of this type operated not for profit but for evangelization. These shows would later on take a more public service orientation. Recent faith-based programs, however, have creatively combined commerce and religion into their formats. In the Philippines, faith-based programs fall under several types and formats, such as evangelism, the devotionals, talk-public affairs, counseling, public service, news, music, variety, children’s show, and drama. Groups produce and air these programs in stations they own, or buy airtime as blocktimers in commercial or in government-run broadcast networks. In many cases, nonreligious stations themselves produce these shows, and many of these shows are now on electronic media.

The earliest radio station that propagated the owners’ brand of faith was DZAS, 1948, on KZAS 680 kHz, later 702 DZAS, under the then newly established Protestant Far Eastern Broadcasting Company. The Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) established the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation in 1968 and began its broadcasts on DZEC. The Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines tapped radio for evangelization beginning only in 1969 when it began operations of DWRV Radio Veritas. The government of Ferdinand Marcos during martial law did not seem to be too strict on these stations. Maintaining good relations with established religious groups made it easier for Marcos to run the nation under an authoritarian regime. Immediately following the ouster of Marcos through the EDSA Revolt in 1986, ownership of the new free TV network, VHF station Channel 11, was contested by two religious charismatic groups: the Jesus Is Lord Movement (JIL) of Brother Eddie Villanueva and the El Shaddai of Brother Mike Velarde. Through the years, religious programs paved the way for either the propagation of new faith or the strengthening of their respective religions.

article.value: Faith-based programs on television during martial law were imported canned shows programmed during Sundays, and later in the daily evening time slot. Examples were The 700 Club and The Rev. Ernest Angley Hour, both on GMA 7; Rex Humbard World Outreach Ministry, Jimmy Swaggart, and The Baptist Hour, on IBC 13; and Gospel Crusade on GTV 4, which also aired the local program The Sunday Mass.

The 1980s saw the more pronounced incursion of religious groups into both radio and television to reach a wider audience. Among them are The Lord’s Flock of Fr Sonny Ramirez, the JIL of Villanueva, the El Shaddai of Velarde, the 700 Club of Pat Robertson, and the Iglesia ni Cristo. Their programs on television combine preaching, testimonies of religious experiences, inspirational music, masses, the recitation of the rosary for Catholics, and healing sessions. There are religious programs on the Eternal World Television Network, such as the popular talk show of Mother Angelica (Panopio and Santico-Rolda 2007).

Evangelization shows that persuade non-adherents to convert run on religious stations operated by the groups themselves. These are Inspirations Unlimited and Day by Day, DZAS; Ang Tamang Daan (The Right Path), which analyzes scriptural passages while junking the doctrines of other religions; Ang Pagbubunyag (The Revelation), a Bible study program, Ang Aking Karanasan (My Experience), about dramatized stories of former members of other religions who have recently converted to INC, and Ang Iglesia ni Cristo (The Church of Christ), all on INC-TV and Net 25; Ang Dating Daan: Bible Exposition (The Old Way: Bible Exposition) and Itanong Mo kay Soriano (Ask Soriano), on UNTV and La Verdad 1350 KHz; and Oras ng Himala (Miracle Hour) on government-run stations PTV 4 and IBC 13.

article.value: Catholic evangelization programs that air on Catholic broadcast stations include the Bible study shows Gabay sa Bibliya (Bible Guide), Mabuting Balita (The Good News), Alay kay Inang Maria (An Offering to Mother Mary), and Kristo: Liwanag sa Dilim (Christ: Light in Darkness), all on DZRV. TV Maria airs The Word Exposed, Preachers in Jeans, and Kerygma TV. Some Catholic evangelism shows are on commercial stations, such as Salitang Buhay (Living Word) and Usapang Kapatid (Fraternal Talk), both on DZMM.

Some faith-based programs are devotionals, either as a program in itself or as fillers during breaks. TV Maria broadcasts The Family Rosary Crusade, The Angelus, and novena prayer segments. Commercial radio and TV stations air The Three O’Clock Habit. The annual Lenten program Siete Palabras (Seven Last Words), on air since 1983 and first aired on BBC 2, anchored by Father Ramirez, reflect on Christ’s death on the cross. ABS-CBN, ABS-CBN Sports+Action Channel 23, PTV 4, and IBC 13 air Sunday Eucharistic celebrations. Commercial stations broadcast these as well, especially masses held in Quiapo, Baclaran, and the EDSA Shrine.

Many faith-based programs follow the format of talk-public affairs that discuss relevant day-to-day issues infused with religious themes and aired on commercial broadcast stations. Diyos at Bayan (God and Country), 1998-2005, by Villanueva, on RPN 9, PTV 4, and then on GMA News TV (GNTV), covers sociopolitical issues in its discussion. The 700 Club Asia, also on GNTV, tackles current events with guests.

Some talk programs are more political than religious. The Sulu Council of the Muslim Women Peace Advocates in Jolo launched the weekly program Women Talk Peace in a local radio station in 2004 to discuss peace and human rights from the perspective of Muslim women and Islamic faith (PCID 2012). Salam Radyo (Radio Salaam), DZUP, on air since 2010, produced by the University of the Philippines Institute of Islamic Studies, hosted by Julkipli Wadi, highlights Moro issues and aspirations.

Many faith-based shows offer family, legal, health, and livelihood counseling to their audiences. Family and relationship counseling programs include Family and Marriage and Pamilya Mo, Pamilya Ko (Your Family Is My Family, Too) on DZRV, Family Matters on DZAS, and Dr. Love with Bro. Jun Banaag on DZMM. Legal counseling programs include Magkabiyak sa Batas (Partners in Law), DZRV; Gabay, Batas at Serbisyo (Guidance, Law and Service), DZEC-TV Channel 49; and Law Center ni Kuya (Big Brother’s Law Center) on UNTV Channel 37. Health counseling programs include Kapanalig sa Kalusugan (Brothers in Health) and Kalusugan at Kabuhayan (Health and Livelihood) on DZRV, Doctors On Line on DZAS, Health Matters on INC-TV, and Clinic ni Kuya (Big Brother’s Clinic) on UNTV. Livelihood counseling programs include Kalusugan at Kabuhayan (Health and Livelihood) and Agri Troubleshooting at Kalusugan (Agriculture Troubleshooting and Health), both on DZRV; EntrePinoy (Filipino Entrepreneur) on DZAS; Agree sa Agri (Agree on Agriculture) on INC-TV; and Job Fair ni Kuya (Big Brother’s Job Fair) on UNTV.

Religious public service programs offer concrete actions to address the needs of their audiences. Some of these shows are Buhay Marino (Mariners’ Lives), where grievances of seafarers are resolved; Pulis ng Pilipino (Filipino Policemen), where listeners can report civil and criminal problems; and Caritas sa Veritas (Charity in Truth), which encourages Filipino Catholics to support the charitable institution Caritas Manila.

An example of a program that is news in format is Church News, about the actions and the administrative functions of the hierarchy of INC. Children’s programs with segments in animation that discuss the Bible are Kawan ng Cordero (Flock of Sheep), UNTV, and Mustard TV, TV Maria.

Religious programs that are music and variety entertainment include Sing for Joy, DZFE; A Song of Praise: Music Festival, a talent competition inviting amateur and professional songwriters to compose songs in God’s honor, UNTV; and Religious Music on Catholic Media Network’s (CMN) DXVP-AM “Virgen del Pilar” Radyo Verdadero in Zamboanga. DZFE 98.7 encourages meditation of the Scriptures with classical music. An interesting gospel music program for the youth was Mag-Smile Club Na (Join the Smile Club), 1996, IBC 13, starring PY Nakar.

The drama is also used by this type of programs. The 700 Club offers short documentaries and drama reenactments to visualize the situation it presents. Programs that are nonreligious but take on the religious stance are the noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Peek-a-Boo!), which regularly produces dramatized stories for its Lenten offerings. Mario O’Hara’s Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Himala? (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), 1979, BBC 2, is a television adaptation of the Spanish novel Marcelino, Pan y Vino, 1952, by José María Sánchez-Silva, about innocent faith. ABS-CBN’s hit telenovela May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10, talks of everyday miracles at a time when some Catholic priests were under fire for alleged involvement in child sex abuse cases.

Faith-based programs have also been the subject of inquiry by the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB). Episodes in 1992 of the weekly TV program Iglesia ni Cristo (Church of Christ), produced by the INC, received an X rating from the MTRCB because of the program’s criticisms of the veneration by Roman Catholics of the Virgin Mary. Eli Soriano’s Ang Dating Daan (The Old Way) went off the air in 2004 when MTRCB suspended it for three months following complaints by INC ministers, who were the target of invectives by Soriano on national television.

Broadcasters Kata Inocencio, Alex Tinsay, Carlo Lorenzo, and former Myx VJ Kristine Camille Antonio provide a fresh look on faith-based programs thatdeviate from the dry and didactic tone of most religious programs. (Encar Benedicto-Ordoñez Collection)

text:
Play, in contrast to work, is an important human activity for the purpose of entertainment, amusement, and distraction. Games, therefore, have been a major source of ideas for radio and TV programming since the advent of Philippine broadcasting. In game shows, contestants may answer questions, exhibit skills, or play games of chance in order to win prizes. Winning is decided by the interplay of luck, intelligence, strength, teamwork, and/or by popular support of the audience.

 

Radio game shows attracted broad listenership from the late 1940s to the 1950s. One of these shows, Ruleta Musikal (Musical Roulette), was hosted by Rafael “Paeng” Yabut on DZRH of the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC). The popular show was aborted in 1957 when Yabut was suspended by MBC due to his feisty political editorializing. Meanwhile, other DZRH game shows also became popular in this period. Spell-to-Win was a quiz show that gave away household appliances to anyone who could spell difficult words like “bouillabaisse.” Knowledge Unlimited was another quiz show that encouraged listeners to contribute their own questions—for example, “What war took place in 1812?” On Best of the Band, hosted by then popular crooner Bimbo Danao, was a program with a name-that-tune format (Isorena-Arcega 2009; Castro 2009).

 

 

 

Such game show prototypes were adapted for television. A variant of the quiz show was Battle of the Brains, 1992-99, televised by RPN 9. Hosted by David Celdran, it provided a venue for academic school competition with prizes of up to 1.7 million pesos. A name-that-tune format came with the advent of karaoke technology but instead of merely guessing songs, players sang the right lyrics. An example was GMA Network’s K! The 1 Million Peso Videoke Challenge, aka All Star K, 2002-9, hosted by Arnel Ignacio, and subsequently by Allan K and Jaya (Manila Standard 1992, 15; IMDb 2014a).

 

Kuarta o Kahon (Cash or Box), 1962-2000, hosted by singer-comedian Pepe Pimentel, was a pioneering game show that ran for 38 years. The show thrilled audiences as contestants chose between increasing cash offers and a mystery prize in a box, which may either be a bigger cash prize or an insignificant object like an egg or a coconut husk. The suspense was heightened by hoots and bets from a live audience. Meanwhile, the TV audience was given the upper hand by revealing to them the content in the box through graphics on-screen (San Diego, Aurelio, and Concepcion 2013).

 

The effectiveness of the show’s concept has been proven by the proliferation of Kuarta o Kahon variants. “Pera o Bayong” (Money or Basket) was a game segment in ABS-CBN’s noontime program Magandang Tanghali Bayan, 1998-2005, led by hosts Randy Santiago, John Estrada, and Willie Revillame. “Pera o Bayong” demolished the ratings of Eat Bulaga! (Peek-a-Boo!), the durable comedy game show produced by Television and Production Exponents Inc since 1979 and hosted by Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon. To regain noontime supremacy in ratings, Eat Bulaga! launched “Meron o Wala” (Filled or Empty), later known as “Laban o Bawi” (Fight or Recover), which was rehashed as “Taktak Mo o Tatakbo?” (Nail It or Run Away?) (Almo 2007).

 

 

 

The competing noontime programs increased their cash rewards to millions of pesos to lure the audience. Extravagant prizes have been criticized for cultivating a culture of begging among the poor who wait in long queues every day, hoping for the chance to earn quick money. The chilling effect of this trend was demonstrated by the tragic first anniversary episode of ABS-CBN’s Wowowee hosted by Willie Revillame. On 4 Feb 2006, some 30,000 people trooped to the Ultra Sports Complex in Pasig City to participate in the celebration. The wild rush resulted in a stampede that killed over 70 people (Godinez 2008; AP 2006).

 

The franchise of foreign game shows became a trend when Viva TV presented Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? from 2001 to 2002 on IBC 13. Hosted by Christopher de Leon, the show’s unexpected success prompted ABS-CBN to mount a local version hosted by Kris Aquino called Pilipinas Game Ka Na Ba? (Philippines Are You Ready to Play?) in 2001-2 (IMDb 2014b).

 

While the offer of grand gifts and cash is a big attraction, it cannot stop diminishing audience share when a game show loses its magic. Not even the fame of world boxing champion Manny Pacquiao and the millions he gave away in GMA Network’s Manny Many Prizes, 2011, were able to prolong the show beyond 2012. In contrast, Eat Bulaga!’s “Pinoy Henyo” (Genius Filipino) continues to delight various sectors of the Filipino audience since its inception in the mid-2000s. The simple game is played by two persons: one player sits on the “henyo” chair with a mystery word on his/her forehead. To guess the word, he/she asks the partner questions. The other player may only answer “yes,” “no,” or “possible.” The popularity of the game led to the creation of “Pinoy Henyo” applications or apps for android phone users (Bartholomew 2012; Google Play 2014).

 

Game shows have increasingly occupied TV time slots throughout the day and even the evening programming. However, their shelf life relies on the right mix of many ingredients that include the skill and appeal of hosts, the bravura and personality of players, the kinds of prizes given away, and the exciting conduct of the game. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

 

Sources

Almo 2007; AP 2006; Bartholomew 2012; Castro 2009; Godinez 2008; Google Play 2014; IMDb 2014b, 2014d; Isorena-Arcega 2009; Manila Standard 1992; San Diego, Aurelio, and Concepcion 2014; VIVA Entertainment 2014.
