Orly Mercado,

Cielito del Mundo, and Dr Antonio Talusan, hosts of Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko, 1976 

(Kapwa Ko Mahal Ko, www.kapwako.org)

text:
Health programs are shows that promote health education, endorse health advocacies, or dispense advice on health problems. They are often in educational magazine talk shows and public service programs, and usually have an interview segment of an expert. Lifestyle and game shows are recently emerging as health programs that promote healthy living and are secondarily educational in nature.

 

In a country with a severe lack of adequate and accessible health care, the media in the Philippines has played an important role as auxiliary informative tools to the existing, albeit meager and unevenly developed, health-care system. Frequently produced on broadcast radio channels, these shows are able to reach underdeveloped areas and marginalized sectors in the Philippines and serve as access points for poor Filipinos to seek free medical help.

 

A pioneer of the health program format, but for an entirely political purpose, was Rajio Taiso, a 15-minute calisthenics program on KZRH during the Japanese occupation. The station signed on at 7:55 am with this program beginning not later than Oct 1942. The program was repeated at noon. Government employees and schoolchildren were required to tune in to the program so they could follow the exercise commands of the odd unseen instructor. The physical exercise program, for some historians, was the station’s way to push forward the “Japanization” of Filipinos, best expressed through obedience to an invisible authority (Tribune 1942, 1943; Ampil 1986; Jose 1992).

 

Health programs gained prominence only in the 1970s, mainly in the form of public service programs. On radio, DZRH launched the program Operation Tulong (Operation Assistance), 1979, which aired from midnight until 2:00 am and was hosted by Manny Calpito, who interviewed on air and assisted people in need of medical care and all sorts of immediate help. Financial and other forms of support come from the listeners, not from government and corporations. On television, health shows in the form of public service were aired in the late afternoon programming, such as the charity shows Damayan (Helping One Another), 1976, GTV 4, with film actor Rosal Rosal calling on various organizations to help alleviate the plight of indigent people going to the program to seek help, and Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), 1974, GMA 7, with Orly Mercado, Boots Anson-Roa, Cielito del Mundo, and kidney specialist Dr Antonio Talusan helping those who need medical attention. Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko is the first program to feature volunteer sign-language interpreters from the Philippine School for the Deaf on a portion of the TV monitor. Rosal would also become one of Kapwa Ko’s regular hosts.

 

An indicator of the Filipinos’ need for medical education and accessible health services was the rise to prominence of John William Joseph Y. Xerez-Burgos Jr, known as Johnny Midnight, a pioneer reporter for Radyo Patrol in the 1960s. He set up a radio show aired from midnight to 2:00 am on DZBB that dispensed health tips enfolded in religious rhetoric. In 1981, a healing segment was inserted into his radio program. It introduced a style of water therapy called “toning” and “pyramid healing” and involved his listeners in a “healing session” as part of the show. He sold pyramids under which listeners were asked to put a glass of water and tune in to his program as astral energies generated through the aluminum tubes of the pyramid endowed the water with healing qualities. It was a 15-minute segment capped by Kuh Ledesma’s rendition of George Canseco’s “Bulaklak” (Flower).

 

Later health care programs, particularly in the 2000s, became more scientific, although many also had a religious impetus for putting the show on air. Doctors on Line started airing in 2004 on DZAS-AM 702-AM Agapay ng Sambayanan (Public Aid) with a simulcast on DXKI-FM 1062 and is available for streaming through the Far Eastern Broadcasting Company’s website. Hosted by Carmen Go-Vargas and Haydee Bernardo Sampang, the show, which is actually designed to cater to listeners’ spiritual as well as physical health, has several segments, specializing in current news and recent studies on health issues, advice on recognizing signs and symptoms of diseases, interviews with guest doctors and medical experts who answer questions submitted by listeners through text messages, calls, or the program’s Facebook page, and medical education that explains medical language in layperson’s terms. The program also covers spiritual health and biblical readings. Another excellent health show on radio is Doctor’s Orders, DWWW 774, which began sometime in the late 2000s, hosted by Dr Jaime Galvez Tan, former undersecretary of the Department of Health. The program highlights local indigenous knowledge and practices on medicine. DZUP 1602, the campus radio station of the University of the Philippines (UP), collaborates with the UP College of Medicine to produce a one-hour weekly program titled Health Matters, which began airing in 2011. Hosted by Fernando Austria Jr and Romar Jay Tirona, nicknamed Klasmeyt Jun and Klasmeyt Roj to signify the educational framing of the show, the program teaches listeners about health issues, health campaigns and advocacies, remedies to various conditions, and services that are available in the UP College of Medicine, the UP Philippine General Hospital, and the Department of Health. The show is packaged to be casual and accessible to students and communities. It received the 8th Hildegarde Awards for Outstanding Achievements in Broadcast Media-Radio in 2014.

 

An advocacy health program on television was Bodytalk, 2003-05, The Knowledge Channel, hosted by Aiza Seguerra, a weekly 30-minute educational series on adolescent reproductive health, including sensitive and controversial issues: menstruation, masturbation, the male and female bodies, sexual intercourse, and sexual violence. The show invited teenagers and students to participate through guesting, spot interviews, or as extras. It supplemented health education in schools in line with the media campaigns of the Women’s Media Circle.

 

Important health programs on television include Salamat, Dok (Thank You, Doctor), premiered in 2004, ABS-CBN, which incorporates public service, medical health information, alternative medicine, and practical home remedy tips; Talk to Doc, 2010, ABS-CBN News Channel, which tackles specific medical cases and their corresponding treatment programs, discussed from the perspective of patients and their doctors; and Pinoy MD: Mga Doktor ng Bayan (Filipino MD: Public Doctors), begun in 2010, GMA, which offers viewers practical tips on how to deal with different medical issues and how to practice a healthy lifestyle.

 

Television shows that promote healthy living have also been produced. Game Plan, 1995-2008, which aired on GMA, Studio 23, and Solar Sports, was originally packaged as a sports show but was relaunched in 2012 with a more clearly defined advocacy for healthy living through sports. In 2011, ABS-CBN aired The Biggest Loser, a competitive game show wherein overweight contestants competed with one another to lose weight safely. A groundbreaking program that combines news coverage and emergency medical first-responder services is Rescue5, premiered 2013, TV5, led by reporter Paolo Bediones. The show equips news reporters and camerapersons with life-saving skills, allowing them to deliver not only news but also crucial assistance during emergencies and disasters. The program Emergency, which began in 1995, GMA, features reports of advances in the medical field, rescue operations of emergency response teams, safety tips concerning disaster and accidents, and stories of the heroic deeds of ordinary people in life-threatening situations.

 

As the health-care system remains sorely underdeveloped, health programs on broadcast media, which prescribe particular ways of life, continue to be relevant to many Filipinos in dire need of medical assistance and health education. Written byLouise Jashil R. Sonido w ith notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

In a country with a severe lack of adequate and accessible health care, the media in the Philippines has played an important role as auxiliary informative tools to the existing, albeit meager and unevenly developed, health-care system. Frequently produced on broadcast radio channels, these shows are able to reach underdeveloped areas and marginalized sectors in the Philippines and serve as access points for poor Filipinos to seek free medical help.

A pioneer of the health program format, but for an entirely political purpose, was Rajio Taiso, a 15-minute calisthenics program on KZRH during the Japanese occupation. The station signed on at 7:55 am with this program beginning not later than Oct 1942. The program was repeated at noon. Government employees and schoolchildren were required to tune in to the program so they could follow the exercise commands of the odd unseen instructor. The physical exercise program, for some historians, was the station’s way to push forward the “Japanization” of Filipinos, best expressed through obedience to an invisible authority (Tribune 1942, 1943; Ampil 1986; Jose 1992).

Health programs gained prominence only in the 1970s, mainly in the form of public service programs. On radio, DZRH launched the program Operation Tulong (Operation Assistance), 1979, which aired from midnight until 2:00 am and was hosted by Manny Calpito, who interviewed on air and assisted people in need of medical care and all sorts of immediate help. Financial and other forms of support come from the listeners, not from government and corporations. On television, health shows in the form of public service were aired in the late afternoon programming, such as the charity shows Damayan (Helping One Another), 1976, GTV 4, with film actor Rosal Rosal calling on various organizations to help alleviate the plight of indigent people going to the program to seek help, and Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), 1974, GMA 7, with Orly Mercado, Boots Anson-Roa, Cielito del Mundo, and kidney specialist Dr Antonio Talusan helping those who need medical attention. Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko is the first program to feature volunteer sign-language interpreters from the Philippine School for the Deaf on a portion of the TV monitor. Rosal would also become one of Kapwa Ko’s regular hosts.

An indicator of the Filipinos’ need for medical education and accessible health services was the rise to prominence of John William Joseph Y. Xerez-Burgos Jr, known as Johnny Midnight, a pioneer reporter for Radyo Patrol in the 1960s. He set up a radio show aired from midnight to 2:00 am on DZBB that dispensed health tips enfolded in religious rhetoric. In 1981, a healing segment was inserted into his radio program. It introduced a style of water therapy called “toning” and “pyramid healing” and involved his listeners in a “healing session” as part of the show. He sold pyramids under which listeners were asked to put a glass of water and tune in to his program as astral energies generated through the aluminum tubes of the pyramid endowed the water with healing qualities. It was a 15-minute segment capped by Kuh Ledesma’s rendition of George Canseco’s “Bulaklak” (Flower).

Later health care programs, particularly in the 2000s, became more scientific, although many also had a religious impetus for putting the show on air. Doctors on Line started airing in 2004 on DZAS-AM 702-AM Agapay ng Sambayanan (Public Aid) with a simulcast on DXKI-FM 1062 and is available for streaming through the Far Eastern Broadcasting Company’s website. Hosted by Carmen Go-Vargas and Haydee Bernardo Sampang, the show, which is actually designed to cater to listeners’ spiritual as well as physical health, has several segments, specializing in current news and recent studies on health issues, advice on recognizing signs and symptoms of diseases, interviews with guest doctors and medical experts who answer questions submitted by listeners through text messages, calls, or the program’s Facebook page, and medical education that explains medical language in layperson’s terms. The program also covers spiritual health and biblical readings. Another excellent health show on radio is Doctor’s Orders, DWWW 774, which began sometime in the late 2000s, hosted by Dr Jaime Galvez Tan, former undersecretary of the Department of Health. The program highlights local indigenous knowledge and practices on medicine. DZUP 1602, the campus radio station of the University of the Philippines (UP), collaborates with the UP College of Medicine to produce a one-hour weekly program titled Health Matters, which began airing in 2011. Hosted by Fernando Austria Jr and Romar Jay Tirona, nicknamed Klasmeyt Jun and Klasmeyt Roj to signify the educational framing of the show, the program teaches listeners about health issues, health campaigns and advocacies, remedies to various conditions, and services that are available in the UP College of Medicine, the UP Philippine General Hospital, and the Department of Health. The show is packaged to be casual and accessible to students and communities. It received the 8th Hildegarde Awards for Outstanding Achievements in Broadcast Media-Radio in 2014.

An advocacy health program on television was Bodytalk, 2003-05, The Knowledge Channel, hosted by Aiza Seguerra, a weekly 30-minute educational series on adolescent reproductive health, including sensitive and controversial issues: menstruation, masturbation, the male and female bodies, sexual intercourse, and sexual violence. The show invited teenagers and students to participate through guesting, spot interviews, or as extras. It supplemented health education in schools in line with the media campaigns of the Women’s Media Circle.

Important health programs on television include Salamat, Dok (Thank You, Doctor), premiered in 2004, ABS-CBN, which incorporates public service, medical health information, alternative medicine, and practical home remedy tips; Talk to Doc, 2010, ABS-CBN News Channel, which tackles specific medical cases and their corresponding treatment programs, discussed from the perspective of patients and their doctors; and Pinoy MD: Mga Doktor ng Bayan (Filipino MD: Public Doctors), begun in 2010, GMA, which offers viewers practical tips on how to deal with different medical issues and how to practice a healthy lifestyle.

Television shows that promote healthy living have also been produced. Game Plan, 1995-2008, which aired on GMA, Studio 23, and Solar Sports, was originally packaged as a sports show but was relaunched in 2012 with a more clearly defined advocacy for healthy living through sports. In 2011, ABS-CBN aired The Biggest Loser, a competitive game show wherein overweight contestants competed with one another to lose weight safely. A groundbreaking program that combines news coverage and emergency medical first-responder services is Rescue5, premiered 2013, TV5, led by reporter Paolo Bediones. The show equips news reporters and camerapersons with life-saving skills, allowing them to deliver not only news but also crucial assistance during emergencies and disasters. The program Emergency, which began in 1995, GMA, features reports of advances in the medical field, rescue operations of emergency response teams, safety tips concerning disaster and accidents, and stories of the heroic deeds of ordinary people in life-threatening situations.

As the health-care system remains sorely underdeveloped, health programs on broadcast media, which prescribe particular ways of life, continue to be relevant to many Filipinos in dire need of medical assistance and health education. text:
A horror program is one that seeks to elicit disquiet, fear, panic, or terror. A fantasy program draws out wonder or amazement by tackling phenomena beyond ordinary and mundane reality. The combination of the two genres is a reliable formula to hold the sustained interest of radio and TV audiences. This penchant for horror and fantasy has a deeper basis. Filipino cosmology from precolonial times to the present consists of realms populated by otherworldly beings. These entities are gods, goddesses, fairies or encantada, ethereal fetus snatchers or the manananggal, shape-shifting witches called the aswang, and nature spirits like the kapre or giant, duwende or elf, and tikbalang or horselike creature. Our folklore abounds with mythical creatures like winged serpents and giant birds. Filipino consciousness embraces belief in the afterlife, which makes ghosts and wandering spirits part of reality. Our literature is replete with epic heroes like Aliguyon, Bantugan, Labaw Donggon, and Lam-ang who all possess incredible powers that rival those of Superman or the X-Men.

 

No wonder then that Severino Reyes’s Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), about fantastic tales in Philippine folklore, has been told and retold in literature, theater, film, radio, and television. In the 1950s, Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang was serialized into a DZRH radio drama with Luz Fernandez as Lola Basyang. Due to the unfading popularity of the long-running radio drama, it was made into a movie in 1985 with comic actor Chichay in the title role. Then in 2007-08, GMA Network produced Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang with storyteller Manilyn Reynes as the granddaughter of Lola Basyang. In 2008, DZRH again produced Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang into a special radio drama trilogy still with Luz Fernandez as Lola Basyang (Socorro 2011; Gonzales 2007).

 

Also in the 1950s, DZRH aired Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), a radio drama about a discreet man who was given fantastic powers by the god Zeus to fight crime. The popularity of the radio program led to a film of the same title with Armando Goyena as Kapitan Kidlat in 1953. Another popular radio program then was Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror). The program was heralded by the creepy howling of a dog, the demonic voice of Mike Perez announcing “Ito ang gabi ng lagim!” (This is the night of terror!), and the screams of a woman over the sinister laughter of Perez. Due to its tremendous popularity, Gabi ng Lagim was made into a film in 1960 and was subsequently produced as a TV series on MBC 11. Many decades later, the spine-chilling voice of Mike Perez is still used to scare carnival thrill-seekers in Star City’s Horror House (DZRH 2014; Cruz 2014; Dalisay 2013; Komixrama 2011). After a long absence, Gabi ng Lagim is back on the air weeknights on DZRH (Benjamin 2014).

 

A suspense-horror series in 1972 was Malikmata (Illusion) over ABC 5 in 1972. First directed by Lupita Concio and then by Lino Brocka, the episodes presented chilling stories like cannibalism and communicating with spirits through the Ouija board. The modern treatment of the horror genre, sometimes with camp or with quiet fear, was gaining viewership for Malikmata when TV stations closed with the declaration of martial law in Sep 1972 (veroli1974 2010).

 

Situational comedies or sitcom became popular in the 1980s. A new approach was to marry fantasy and comedy as shown in the Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!) series that became a big hit for 10 years. The first cast was composed of Vic Sotto as Enteng the human husband, Alice Dixson as Faye the fairy wife, Aiza Seguerra as the crossbreed daughter, and Charito Solis as the fairy grandmother. Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! ran in 1987-89 on IBC 13, then on ABS-CBN in 1989-95, and then on GMA 7 in 1996-97. The story revolved around the problems of a marriage between an ordinary human and a fairy princess. Two films with the same title based on the TV sitcom became box-office hits in the early 1990s (Retro Pilipinas 2012).

 

TV primetime programming in the 1980s also saw the development of gruesome horror series, like Regal Television’s Regal Shockers, 1985-91. The drama anthology was meant to terrify audiences with gore, violence, and dark terror. However, it gradually lost the support of advertisers due to its perceived negative effect, especially on minors. In an effort to depart from the ghastly treatment of the horror genre, MAQ Productions, a subsidiary of Regal Television, launched Lihim ng Gabi(Secrets of the Night) in 1996-97 over GMA Network. The show pioneered in the mixed format of documentary and dramatic feature that present real people telling their supernatural experiences with commentaries from paranormal experts or researchers. Episodes included real-life stories on reincarnation, extraterrestrials, kulam or hex, gayuma or magic love potion, haunted house, near-death experience, and being possessed by spirits.

 

To conquer children’s viewership, ABS-CBN created its own long-running fantasy program, Wansapanataym, premiered in 1997. The anthology is patterned after Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang and western fairy tales. It utilizes digital computer graphics and prosthetics to create a more modern look. Famous stars are billed with child actors to portray roles like kings, queens, fairies, elves, genies, and witches. Each episode is meant to teach a lesson.

 

To gain audience share among teenagers and young adults, ABS-CBN presented its own docudrama with true-to-life characters interviewed on camera in Nginig! (Shivers!), 2004-6. Nginig! was also partly reality TV since it capitalized on a young team of so-called psychics, with host Raymond Bagatsing, to detect otherworldly or ghostly incidents in the actual locations of the episodes. An extension of the anthology called Nginig: The Hidden Files was aired over Studio 23 hosted by hip-hop dancers Spencer Reyes, Jhong Hilario, Danilo Barrios, and Nico Manalo (ABS-CBN Interface 2004; ABS-CBN wikis).

 

The importance of the fantasy genre is demonstrated by the fact that GMA Network unseated ABS-CBN as top-rating network through the fantasy drama series that was repackaged as fantaserye or telefantasya (fantasy series). The fantaserye capitalizes on grand production design, bizarre prosthetics, and digital imaging. GMA Network was able to achieve ratings supremacy first through Mulawin, 2004, about creatures who were half-human and half-bird, featuring the love team of Angel Locsin and Richard Gutierrez. The success of Mulawin prompted GMA Network to produce its film version in 2005. GMA Network also produced the expensive fantaserye Encantadia (Fairyland), 2005, which portrayed the power struggles in a world of fairies, warriors, and mythical creatures divided into four kingdoms representing water, earth, wind, and fire. The sustained victory in the fantaserye ratings encouraged GMA Network to adapt Mars Ravelo’s komiks characters like Dyesebel the mermaid and Darna the celestial heroine. Marian Rivera’s Dyesebel, 2008, and Darna, 2009, were great hits. But it was Angel Locsin’s previous Darna, 2005, that reached a record high of 52.1 rating when Locsin first wore the Darna attire in the series (Philippine Drama Series 2010).

 

Determined to regain its position as the top TV station, ABS-CBN lured Locsin to transfer to its camp. She was immediately given her own two-part series, paired with leading ABS-CBN actors Piolo Pascual and John Lloyd Cruz. As expected, ABS-CBN ratings soared with Lobo (Werewolf) in 2008 and Imortal (Immortal) in 2010. Both fantasy-horror series were derivatives of Hollywood movies, like Underworld, 2003, and Twilight, 2008, that deal with the gothic world of vampires and werewolves (Santiago 2009; IMDb 2014a; Mendoza 2009; Philippine Drama Series 2010).

 

Even the news and public affairs department of broadcast networks capitalize on horror and fantasy. One of the favorite topics is tracking down ghosts in the infamous Manila Film Center (MFC) building that collapsed in 1981, allegedly burying hundreds of workers. ABS-CBN’s Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), hosted by Noli de Castro, went back to the scene of the tragedy in a Halloween episode titled “Haunted Theatre in Roxas Boulevard,” in the early 1990s. The episode interviewed people who experienced ghostly presence in the building. It also invited psychics to act as spirit mediums so that disturbed souls may intelligibly communicate their messages. Meanwhile, GMA Network’s i-Witness episode about the MFC was “Multo ng Nakaraan” (Ghost of the Past), 2005. The documentary by Howie Severino traced the unknown survivors and the relatives of victims who were either recovered or still buried in the building. In the episode, Severino arranged for the extraordinary encounter of relatives and survivors after 24 years when they revisited the ill-fated building (GMA Network 2014).

 

Because of network competition, broadcast journalists investigate paranormal phenomena not just with straight reporting but with the aid of digital special effects and scary dramatization by bit players. Such devices have become common: the segment “Gabi ng Lagim Halloween Special,” 2013, of GMA Network’s Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho) traced the possible relatives of a child ghost that haunted a vehicle and its driver. ABS-CBN’s Hiwaga series, 2012, hosted by Atom Araullo, examined paranormal experiences of ordinary people.

 

The genre thrives on Philippine radio and television because of the Filipino belief in the supernatural—whether demonic or divine. Innovations, like the use of famous stars or hosts and digital technology, enhance storytelling about real-life or fictional characters. Thus, the horror and fantasy show has proven its ability to attract audiences, critical raves, and awards from national and international organizations. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

text:
The komedi (comedy) is a humorous work that aims to amuse audiences and provoke laughter. The characters are often ridiculous, their behavior is sometimes exaggerated, the situations are funny, and the narrative is either predictable or full of surprising twists and turns.

 

The komedi in Philippine broadcast is of three types: the situational comedy or sitcom, the gag show or sketch comedy, and the stand-up comedy. A sitcom has a predictable plot: someone makes a mistake, the error puts the characters in unexpected situations, the mistake is discovered at the end, and the characters patch things up. A gag show is a mixed bag of sketches, spoofs, and music that parodies human foibles, plays practical jokes about everyday life, caricatures products and services, or critiques sociopolitical issues and personalities. In stand-up comedy, a performer recites a monologue or performs an act in humorous ways.

 

The sitcom follows various formats. The straight narrative, some slapstick in rendition and with themes focusing on family and friends, is the most common, such as Tang-Tarang-Tang (a play on “Tatang,” a variant of the term for a male parent), about a dysfunctional Filipino family and its patriarch, which started in the 1950s on KZRH and became a popular show in the late 1960s until the 1970s on Channel 3; John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-90, RPN 9, about a poor family’s hilarious responses to its social condition; Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977-90, IBC 13, about a bunch of lazy, ambition-less students making fun of people around them; Hapi House (Happy House), 1987-88, IBC 13, which showed the oddities, ironies, and awkward moments of a typical Filipino family; Buddy en Sol (Buddy and Sol), 1991-93, RPN 9, about friendships and loyalties in the midst of conflicts; and Pepito Manaloto, which premiered in 2010, GMA, about the funny daily experiences of an instant-millionaire family.

 

Some comedy programs are infused with fantasy, such as Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-97, first on IBC 13, then ABS-CBN, and GMA, about the marriage of a human being and a supernatural, and Vampire ang Daddy Ko (My Daddy Is a Vampire), which premiered in 2013, GMA, about the battle between good and evil.

 

Some sitcoms carry a political tone that comment on Filipino manners, politics, customs, and government. The earliest example is Horacio de la Costa’s Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which first aired on KZRM Radio in 1938 before World War II and went on until the 1960s, interrupted only by the Japanese occupation. Similar sitcoms are Barrio Balimbing (Barrio of Turncoats), 1986 on IBC 13, then 1987-88 on ABS-CBN, about ordinary people’s perception of political and social issues; and Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, ABS-CBN, about the peccadilloes of a morally depraved elite family foisting their whims on the rest of society as other people imitate, repel, fight, praise, and hobnob with them.

 

Lately, the comedy forms part of light romance stories, called the rom-com, although this format is often used in films than in broadcast. The comedic sequences, however, recede at some point of the narrative to give way to the more dramatic moments of the show, but ends in a light, positive mood. An example is the telenovela Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just One Glance), 2013, ABS-CBN.

 

Early gag shows were features of the variety show, the earliest of which was de la Costa’s Common Weal Hour in the 1930s on KZIB. KZRH during World War II allotted time for Tagalog skits. The format of the slapstick gag show was exploited to the full beginning in the 1960s by Super Laff-Ins, 1960s, ABC RTV 5, followed by T.O.D.A.S., 1977-89, IBC 13; Goin’ Bananas, 1986-91, BBC 2, then IBC 13, then ABS-CBN; Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, ABC 5; and Bubble Gang, which premiered in 1995, GMA.

 

Sociopolitical gag shows included Under the Guava Tree with Juan Tamad, 1962, IBC13; Champoy, 1975-85, first on GTV 4, then on RPN 9; U.F.O.: Urbana, Felisa, and Others, 1984-89, GMA 7; Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89, IBC 13; Mongolian Barbecue, 1990-91, IBC 13, then 1993-95, RPN 9; Ispup (Spoof), 1999-2004, ABC5; and Kontrabando (Smuggled), 2015, TV5.

 

Spoof comedy in the mid-1990s and on through the 2000s combined some elements of reality television, mostly practical jokes on people on the streets and the funny situations in which some of these people are caught on camera. Examples are Wow Mali (Oh No, It’s a Mistake), 1996-2006, 2009-15; The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel, 2003-5; and Mommy Elvie’s Problematic Show, 2007-8, all on ABC/TV5.

 

The stand-up comedy could be traced to the early comic repartees of radio actors in the 1930s until World War II. Comic partners who made fun of each other were Pugo and Togo, German San Jose and Leonora Reyes, Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan, and Vicente Ocampo and Diana Toy. article.value: The komedi (comedy) is a humorous work that aims to amuse audiences and provoke laughter. The characters are often ridiculous, their behavior is sometimes exaggerated, the situations are funny, and the narrative is either predictable or full of surprising twists and turns.

The komedi in Philippine broadcast is of three types: the situational comedy or sitcom, the gag show or sketch comedy, and the stand-up comedy. A sitcom has a predictable plot: someone makes a mistake, the error puts the characters in unexpected situations, the mistake is discovered at the end, and the characters patch things up. A gag show is a mixed bag of sketches, spoofs, and music that parodies human foibles, plays practical jokes about everyday life, caricatures products and services, or critiques sociopolitical issues and personalities. In stand-up comedy, a performer recites a monologue or performs an act in humorous ways.

The sitcom follows various formats. The straight narrative, some slapstick in rendition and with themes focusing on family and friends, is the most common, such as Tang-Tarang-Tang (a play on “Tatang,” a variant of the term for a male parent), about a dysfunctional Filipino family and its patriarch, which started in the 1950s on KZRH and became a popular show in the late 1960s until the 1970s on Channel 3; John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-90, RPN 9, about a poor family’s hilarious responses to its social condition; Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977-90, IBC 13, about a bunch of lazy, ambition-less students making fun of people around them; Hapi House (Happy House), 1987-88, IBC 13, which showed the oddities, ironies, and awkward moments of a typical Filipino family; Buddy en Sol (Buddy and Sol), 1991-93, RPN 9, about friendships and loyalties in the midst of conflicts; and Pepito Manaloto, which premiered in 2010, GMA, about the funny daily experiences of an instant-millionaire family.

Some comedy programs are infused with fantasy, such as Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-97, first on IBC 13, then ABS-CBN, and GMA, about the marriage of a human being and a supernatural, and Vampire ang Daddy Ko (My Daddy Is a Vampire), which premiered in 2013, GMA, about the battle between good and evil.

The earliest example is Horacio de la Costa’s Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which first aired on KZRM Radio in 1938 before World War II and went on until the 1960s, interrupted only by the Japanese occupation. article_title: Legal Advice Shows and Legal Dramas

photos.desc:
Atty. Jose Sison, host of Ipaglaban Mo, 1988 

(Photo courtesy of ABS-CBN)

text:
Like health and counseling programs, broadcast shows that dispense legal advice and discuss legal cases attract viewers and listeners. Similarly, legal dramas, a genre of the soap opera, which reenact actual cases or dramatize fictional cases, fascinate audiences, particularly on television. In legal advice shows, lawyers who host the programs respond to callers and e-mail writers who seek legal guidance concerning citizen rights or problems that may require legal solutions.

 

Legal advice programs are produced for radio, television, and teleradyo, a combination of television and the Tagalog radyo (radio), referring to simultaneous transmission of the live video and audio of the radio announcer inside the radio studio via cable television and the sound of the program via radio. The cases brought before the hosts for legal opinion include wills and inheritance, quarrels and disagreements among relatives, unfaithful spouses, and unpaid lease rentals. Real names of callers are kept confidential. The more well-known examples are Compañero y Compañera (in Spanish, male colleague and female colleague), which aired on DZMM from 1994 until it moved to ABS-CBN in 1997, then to GMA Network in 1998, and to RPN 9 in 2000 until 2001. It was hosted by lawyer and later senator Renato Cayetano with Gel Relos while on DZMM and Channel 2. On the air on DZMM since 1996 is Usapang de Campanilla (referring to discourse between prominent lawyers), hosted by lawyer Danilo Concepcion. Another lawyer, Mel Sta. Maria, gives legal advice in the radio program Relasyon (Relations) on Radyo5 and “Makatarungan Ba?” (Is it Just?), a segment on TV5’s news program Aksyon (Action). On Channel 11 from 1992 to 1996, lawyer Joji Antonio-Alonso hosted The Police Hour every midnight. She has been hosting the Legal Forum on the same channel since 1994, daily for 15 minutes. One of the latest legal advice programs to go on air is Legal Help Desk on CNN Philippines Channel 9, since 2012, hosted by lawyer Karen Jimeno.

 

Radio has so far produced only one legal drama, Ginang Hukom (Madame Judge) on DZRH in the 1950s, based on cases decided by Philippine courts. When television began showing courtroom drama and other legal drama subgenres, such as crime investigation, beginning also in the 1950s, no other similar radio show followed Ginang Hukom. On television, actual legal cases are dramatized on Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), since 1988 on IBC Channel 13, GMA Channel 7, and ABS-CBN, hosted by lawyer Jose Sison. This program inspired two movies, Ipaglaban Mo: The Movie (Redeem Her Honor), 1995, directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya, and Ipaglaban Mo: The Movie II (Fight for It: The Movie 2), 1997, directed by Rory B. Quintos. Another program that dramatized actual legal cases was Calvento Files, 1995-98, ABS-CBN, which was also produced into a movie, Calvento Files: The Movie, 1997, directed by Lauren Dyogi and Michael de Mesa. Other legal dramas include Scene of the Crime Operatives (S.O.C.O.), 2005-11, DZMM TeleRadyo; Crime Klasik (Crime Classic), since 2012, Aksyon TV; Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is One You), 2009-10, ABS-CBN; and Case Unclosed, 2008-10, GMA Network. A real-life drama that unfolds live before a studio audience is Public Atorni: Asunto o Areglo? (Public Attorney: Lawsuit or Amicable Settlement?), 2010, on TV5, where lawyer Persida Rueda-Acosta arbitrates disputes over small claims.

 

Given the high-profile depiction of lawyers and the exciting portrayal of courtroom combat and crime investigations, legal dramas and legal advice programs are expected to endure on the air, with the courts providing an almost inexhaustible file of actual cases to a mesmerized audience. Written by Victor C. Avecilla

text:
Magazine programs are mélanges of diverse items packaged in an episode that either lack a thematic coherence or have a unifying topic but presented in segments of different formats. The segments may feature interviews, commentaries, instructional guides, entertainment, news, or any combination of these forms. Magazine shows on lifestyle, food, and travel are highly popular in Philippine broadcast.

 

This type of program came to full bloom in the early 1970s. A pioneer was the pre-martial law daily news magazine The Morning Show, which was revived during martial law as Good Morning, Manila, GTV 4. It featured personalities, the weather, sports, and other cultural facts.

 

Since then, morning magazine shows have been radio and television standards for years, broadcast early in the morning, typically 5:30-7:00 am. Every radio channel and network has a number of variations on this form, with its hosts typically conversing on topics such as family, health, home, and news bits from the previous day. Usual segments include exercise tips, market tours, cooking demonstrations, and updates on local festivities and events. A staple element on breakfast television is the token living room set where the hosts facilitate talk among themselves or with viewers, and shifts between segments.

 

An excellent magazine program beginning in the mid-1970s was Metro Magazine, a combination of talk, travelogue, and mini-documentaries, produced by the Metro Manila Commission. Ms. Ellaneous, 1977-84, GMA, was a weekly lifestyle program that combined talk, games, and documentary, covering topics ranging from human interest stories to tourist destinations to do-it-yourself tutorials. Womanwatch, 1983-85, was a magazine show with a specific interest in women’s issues like sexual harrassment, domestic violence, and child abuse.

 

ANC airs several lifestyle telemagazine programs. Green Living focuses on sustainable urban living, with special interest in building green homes, promoting best environmental practices, featuring healthy recipes, and developing sustainable business practices. Executive Class incorporates infotainment and travelogue in featuring exotic destinations all over Europe, North America, and Asia, catering to an elite audience more interested in luxury travel and living than off-road adventures, detailing where successful executives and top brass go for the best hotels, sights to see, and shopping opportunities.

 

Cooking shows are also crowd favorites on Philippine television. The pioneer was Nora Daza, whose televised culinary career began as early as 1958 when she hosted Let’s Cook with Nora, ABS-CBN, then Cooking It Up with Nora, BBC 2, in the 1980s and a radio show called At Home with Nora. The cooking show genre is not limited to women. Chef Pablo “Boy” Logro also enjoyed acclaim as a celebrity chef on Philippine television when he co-hosted Idol sa Kusina (Kitchen Idol), 2011, and Chef Boy Logro: Kusina Master (Chef Boy Logro: Kitchen Master), 2012, both on GMA Life TV. The cooking show format was also combined with talk entertainment to have hosts accommodate cooking ideas from featured guests. Janice de Belen hosted the noontime cooking show called Spoon, 2007-15, Net 25, where chefs and other celebrities were invited to share their recipes.

 

Travel and tourism also became popular themes for magazine shows. Travel Time, 1986-2015, on GMA, IBC 13, and ANC, hosted by Susan Calo-Medina, was the longest-running travel documentary show at 24 years, with its emphasis on local over foreign travel destinations. Tatak Pilipino (Filipino Trademark), 1990-94, ABS-CBN, hosted by Jim Paredes and Gel Santos Relos, featured perceived eccentricities and unique practices of Filipino culture, covering topics like local circumcision practices, eating azucena (dog meat) and balut (boiled duck egg with a nearly developed embryo), Pinoy hospitality, local crafts, komiks, Philippine games, history, and a range of other subjects. A similar program was Pep Talk, 1988-90, ABS-CBN, by Loren Legarda, who toured the entire country to feature varied interesting people and places. Cheche Lazaro Presents, 1998-2003 on GMA, then 2010-14 on ABS-CBN, was a lifestyle and travel telemagazine that featured Lazaro taking viewers to diverse places, peoples, and cultures of the Philippines, Asia, Australia, Europe, and South America, touring them through the cultural and historical sights, taking them on local food binges, and engaging them in interviews with locals and immersions in local activities and festivals. A show with a novel approach is Francisco “Paco” Guerrero’s What I See, which first ran on GMA News TV in 2012. The show features the host’s travel photography. He interacts with Filipino artisans to capture their lives, activities, and modes of expression in story-rich photographs. The travelogue doubles as a photography and art show as Guerrero shares tips on taking pictures and, in a segment of the show, demonstrates his own portraiture techniques while sharing his views on the things he witnessed. Travel shows have been such timeless audience favorites that Lakbay Travel Channel, or Lakbay TV, a channel dedicated exclusively to travel and tourism shows, was launched in 1999. The channel is geared toward responsible tourism development and cultural pride.

 

Other magazine programs focus on specific themes. Apple Pie, Patis, Paté, Atbp. (Apple Pie, Fish Sauce, Paté, Etc.), 1986-89, RPN 9, presented the multifaceted lives of Filipinos abroad. AgriLink, 1993-99, ABC 5, was an agricultural-entrepreneurial magazine. Lovely Day, 2004-9, GMA, was a children’s magazine that featured children immersing themselves in various experiences that teach them social, cultural, and life lessons. Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho), which began in 2004, GMA, specializes on different cuisines and features life stories and events that have gone viral on social media. Sports magazines include Game Plan, 1995-2008, first on GMA, then on Studio 23, and Sports Unlimited, 1997-2015, ABS-CBN. An environmental magazine is Born to Be Wild, premiered 2007, GMA, the first and, as of yet, only locally produced nature documentary show on Philippine TV.

 

Throughout the history of Philippine broadcast media, magazine programs have served as ways for Filipinos to engage with each other and recognize points of intersection between different cultures, struggles, and life experiences. Indeed, from light and easy infotainment to journalistic documentary programming, these shows have been integral to the production of the Filipinos’ collective imagination of themselves, their own country, and the Filipino nation. Written by Louise Jashil R. Sonido with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
Music videos on television are short video films of song and imagery, also coloquially known as “MTV” (Moller 2011). The term is derived from the popularity of the Music Television (MTV) network in the 1990s, which was among the first music and entertainment networks airing foreign, and later local, music videos in the country. Music videos were then mostly videotaped performances of a musical piece. Now, music on television or MTVs are developing and evolving into forms with various aesthetic and thematic influences from advertising to cinema, and to “new media.”

 

MTV Network was launched in 1981, with “Video Killed the Radio Star” by The Buggles as the first music video to go on air (Moller 2011; Peake 2015). It took more than a decade for the US-based MTV Channel of the Viacom Media Networks to expand to Asia in 1992 and to Southeast Asia in 1995. From 1992 to 2010, MTV broadcast on then STAR TV-controlled MTV Asia. Other networks that also aired music videos in the Philippines were Channel [V] Philippines, 1994-2011, MYX, beginning in 2001, and UNTV, 2001-04, counterpart of the FM rock radio station NU 107.

 

 

 

Initial MTV programming were countdowns of the top music videos, adopted from FM radio stations. A rotating cast of video jockeys (VJs), instead of disc jockeys (DJs), hosts these charts that factor in airplays and album sales. Francis Magalona, “King of Pinoy Rap,” was the first Filipino VJ on MTV Asia. Other Filipino VJs of TV shows on MTV Southeast Asia and the MTV Philippines include Andi Manzano, Sib Sibulo, Kat Alano, Anne Curtis, Maggie Wilson, Victor Basa, Donita Rose, KC Montero, Sarah Meier, Belinda Panelo, Cindy Kurleto, Marc Abaya, KC Concepcion, Patty Laurel, Shannen Torres, and Mariel Rodriguez. Most of these VJs were selected through the MTV VJ Hunt, a search conducted every two years. In the latest reincarnation of MTV Philippines, MTV Pinoy, VJs include Sam Pinto, Yassi Pressman, Andre Paras, Josh Padilla, Shy Carlos, Chris Schneider, Aryanna Epperson, Kito Romualdez, and Katarina Rodriguez.

 

Through the years, MTV served as a platform for music-related shows featuring TV personalities, music icons, and their personal lives, such as MTV Cribs, about mansions of celebrities, and MTV Pimp My Ride, about car-makeovers of celebrities. Among MTV’s animated shows seen in the Philippines were the claymation Celebrity Deathmatch, where stars of the international music industry fight to the death in a wrestling ring; and Beavis and Butthead, where the two eponymous teenagers comment and watch music videos, often making fun of them. More weird adult cartoons were produced under the label MTV Oddities.

 

 

 

Established and emerging genres also had their respective shows, such as MTV Jams for hip-hop, Headbangers Ball for heavy metal, and MTV Alternative Nation for “alternative music.” In contrast to MTV’s global and commercial marketing of international rock stars, music channels such as UNTV and its show In the Raw provided and pioneered alternative venues, other than clubs, for underground bands to express their music, although some bands later achieved commercial success. Francis “Brew” Reyes of rock band The Dawn hosted the TV show and its corresponding radio show on NU 107, featuring demos and sessions of unsigned bands.

 

Early music video performances were TV guestings in the 1980s. Funk band P.O.T’s remake of the Philippine Advisors’ “Yugyugan Na” (Dance Time) was first performed on GMA’s weekly variety show S.O.P. The Eraserheads, before reaching cult status, were regular guests in noontime or variety shows. Most musicians followed this trend of live performances in the late 1990s. Other recorded music videos, including footage of band members performing and, later, incorporating narratives, such as Eraserheads’ “Ang Huling El Bimbo” (The Last El Bimbo), directed by Auraeus Solito, which tells the demise of the romantic tragedy of the paraluman character, the beloved of the protagonist. It won the International Viewer’s Choice Award for Asia at the 1997 MTV Music Video Awards.

 

 

 

Reminiscent of MTV Unplugged that features rock bands rendering their heavy music live with no amplifiers was Wolfgang’s live album Acoustica, 2000, which included a video CD in its package. Official or otherwise, live performances uploaded on YouTube may also qualify as music videos. In the said online platform, Tower of Doom has been uploading episodes of Tower Sessions featuring performing live bands from different music genres. Most “official” music videos, however, show band members in cinematic shots from different camera angles. Others insert fragments to compose stories and invoke collective tributary memories of musical influences such as Rivermaya’s cover of punk band legend The Wuds’s “Inosente Lang ang Nagtataka” (Only the Innocent Wonders) and Kamikazee’s rendition of master rapper Francis M’s “Meron Akong Ano” (I Have What), featuring Ian Tayao of Queso, Chito Miranda of Parokya ni Edgar, and Reg Rubio of Greyhoundz.

 

Some videos reference popular culture. Sandwich’s “Betamax” triggers nostalgia of the 1980s and the 1990s, as suggested by the title. As the song prompts images from these decades when “there was no MTV yet,” the footage shows children playing Filipino street games such as piko (hopscotch) and tumbang preso (knock the can down). While Kiko Machine’s “Takeshi’s Castle” explicitly reminds us of the imported Japanese TV game show, Up Dharma Down’s “Sana” (Hopefully) mishmashes the said show with the Atari video games. Two of Wolfgang’s music videos were soundtracks to video games: “No Falter” for the film adaptation of the Final Fantasy franchise and “Novus Is Burning” for LevelUp!, both of which employ 3D graphics.

 

Beyond recorded footage, some artists push the boundaries of the music video and use animation techniques, such as 3D animation in “Tumatakbo” (Running) by pop rock band Mojofly; stop-motion in Mottaka by metal band Queso, formerly Cheese; stylized vector-like flash animation in “Quick to Panic” by Cebu-based indie band Sheila and the Insects; and rotoscoping in “Dream Systems” by The Purplechickens. Maximizing technological innovations and the Internet to sing about overseas Filipino workers, the 360-degree music video “#GoogleMissKoNa” enables the viewer to “rotate” the camera using arrow buttons on the video interface.

 

Music on television also served as venues for the proliferation and distribution of “novelty songs.” Rapper Abra offers a scathing critique, when his chorus scoffs at popular mass media “not to make a fool out of me” while the video shows him drawing the million-peso prize from a hat, accompanied by upbeat rhythms, similar to those of novelty songs. Sung in Bisaya, the music video “Ako si M16” (I am M16) by Cebu-based reggae band Junior Kilat, aired on national TV initially via UNTV, tells of the arms trade and overspending on guns and violence.

 

Employing chiaroscuro effects to the band members and framing a narrative based on Edgardo M. Reyes’s short fiction “Isang Balutang Pancit” (A Bag of Noodles), The Jerks’s “Rage” sings of the failed promise of democracy under the post-martial law regimes. Besides cinematic shots and local literary roots of the story being told, the words of the chorus “rage against the dying of the light” reference Dylan Thomas’s classic villanelle poem “Do Not Go Gentle into That Good Night,” but the quoted phrase in the lyrics followed by “sing a song against this terrible sight” modifies the originally personal message of Thomas’s poem to the political and social. The song remains relevant until now not just because of its aesthetic influences but also because it contains and critiques social realities. Inspired by rap-metal band Rage Against the Machine, Dicta License’s “Alay sa mga Nagkamalay noong Dekada Nobenta” (An Offering to Those Who Were Enlightened in the 1990s) stresses the call and need to change the grave ills besetting Philippine society.

 

Paying tribute to the martyrs of Hacienda Luisita, the HLMX Trilogy, produced by Luisita Watch and Molotov Pilipinas, tells about the decades-long agrarian reform struggle in the country, as concretely manifested in Hacienda Luisita. Calling to action, the chorus of 5 Year Plan’s “Pagbawi” (To Take Back) calls on the listeners to take the land back; Goons N’ Guns’s “Luisita’s Cry” wails “blood, sweat and tears, Lusita’s been crying for years” with Tagalog verses rapped to contain the chants, ending with the slogan: “tunay na reporma sa lupa ipaglaban” (fight for genuine agrarian reform). In Gazera’s “Kung Puntod na ang mga Bukirin” (When Farms Have Turned into Graves), based on Axel Pinpin’s poem of the same title, the ghosts of the victims come alive, expressed in the articulation that “the land is breathing, demanding for justice,” haunting the despotic landlords who perpetrated their killing. Combining the three videos together is a little girl traversing the sugarcane field, interspersed with real documentary footage of the struggle for land, concluding with raised red flags in the azucarera (sugar refinery).

 

With these variety of themes discussed in music videos on television, Philippine social realities have been and are still being recorded, not just as an appendage of the business ventures of the entertainment industry but also as avenues for the expression of aspirations for a better future and as warning shots of unrest that may be transformed into offensives of collective resistance. Written by Arbeen Tilde Acuña

text:
Music programs revolve around performances of musical pieces offered in segments to form a packaged show. The performance of compositions is through singing, dancing, or instrument playing. Musicals are shows with music as the main element that drives the narrative and dramatic plot forward.

 

Music programs can be variety or magazine shows combined with talk and special features. While often an incongruous mixture of styles and elements characterize most music programs, some have a common theme that weaves the segmented pieces together. The thematic focus can be on an artist, composer, choreographer, genre, period, or trend. Early music programs in the Philippines had live acts with the attendance of studio audiences. The format began to include singing contests. In the 1970s, some singers lip-synched the song performances, but this practice has declined through the years, owing to the requirement of audiences for good, honest performance. Lately, music videos and reality talent shows have become a trend, setting new formats of a music program.

 

Music programs have been mainstays in Philippine broadcast media since it began. Henry Herman’s experimental broadcasts in 1922 featured music and news. Isaac Beck, whose KZIB station began to air in 1925, broadcast Filipino artists and sarsuwela singers in bodabil and radio shows. In a society rooted soundly in strong oral traditions, it is no wonder these shows, which cover variety show musicals, live performances and concert series, singing contests, and personality platter shows, easily captured and continue to arrest the attention of many Filipinos.

 

Many early Philippine music programs were patterned after American formats like the vaudeville, with its mix of cheerful music and comical skits to entertain audiences. It was during this era that Philippine radio popularized such characters as Pugo and Togo, German San Jose and Leonora Reyes, Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan, and Vicente Ocampo and Diana Toy. In the mid-1930s, the rise of blocktimers and blocktime shows augmented the bodabil-type of variety show to feature multiple sponsors and multiple ensembles of performers and radio artists. The format stayed and evolved in Philippine radio until its golden years, the decades from post-World War II until the martial law era, which saw the resurgence of music radio shows after years of taking a backseat to news, commentary, and Japanese anti-American propaganda during World War II.

 

The post-World War II years saw a more distinctly Filipino approach to radio programming and content production in spite of still markedly American influences. With the coming of television, the emergence of the Philippine recording industry, the development of the stereo and, by consequence, the popularization of FM radio transmissions, Philippine media companies began to tap more local artists for recording and distribution of music, resulting in a resurgence of music programs. Through the golden years of Philippine radio, Filipino singers rose to fame, with the 1950s yielding Bimbo Danao, Phil Delfino, Belle Gonzales, and Don David; the 1960s, Pilita Corrales, Sylvia La Torre, RJ Jacinto, and several teenage bands; and the 1970s, Nora Aunor, Basil Valdez, Sharon Cuneta, Hajji Alejandro, Celeste Legaspi, Jose Mari Chan, Ryan Cayabyab, and other artists who formed the so-called Pinoy Rock and Manila Sound anteceding the Original Pilipino Music (OPM) brand in later years. Throughout these periods, the Filipinized bodabil gained much traction, giving birth to derivative formats of the variety show genre in music programs.

 

ABS-CBN launched Jam Session, 1961, a youth-oriented music program starring Bobby Ng and a band called the Hi-Jacks; The Lucky Strike Show, 1963, hosted by Nelda Lopez Navarro; and evening variety shows like Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) and a discotheque program called Nineteeners, both in 1966. Asia’s Queen of Song Pilita Corrales, known for her renditions of Visayan ballads, began hosting the weekly An Evening with Pilita, 1965-72, Channel 3. The show was known for flamboyant and dynamic Filipino-inspired song-and-dance numbers. At the same time, Helen of Song, hosted by Helen Gamboa, and Carmen on Camera, which featured Carmen Soriano, vied for audience shares on ABC RTV Channel 5 and RBS TV Channel 7, respectively. Celeste Legaspi hosted and performed in the music programs At Long Last Celeste, 1975, and Iba’t Ibang Celeste (Many Sides of Celeste), 1976.

 

Dance Time with Chito, 1961-64, RBS TV DZBB Channel 7, a late-night dance program broadcast live from a spartan studio, became the mold for later dance programs on television. Competing with the show were DJ Dance Time and The Nite Owl Dance Party, both on MBC TV Channel 11. Catch Up with Tirso, 1970, Channel 11, a song-and-dance show, featured the then-ascending popularity of teen movie idol Tirso Cruz III. Nora Aunor thrilled her fans with the weekly musical show Superstar, 1971-89, RPN 9.

 

The musical opera show Sunday, Sweet Sunday, 1966-74, Channel 13, broadcast performances of excerpted operettas, Broadway musicals, and classical kundiman (love songs) by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio and Jimmy Melendrez, in televised adaptations of Arthurian romances and Shakespearean dramas. It went off the air when martial law was declared in 1972, and was replaced by Zing, 1972-73, KBS Channel 9, also with the same hosts. When Zing ended its run in 1973, the two hosts revived Sunday, Sweet Sunday, 1973-74, also on Channel 13. The show was later repackaged in A Little Night of Music, 1989-2001, GMA, to reintroduce its more classical selections to the new generation.

 

Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), 1970-2005, was a music TV show hosted by Armida Siguion-Reyna that ran on several channels: RPN 9, ABS-CBN, IBC 13, and ABC 5. It drew its appeal from a soundly Filipino-anchored selection of music, with revivals of old folks songs, lullabies, kundiman, harana (serenade), and balitaw (courtship song); and costumed singers in traditional garb singing in rural and historical settings. Composers Restie Umali and Levi Celerio wrote, updated, and revived almost 300 pieces for the show throughout its long run. The show earned Armida Siguion-Reyna her title as the Reyna ng Kundiman (Queen of the Kundiman).

 

It was Aawitan Kita that produced what is properly called the television musical through some episodes that were one-and-a-half-hour docu-dramas that explored significant aspects of the history of the Philippines. Examples of these musicals in the 1970s were “Sisa,” “Pagpatak ng Ulan” (When the Rain Drops), “Ang Lakambini at ang Supremo” (The Muse and the Supreme Chief), and “Dung-aw” (Lament). Aawitan Kita also mounted sarsuwela on television, like “Ang Binhi” (The Seedling), “Sayang” (Lost Opportunity), “Ang Nazareno” (The Nazarene), and Amado Hernandez’s “Ulo ng Lechon” (Head of the Roasted Pig).

 

Kuh Ledesma produced a television program called Kuh by Special Arrangement, IBC 13, that won the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon, 1986 and 1987. Ryan Cayabyab’s weekly music show Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music with Ryan), ABS-CBN, had a long run from 1988 to 1995. 100">Bert Nievera hosted Chairman of the Board, 1992, IBC 13. Sharon Cuneta, first known for “Mr. DJ” which landed her on the hit charts in 1978, had a long career in television music shows, with her first music variety show, The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1986-88, IBC 13, and then 1988-97, ABS-CBN. Her second, Sharon, ran from 1998 to 2010, ABS-CBN, before it ended to give room for her to host Star Power, a talent show, with Christian Bautista and Erik Santos. Her third, Sharon: Kasama Mo, Kapatid (Sharon: With You, My Sibling), ran for eight months in 2012 on TV5 when she transferred networks. In 2013, she co-hosted The Mega and the Songwriter, a music variety talk show, with Ogie Alcasid.

 

Concert series, from radio coverage to television broadcast, also retained its presence as a familiar music show format. In 1939, when the radio station KZRH was inaugurated, it had a dominantly Western programming that highlighted American music, such as jazz, blues, and swing, to package the promotion of American English to the masses. Wave 98.1 became the go-to station for easy listening rhythm and blues.

article.value: Music programs revolve around performances of musical pieces offered in segments to form a packaged show. The performance of compositions is through singing, dancing, or instrument playing. Musicals are shows with music as the main element that drives the narrative and dramatic plot forward.

Music programs can be variety or magazine shows combined with talk and special features. While often an incongruous mixture of styles and elements characterize most music programs, some have a common theme that weaves the segmented pieces together. The thematic focus can be on an artist, composer, choreographer, genre, period, or trend. Early music programs in the Philippines had live acts with the attendance of studio audiences. The format began to include singing contests. In the 1970s, some singers lip-synched the song performances, but this practice has declined through the years, owing to the requirement of audiences for good, honest performance. Lately, music videos and reality talent shows have become a trend, setting new formats of a music program.

article.value: Music programs have been mainstays in Philippine broadcast media since it began. Henry Herman’s experimental broadcasts in 1922 featured music and news. Isaac Beck, whose KZIB station began to air in 1925, broadcast Filipino artists and sarsuwela singers in bodabil and radio shows. In a society rooted soundly in strong oral traditions, it is no wonder these shows, which cover variety show musicals, live performances and concert series, singing contests, and personality platter shows, easily captured and continue to arrest the attention of many Filipinos.

Many early Philippine music programs were patterned after American formats like the vaudeville, with its mix of cheerful music and comical skits to entertain audiences. It was during this era that Philippine radio popularized such characters as Pugo and Togo, German San Jose and Leonora Reyes, Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan, and Vicente Ocampo and Diana Toy. In the mid-1930s, the rise of blocktimers and blocktime shows augmented the bodabil-type of variety show to feature multiple sponsors and multiple ensembles of performers and radio artists. The format stayed and evolved in Philippine radio until its golden years, the decades from post-World War II until the martial law era, which saw the resurgence of music radio shows after years of taking a backseat to news, commentary, and Japanese anti-American propaganda during World War II.

The post-World War II years saw a more distinctly Filipino approach to radio programming and content production in spite of still markedly American influences. With the coming of television, the emergence of the Philippine recording industry, the development of the stereo and, by consequence, the popularization of FM radio transmissions, Philippine media companies began to tap more local artists for recording and distribution of music, resulting in a resurgence of music programs. Through the golden years of Philippine radio, Filipino singers rose to fame, with the 1950s yielding Bimbo Danao, Phil Delfino, Belle Gonzales, and Don David; the 1960s, Pilita Corrales, Sylvia La Torre, RJ Jacinto, and several teenage bands; and the 1970s, Nora Aunor, Basil Valdez, Sharon Cuneta, Hajji Alejandro, Celeste Legaspi, Jose Mari Chan, Ryan Cayabyab, and other artists who formed the so-called Pinoy Rock and Manila Sound anteceding the Original Pilipino Music (OPM) brand in later years. Throughout these periods, the Filipinized bodabil gained much traction, giving birth to derivative formats of the variety show genre in music programs.

ABS-CBN launched Jam Session, 1961, a youth-oriented music program starring Bobby Ng and a band called the Hi-Jacks; The Lucky Strike Show, 1963, hosted by Nelda Lopez Navarro; and evening variety shows like Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) and a discotheque program called Nineteeners, both in 1966. Asia’s Queen of Song Pilita Corrales, known for her renditions of Visayan ballads, began hosting the weekly An Evening with Pilita, 1965-72, Channel 3. The show was later repackaged in A Little Night of Music, 1989-2001, GMA, to reintroduce its more classical selections to the new generation.

Composers Restie Umali and Levi Celerio wrote, updated, and revived almost 300 pieces for the show throughout its long run. The show earned Armida Siguion-Reyna her title as the Reyna ng Kundiman (Queen of the Kundiman).

Kuh Ledesma produced a television program called Kuh by Special Arrangement, IBC 13, that won the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon, 1986 and 1987. Ryan Cayabyab’s weekly music show Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music with Ryan), ABS-CBN, had a long run from 1988 to 1995. 100">Bert Nievera hosted Chairman of the Board, 1992, IBC 13. Sharon Cuneta, first known for “Mr. DJ” which landed her on the hit charts in 1978, had a long career in television music shows, with her first music variety show, The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1986-88, IBC 13, and then 1988-97, ABS-CBN. Her third, Sharon: Kasama Mo, Kapatid (Sharon: With You, My Sibling), ran for eight months in 2012 on TV5 when she transferred networks. In 2013, she co-hosted The Mega and the Songwriter, a music variety talk show, with Ogie Alcasid.

text:
News programs are newscasts about current events, which are presented in segments of stories presented by one or more anchors in a studio or newsroom, or from the field. A story is either broadcast live or prerecorded from the field by a reporter. For radio, the anchor reads the entire story, or introduces the story that is followed by a field reporter’s narration of the event, which is either prerecorded or covered live from the field. For television, the anchor provides the lead of the story, followed by a reporter’s coverage of the news. The reporter’s presentation often includes a voice-over narration, video and audio clips, animated or digital images and graphics, and brief sound bites of interviews. Lately, sound effects or music accompanies the presentation of the news, and some news programs have short editorials.

 

The history of Philippine broadcast news can be traced along two lines: the political and the economic. The Philippine press, including broadcast, is often cited the freest in Asia. Broadcast stations at various stages in the country’s history have suffered repression from the state, and in turn have checked the abuses of the state through reports that have had significant impact on nation-building. Yet, in the economic sense, broadcast news in the country faces significant restrictions, which stem from the nature of their ownership: broadcast networks are owned by entrepreneurs who have business interests elsewhere and who consider news a commodity, subject to the contest for ratings and profit.

 

Newscasts in the 1920s were El Conde de Guell and Sunkist News, both on KZRM, which were sponsored by brands of cigars and a juice drink, and Palmolive Newsreel of the Air, DZIB, sponsored by a brand of bath soap. The best announcers of the period were Americans; Filipinos broke into newscasting only in 1934. Among the first announcers were Ira Davis, Vero Perfecto, Norman Reyes, Leon Ma. Guerrero III, and Koko Trinidad, who was the first Filipino to be given an English newscasting assignment on KZRM. Newscasts in Spanish were read by local Spaniards, among them Conchita Garriz. Newscasts in the Visayas were trilingual. On KZRC in Cebu, Jose del Mar and Gaudencio Peña read the news in Spanish while Jose Bautista announced the news in Cebuano, and American Harry Fenton read the news in English (Alburo 1997; History of Philippine Radio Stations 1979). Radio stations started producing radio commentaries. While many Filipino announcers spoke like American newscasters, Tagalog was slowly gaining its entry into broadcast. By 1940, most of KZIB’s programs were in Tagalog, and KZRF had News in Tagalog (Broadcast Media Development Program, n.d.; Jimenez 1996; Lent 1973; Trinidad 2000; Reuter 2001). Some news were dramatized, particularly the weekly news summaries of the early 1940s, with Trinidad and Lamberto Avellana impersonating the voices of important political personalities from around the world. Regular news programs, however, were brief and comprised only five percent of programming.

 

With war looming on the horizon, news programs on all radio stations increased in length and frequency. News programs were closely monitored by the American colonial administration to check the loyalty of the Filipinos. The government put up KZND for its own newscasts and announcements. On 5 Jan 1942, the station Voice of Freedom, so named by Gen Douglas MacArthur, went on the air with the program of the same name, Voice of Freedom, which broadcast nightly at 6:00, on varying frequencies to elude interference. Romulo, Guerrero, and Salvador P. Lopez wrote the news and commentary in English which Romulo, Guerrero, and Norman Reyes took turns reading on the air (Reyes 1995). The English newscast and commentary were followed by the program Tinig ng Kalayaan—Tagalog for voice of freedom—voiced by Philippine Army Lieutenant Francisco Isidoro, who translated the English scripts to Tagalog and delivered them on the air. These news broadcasts did not last because Japanese forces advanced toward Manila. The surrender of Corregidor silenced the Voice of Freedom. In early May 1942, the Voice of Juan de la Cruz went on the air. It was the voice of 18-year-old Carlos Malonzo, broadcasting comments about events happening in Manila. The program lasted for two months. The Japanese cornered and executed him, but his wife, Violet Brown, carried on the broadcast for another two months.

 

Broadcast news during the Japanese occupation was mainly overt propaganda through endless lectures and political speeches. The Japanese-captured KZRH, later renamed PIAM, broadcast announcements from the Japanese Military Administration. Newscasts in English, Tagalog, and Spanish of 15 minutes each were aired three times a day. Eventually, the news was also regularly read in Nihongo. Broadcasters of the Japanese-controlled radio station were Filipinos, among whom were, ironically, KZND station manager Vero Perfecto and Voice of Freedom news writer, commentator, and announcer Leon Ma. Guerrero III. KGEI was a critical source of news from the United States, with Filipinos on its staff translating and reading the news in English to Tagalog, Ibanag, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Pampango, Bikol, Hiligaynon, Cebuano, and Moro. Indeed, radio news immediately before World War II and during the Japanese occupation was a tug of war between American forces and Japanese troops.

 

Post-World War II broadcast news was a mix of politics and economics. The amount of airtime dedicated to news programs increased. There was more coverage of live news events and commentary. These developments were partly helped by advances in broadcast technology, but were also provoked by opposing political forces that increasingly used broadcasting for political gain.

Most remembered commentators of the 1960s were Rafael Yabut, in his early morning program Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw (Wake Up at the Break of Dawn), DZRH, and Damian Sotto, in Mangatwiran Ka (Reason Out), DZAQ; both were critics of organized religion and government corruption. Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio) of ABS-CBN’s DZAQ would become the model for news reporting on radio and would produce the likes of Orly Mercado, Barr Samson, Rey Langit, Emmy Arcilla, Joe Taruc, and Bobby Guanzon. Robert Stewart editorialized the late evening news in The News with Uncle Bob on RBS-TV. The leading news television program of its time was The Big News, beginning in 1962, ABC Channel 5, with Duds Rivera and Bong Lapira, who would be replaced by Jose Mari Velez. In 1970, KBS-TV launched Newswatch, with Harry Gasser as main anchor.

 

When Marcos placed the country under martial rule in 1972, the media was among the first to be silenced, literally in the case of radio and television. The first of the regular evening television news programs to go on the air was the government-produced The DPI Reports. News programs included NewsWatch, KBS-RPN; News at Seven, RBS-GMA; Newsday, IBC 13; Newscenter 4 and News Today, both on GTV 4; and BBC Balita (BBC News), Channel 2, the first primetime news program in Filipino after martial law was declared. Broadcast news programs during martial law were monitored and censored. The networks kept silent about the many inconvenient truths about the Marcos dictatorship. All news about the activities of the political opposition was absolutely forbidden on the air. An interesting development, however, was the entry of women into broadcast news.

 

The character of broadcast news radically changed in the aftermath of the assassination of Sen Benigno Aquino Jr on 21 Aug 1983. Events chanced upon each other in rapid succession that led to the EDSA Revolt in Feb 1986 which unceremoniously ousted the government of Marcos. The revolt was kindled by Radyo Bandido (Bandit Radio), the clandestine program of June Keithley who called on the people, via Radio Veritas and DZRJ, supported by the voice of Jaime Cardinal Sin on the airwaves, to rally behind a group of the military that turned its back on Marcos. The news on radio and television, both from the government and the mutineers, tugged on the hearts and minds of the Filipinos. Contending political forces competed in controlling the airwaves, with the people participating in the reality of the visuals and the sounds of the fury of the times.

 

News became the most valued program after the 1986 EDSA Revolt. The restoration of freedom and democracy emboldened AM radio stations to strengthen their news programming. Filipino became the language of television news, spearheaded in 1987 by TV Patrol, ABS-CBN. Interestingly, however, broadcast companies started sending their journalists to do war and disaster coverage all over the globe.
