article.value: News programs are newscasts about current events, which are presented in segments of stories presented by one or more anchors in a studio or newsroom, or from the field. A story is either broadcast live or prerecorded from the field by a reporter. For radio, the anchor reads the entire story, or introduces the story that is followed by a field reporter’s narration of the event, which is either prerecorded or covered live from the field. For television, the anchor provides the lead of the story, followed by a reporter’s coverage of the news. The reporter’s presentation often includes a voice-over narration, video and audio clips, animated or digital images and graphics, and brief sound bites of interviews. Lately, sound effects or music accompanies the presentation of the news, and some news programs have short editorials.

The history of Philippine broadcast news can be traced along two lines: the political and the economic. The Philippine press, including broadcast, is often cited the freest in Asia. Broadcast stations at various stages in the country’s history have suffered repression from the state, and in turn have checked the abuses of the state through reports that have had significant impact on nation-building. Yet, in the economic sense, broadcast news in the country faces significant restrictions, which stem from the nature of their ownership: broadcast networks are owned by entrepreneurs who have business interests elsewhere and who consider news a commodity, subject to the contest for ratings and profit.

Newscasts in the 1920s were El Conde de Guell and Sunkist News, both on KZRM, which were sponsored by brands of cigars and a juice drink, and Palmolive Newsreel of the Air, DZIB, sponsored by a brand of bath soap. The best announcers of the period were Americans; Filipinos broke into newscasting only in 1934. Among the first announcers were Ira Davis, Vero Perfecto, Norman Reyes, Leon Ma. Guerrero III, and Koko Trinidad, who was the first Filipino to be given an English newscasting assignment on KZRM. Newscasts in Spanish were read by local Spaniards, among them Conchita Garriz. Newscasts in the Visayas were trilingual. On KZRC in Cebu, Jose del Mar and Gaudencio Peña read the news in Spanish while Jose Bautista announced the news in Cebuano, and American Harry Fenton read the news in English (Alburo 1997; History of Philippine Radio Stations 1979). Radio stations started producing radio commentaries. While many Filipino announcers spoke like American newscasters, Tagalog was slowly gaining its entry into broadcast. By 1940, most of KZIB’s programs were in Tagalog, and KZRF had News in Tagalog (Broadcast Media Development Program, n.d.; Jimenez 1996; Lent 1973; Trinidad 2000; Reuter 2001). Some news were dramatized, particularly the weekly news summaries of the early 1940s, with Trinidad and Lamberto Avellana impersonating the voices of important political personalities from around the world. Regular news programs, however, were brief and comprised only five percent of programming.

With war looming on the horizon, news programs on all radio stations increased in length and frequency. News programs were closely monitored by the American colonial administration to check the loyalty of the Filipinos. The government put up KZND for its own newscasts and announcements. On 5 Jan 1942, the station Voice of Freedom, so named by Gen Douglas MacArthur, went on the air with the program of the same name, Voice of Freedom, which broadcast nightly at 6:00, on varying frequencies to elude interference. Romulo, Guerrero, and Salvador P. Lopez wrote the news and commentary in English which Romulo, Guerrero, and Norman Reyes took turns reading on the air (Reyes 1995). The English newscast and commentary were followed by the program Tinig ng Kalayaan—Tagalog for voice of freedom—voiced by Philippine Army Lieutenant Francisco Isidoro, who translated the English scripts to Tagalog and delivered them on the air. These news broadcasts did not last because Japanese forces advanced toward Manila. The surrender of Corregidor silenced the Voice of Freedom. In early May 1942, the Voice of Juan de la Cruz went on the air. It was the voice of 18-year-old Carlos Malonzo, broadcasting comments about events happening in Manila. The program lasted for two months. The Japanese cornered and executed him, but his wife, Violet Brown, carried on the broadcast for another two months.

Broadcast news during the Japanese occupation was mainly overt propaganda through endless lectures and political speeches. The Japanese-captured KZRH, later renamed PIAM, broadcast announcements from the Japanese Military Administration. Newscasts in English, Tagalog, and Spanish of 15 minutes each were aired three times a day. Eventually, the news was also regularly read in Nihongo. Broadcasters of the Japanese-controlled radio station were Filipinos, among whom were, ironically, KZND station manager Vero Perfecto and Voice of Freedom news writer, commentator, and announcer Leon Ma. Guerrero III. KGEI was a critical source of news from the United States, with Filipinos on its staff translating and reading the news in English to Tagalog, Ibanag, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Pampango, Bikol, Hiligaynon, Cebuano, and Moro. Indeed, radio news immediately before World War II and during the Japanese occupation was a tug of war between American forces and Japanese troops.

Post-World War II broadcast news was a mix of politics and economics. The amount of airtime dedicated to news programs increased. There was more coverage of live news events and commentary. These developments were partly helped by advances in broadcast technology, but were also provoked by opposing political forces that increasingly used broadcasting for political gain.

Most remembered commentators of the 1960s were Rafael Yabut, in his early morning program Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw (Wake Up at the Break of Dawn), DZRH, and Damian Sotto, in Mangatwiran Ka (Reason Out), DZAQ; both were critics of organized religion and government corruption. Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio) of ABS-CBN’s DZAQ would become the model for news reporting on radio and would produce the likes of Orly Mercado, Barr Samson, Rey Langit, Emmy Arcilla, Joe Taruc, and Bobby Guanzon. Robert Stewart editorialized the late evening news in The News with Uncle Bob on RBS-TV. The leading news television program of its time was The Big News, beginning in 1962, ABC Channel 5, with Duds Rivera and Bong Lapira, who would be replaced by Jose Mari Velez. In 1970, KBS-TV launched Newswatch, with Harry Gasser as main anchor.

When Marcos placed the country under martial rule in 1972, the media was among the first to be silenced, literally in the case of radio and television. Broadcast news programs during martial law were monitored and censored. The networks kept silent about the many inconvenient truths about the Marcos dictatorship. All news about the activities of the political opposition was absolutely forbidden on the air. An interesting development, however, was the entry of women into broadcast news.

Events chanced upon each other in rapid succession that led to the EDSA Revolt in Feb 1986 which unceremoniously ousted the government of Marcos. The revolt was kindled by Radyo Bandido (Bandit Radio), the clandestine program of June Keithley who called on the people, via Radio Veritas and DZRJ, supported by the voice of Jaime Cardinal Sin on the airwaves, to rally behind a group of the military that turned its back on Marcos. The news on radio and television, both from the government and the mutineers, tugged on the hearts and minds of the Filipinos. Contending political forces competed in controlling the airwaves, with the people participating in the reality of the visuals and the sounds of the fury of the times.

News programming was highly marked by what critics would call the tabloidization of news that skewed the content, format, and style of reporting toward entertainment and sensationalism, all in the rush to capture a wider audience reach and increase ratings and profits. Interestingly, however, broadcast companies started sending their journalists to do war and disaster coverage all over the globe. A remarkable development was the live coverage of impeachment trials of the country’s leaders and legislative hearings on the scandalous corruption perpetrated by government officials. text:
Reality television or reality TV encompasses various types of television programs that are framed to capture real people and their behavior within a naturally unfolding situation or a producer-contrived scenario. The genre is characterized by the presence of individuals acting as themselves, the use of surveillance or observational footage, and the use of unscripted dialogue (Vinculado 2007).

 

Reality programs in the Philippines were first employed on radio, the earliest of which was in the 1950s with Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks) on DZRH, sponsored by Vicks Vaporub vaporizing ointment, and patterned after the American radio program Queen for a Day. It featured five women candidates called “reyna” (queens), who are each interviewed to share their individual experiences. The one who earns the loudest applause is adjudged the “reyna” (Aniceto 1945).

 

During the early days of reality programming’s inception on Philippine television, its presence consisted primarily in the deployment and integration of its conventions in different television genres, resulting in hybrid shows. Several television shows during the 1990s included segments that contain elements of reality programming. The country’s longest-running gag show Wow Mali (Oh No, It’s a Mistake), 1996-2006, 2009-15, ABC/TV5, conceptualized by host-comedian Joey de Leon, involves a roving crew playing and documenting practical jokes on real people on the streets, with the humor aspect generated by the spontaneous reactions and responses of the prank victims.

 

At the beginning of the new millennium, some television shows resorted to assimilating the conventions of reality-based programming to gain ground in the ratings war. For instance, the lifestyle show Extra, Extra was reformatted to Extra Challenge, 1999-2006, GMA Network, a reality-based show inspired by American reality-based challenge competitions that featured celebrities pitted against one another in a weeklong series of challenges ranging from extreme sports to immersion in the lives of ordinary citizens. Click, 1997, GMA, a youth-oriented afternoon television series, briefly ran a promotional reality game show, in which the teen cast competed against one another in a series of island challenges. Television talk shows and noontime variety shows also included occasional reality-based challenge segments that involved celebrity guests participating in studio games, or accomplishing a series of challenges in different outdoor locations.

 

The 2000s has been marked by the massive importation and localization of various foreign reality television franchises that range from reality-based challenge series to talent searches. Among these television imports are Pinoy Big Brother (Filipino Big Brother), which premiered in 2002 on ABS-CBN, arguably the most sensational among the reality-based franchises, which features participants living together in a house subjected to perpetual surveillance for the duration of the show while accomplishing different challenges contrived by the unseen game master “Kuya” (Big Brother); the reality game show cum social experiment, and the talent-search Pinoy Dream Academy, 1996, ABS-CBN, which combines the format of Big Brother and reality-based singing competitions by confining the contestants in a monitored house, as they battle against one another in a series of singing challenges; Philippine Idol, 2006, ABC 5, a reality-based singing competition patterned after the successful American Idol franchise, which follows the journey of hopefuls from the audition phase to their live performances; and Survivor Philippines, 2008-12, GMA, a competitive survival challenge that gathers celebrities in an isolated tropical island bereft of any luxuries of modern living. These reality television shows have also served as springboards for the careers of celebrity hopefuls, as eventually the winners and even finalists pursue successful show business careers after signing contracts with the respective networks that released these franchises.

 

Visibly influenced by the global successes of international reality television franchises, as well as by the palpable enthusiasm of local audiences for the genre, local television networks have created original reality television shows. Locally created “artista searches” (talent searches) Starstruck, 2003, GMA, and Star Circle Quest, 2004, ABS-CBN, follow the journey of youth participants aspiring to enter show business in a series of auditions and workshops. Another reality show, 30 Days, launched in 2004, GMA, features former television and film actors and actresses aspiring to revive their careers as they are pitted against one another in a series of challenges intended to determine who among them is the worthiest to gain a second chance in the show business. Born Diva, 2004, ABS-CBN, integrates the conventions of a singing competition with an actual documentation of the cosmetic transformation of female contestants. In what can be construed as an effort to invite the sympathy of viewers, local reality-based talent searches noticeably integrate documentary modes to foreground the dramatic life stories of the participants (Sanico and Papa 2006). Another observable element in these local reality-based competitions is that, similar to their foreign counterparts, they forward the impression of a high level of interactive participation from the viewers, as television audiences decide who leaves, stays in, and eventually wins the competition by casting votes through telecommunication channels.

 

Various local reality-based challenge shows were also produced in recent years. The paranormal reality show Philippine Scariest Challenge, 2008, TV5, highlighted celebrity contestants accomplishing a set of challenges in a haunted location. Sports-related challenges are showcased in programs like Pinoy Mano Mano: Celebrity Boxing Challenge (Filipino Hand to Hand: Celebrity Boxing Challenge), 2007, ABS-CBN, and the long-running lifestyle-reality show Sports Unlimited, 1997-2015, ABS-CBN. Integrating reality-based challenges with the conventions of a wish-granting show, Day Off, 2005, QTV-11, features celebrities taking on the occupational duties of selected individuals, who are then luxuriously treated to a single-day vacation leave.

 

News and public affairs programs have also been formatted to appropriate the conventions of reality television. Investigative shows like Isumbong Mo Kay Tulfo (Report It to Tulfo), 1993-2006, RPN 9, make use of hidden cameras, a questionable practice, to catch offenders in the act of committing crimes during entrapment operations, as well as to document the arrest procedures of law enforcement authorities. GMA Network’s Imbestigador (Investigator), an investigative show that began in 2000 and hosted by Mike Enriquez, documented (through the use of hidden cameras) illegal activities both in private and public offices, and the entrapment operations conducted by authorities. In 2010, GMA Network launched Rescue, hosted by Arnold Clavio, a reality-documentary program that featured actual footage of rescue operations conducted by authorities and civilians in response to accidents, calamities, and crimes. Another public affairs program is Face to Face, 2014, TV5, dubbed the “Barangay Hall On-Air,” which invites disputing individuals on studio to settle their personal arguments with the help of the show’s resident counselors. Elements of reality television can likewise be gleaned in the inclusion of closed-circuit television (CCTV) footage, as well as in the presence of civilian newscasters in news programs, as in the case of the CCTV Patrol and Citizen Patrol segments in ABS-CBN’s TV Patrol. These elements somehow heighten the impression of increased public participation in the accomplishment of the mass media industry’s mandate as purveyors of socially relevant information and avenue for the articulation of mass grievances.

 

Reality television series have also been developed to document the lives of local celebrities, particularly highlighting aspects of their lives previously unexposed to the public eye. Melason, 2010, ABS-CBN, dubbed as the first spin-off to Pinoy Big Brother (PBB), documented the lives of real-life couple and former PBB contestants Melai Cantiveros and Jason Francisco, as they face the pressures that go with their newfound fame and the challenges it brings to their relationship. It Takes Gutz to Be a Gutierrez, 2014, TV5, focuses on the lives of the members of one of the biggest celebrity families in the local show business, following them in their domestic and career engagements.

 

Reality television brings forth difficult questions concerning the blurring of the line between public and private spheres. In addition to this, even the genre’s claim to reality remains an open sphere for interrogation, since the mediating dynamics that go into the processes of television production bring into the picture how a specific reality television program uneasily navigates the tension between authenticity and artificiality. Programs that bear elements of reality programming have also received accusations of exploitation and sensationalism. For instance, Pinoy Big Brother has faced controversies and was censured by the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board, the government regulatory board, for airing intimate scenes that “violate public norms of taste and decency.” Nevertheless the consistently vigorous response of television viewers to this mode of programming, along with the widened accessibility to technologies that allow users to document and upload virtual captures of actual events in real time, implies that reality television—or at least, its conventions—will remain an enduring presence in the local media landscape. Written by Laurence Marvin S. Castillo with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

 

Sources

Aniceto 2007; Sanico and Papa 2006; Vinculado 2007.

text:
SPORTS BROADCASTING

 

Philippine sports broadcasting has been rooted in two realities: what sports might appeal to a large audience and which technical capabilities are available at a given phase in the development of broadcasting in the country.

 

Basketball has been the uncontested most popular sport in the country following the success of Philippine national teams in the 1936 Berlin Olympics where the Philippines placed fifth, the 1954 Rio de Janeiro World Championships where the Philippine team placed third, and a string of Asian titles. As such, basketball games, like those of the popular National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and the Manila Industrial and Commercial Association (MICAA) were followed avidly on radio. Long before television provided audiovisual sports, the acknowledged “Father of Philippine Sportscasting” Willie Hernandez was painting colorful sports theater of the mind on radio. Hernandez is remembered for his frenetic delivery at machine-gun speed that kept listeners glued to their radio sets. He also had the ability of giving basketball idols fitting monikers like “The Big Difference” for Caloy Loyzaga, the “Big J” for Robert Jaworski, and countless others.

 

 

In time, television developed outside-broadcast capabilities, and the MICAA and collegiate games would soon be covered by ABS-CBN. The network also pioneered in the comprehensive coverage of the 1968 Mexico Olympics. Whereas before fans had to wait for days to watch an international event, satellite broadcasting enabled more recent and subsequently live viewing of games.

 

The martial law era changed the parameters of sports in the 1970s and 1980s as new broadcasters and sports leagues and heroes emerged. The government station GTV-4, later Maharlika Broadcasting System (MBS), featured weekend coverage of international and local events with emphasis on building up new sports stars like trackster Lydia de Vega. MBS also spearheaded comprehensive coverage of Philippine athletes in international competitions, like the Southeast Asian Games and the Asian Games.

 

In 1975, the professional Philippine Basketball Association (PBA) was formed. Its nearly five-hour thrice-weekly live broadcasts were for a long time the uncontested ratings winner. The fiery Crispa-Toyota rivalry would keep fans glued to their TV screens for close to seven years until the teams disbanded. Both teams had the most popular, if not the most talented, players who attracted audiences of varied ages. The PBA extended its dominant ratings posture into the 1980s and 1990s with the rise of a new breed of basketball stars and teams to support. With the advent of cable television in the 1990s, however, its live dose of the USA’s National Basketball Association (NBA) games, and the rise of alternative media platforms and genres, the PBA was faced with viable competition.

 

 

Simply called PBA, it is still the longest running sports program on Philippine TV. Various production houses and networks have taken turns in producing the games for television. Dick Ildefonso and Emy Arcilla were the two pioneering broadcasters followed by the team of the production company Vintage that included Joe Cantada, Pinggoy Pengson, Sev Sarmenta, Ed Picson, Bill Velasco, Jun Bernardino, Chino Trinidad, and Romy Kintanar. The game analyst soon became part of Philippine sportscasting, graduating from being merely a “color man” providing trivia and information tidbits to actually dissecting games. The early analysts included Andy Jao, Steve Kattan, Quinito Henson, and Joaqui Trillo. Cantada brought the most experience to the Vintage team, having covered Anthony Villanueva’s silver medal finish in the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, the summer bikathon Tour of Luzon, and countless championship boxing bouts.

 

College basketball also competed for audience attention when it was shown more extensively on TV. The University Athletic Association of the Philippines games got more regular coverage beginning in the 1990s produced by Silverstar Sports. Jimmy Javier and Trillo formed a popular broadcast team that college students identified with. The NCAA soon followed with Vintage while ABS-CBN tried their hand in presenting college sports.

 

Other trends emerged in the sports broadcast scene in the succeeding years. First, more sports events were covered live. Dedicated satellite coverage of the Olympics was initiated by government station PTV, starting with the 1996 Atlanta games. The games were on air 24 hours a day, with live telecasts of major events aired in the early morning hours and then generously replayed within the primetime hours. In time, Solar Sports, a broadcast blocktimer, dominated the airwaves with its NBA games shown on the cable channel Basketball TV. It also had its own Solar Sports network, a repository of various international and local events.

 

 

Billiards also made inroads as Efren “Bata” Reyes, Django Bustamante, and other cue masters made names in the international scene. Most Filipinos identified with the success of Reyes and company, and the billiards table seemed as permanent a fixture as a basketball court in barangays all over the country.

 

Manny Pacquiao began conquering the boxing world and each of his fights was a major television event. From almost a reed-thin youngster to a boxing star, the country witnessed the victories of Pacquiao first on the weekly boxing show Blow by Blow and then in fights beamed live from Las Vegas. ABS-CBN, and later GMA, carried free telecasts while live, commercial-free viewing was done via cable pay-per-view or in select cinemas.

 

Lastly, volleyball made a slow but endearing connection with viewers. The fast-paced matches soon had heroines such as in the Shakey’s V-League. The league was presented regularly on television. The support of social media, where fans could connect to players and teams, was a major factor for its success.

 

Magazine format sports shows also began to emerge in Philippine TV after the martial law era. Sports Unlimited hosted by Dyan Castillejo, a former tennis star, was among the pioneers in the genre. There were also Game Plan from Probe Productions; Hardball, a sports talk show on ABS-CBN; CNN Sports Desk; and other nightly sports roundups on PTV 4 and the ABS-CBN Sports Channel. Written by Severino R. Sarmenta Jr.

article.value: SPORTS BROADCASTING

Philippine sports broadcasting has been rooted in two realities: what sports might appeal to a large audience and which technical capabilities are available at a given phase in the development of broadcasting in the country.

Basketball has been the uncontested most popular sport in the country following the success of Philippine national teams in the 1936 Berlin Olympics where the Philippines placed fifth, the 1954 Rio de Janeiro World Championships where the Philippine team placed third, and a string of Asian titles. As such, basketball games, like those of the popular National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and the Manila Industrial and Commercial Association (MICAA) were followed avidly on radio. Long before television provided audiovisual sports, the acknowledged “Father of Philippine Sportscasting” Willie Hernandez was painting colorful sports theater of the mind on radio. Hernandez is remembered for his frenetic delivery at machine-gun speed that kept listeners glued to their radio sets. He also had the ability of giving basketball idols fitting monikers like “The Big Difference” for Caloy Loyzaga, the “Big J” for Robert Jaworski, and countless others.

article.value: In time, television developed outside-broadcast capabilities, and the MICAA and collegiate games would soon be covered by ABS-CBN. The network also pioneered in the comprehensive coverage of the 1968 Mexico Olympics. Whereas before fans had to wait for days to watch an international event, satellite broadcasting enabled more recent and subsequently live viewing of games.

The martial law era changed the parameters of sports in the 1970s and 1980s as new broadcasters and sports leagues and heroes emerged. The government station GTV-4, later Maharlika Broadcasting System (MBS), featured weekend coverage of international and local events with emphasis on building up new sports stars like trackster Lydia de Vega. MBS also spearheaded comprehensive coverage of Philippine athletes in international competitions, like the Southeast Asian Games and the Asian Games.

In 1975, the professional Philippine Basketball Association (PBA) was formed. Its nearly five-hour thrice-weekly live broadcasts were for a long time the uncontested ratings winner. The fiery Crispa-Toyota rivalry would keep fans glued to their TV screens for close to seven years until the teams disbanded. Both teams had the most popular, if not the most talented, players who attracted audiences of varied ages. The PBA extended its dominant ratings posture into the 1980s and 1990s with the rise of a new breed of basketball stars and teams to support. With the advent of cable television in the 1990s, however, its live dose of the USA’s National Basketball Association (NBA) games, and the rise of alternative media platforms and genres, the PBA was faced with viable competition.

article.value: Simply called PBA, it is still the longest running sports program on Philippine TV. Various production houses and networks have taken turns in producing the games for television. Dick Ildefonso and Emy Arcilla were the two pioneering broadcasters followed by the team of the production company Vintage that included Joe Cantada, Pinggoy Pengson, Sev Sarmenta, Ed Picson, Bill Velasco, Jun Bernardino, Chino Trinidad, and Romy Kintanar. The game analyst soon became part of Philippine sportscasting, graduating from being merely a “color man” providing trivia and information tidbits to actually dissecting games. The early analysts included Andy Jao, Steve Kattan, Quinito Henson, and Joaqui Trillo. Cantada brought the most experience to the Vintage team, having covered Anthony Villanueva’s silver medal finish in the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, the summer bikathon Tour of Luzon, and countless championship boxing bouts.

College basketball also competed for audience attention when it was shown more extensively on TV. The University Athletic Association of the Philippines games got more regular coverage beginning in the 1990s produced by Silverstar Sports. Jimmy Javier and Trillo formed a popular broadcast team that college students identified with. The NCAA soon followed with Vintage while ABS-CBN tried their hand in presenting college sports.

Other trends emerged in the sports broadcast scene in the succeeding years. First, more sports events were covered live. Dedicated satellite coverage of the Olympics was initiated by government station PTV, starting with the 1996 Atlanta games. The games were on air 24 hours a day, with live telecasts of major events aired in the early morning hours and then generously replayed within the primetime hours. In time, Solar Sports, a broadcast blocktimer, dominated the airwaves with its NBA games shown on the cable channel Basketball TV. It also had its own Solar Sports network, a repository of various international and local events.

text:
Talk shows, also known as talk entertainment programs or chat shows, are radio and television programs in which a host or several hosts discuss various topics, usually with celebrity guests or with experts on the subject of the day. Audiences are typically enjoined to participate, whether through call-ins or, in more recent formats, through online engagements in the show’s website or Facebook page. Many notable talk shows draw their entertainment value from the boldness, unconventionality, or humor of the host, and from the popular or controversial nature of the topics they engage.

 

Talk entertainment was not a major genre during the early days of broadcasting in the Philippines. The genre would see its full potential on television only during the few years before the declaration of martial law in 1972. Talk focused on selling the shows of movie stars and recording artists, slowly segueing to interview formats that took special interest in their lives as showbiz personalities and, beginning in the mid-1980s, in the lives of ordinary people.

 

 

A pioneer of the genre was Two for the Road, a talk-public affairs program, first aired on ABS-CBN, then DZXL-TV 9 from 1967 to 1972, on GMA from 1979 to 1986, and then again on ABS-CBN from 1986 to 1987. Hosted by Elvira Manahan and Joey Lardizabal (later Nestor Torre Jr), it was known for bold and edgy discussions that were particularly controversial because the program first aired before the dark ages of martial law. Johnny Litton began in 1969 as a segment host of Two for the Road, then went on to host the 13-year run of Oh No, It’s Johnny, 1987-99, ABS-CBN, with society columnist Maurice Arcache, and, a few years later, Oh Yes, Johnny’s Back, also on ABS-CBN, with Anton San Diego and Tessa Prieto-Valdes. Known for his congenial wit, he conducted his shows with a propriety appealing to the show’s more elite target audiences, veering away from the brusque, often abrasive, styles typical of show business talk shows.

 

Jose “Joe” Quirino, also known as JQ, hosted a television show on IBC 13 called Seeing Stars with Joe Quirino, 1975-86. The show featured his interviews with movie celebrities and television stars and had a song-and-dance segment for added entertainment. With the same formal, dignified approach, but more interesting and engaging, and with more wit and humor, Edu Manzano hosted Not So Late Night with Edu, 1985, GMA, and Late Night with Edu, 1992-94, and What’s Up Doods?, 2013, both on ABC/TV5. In MAD: Martin After Dark, 1988-93, GMA, retitled Martin Late at Night, 1993-98, ABS-CBN, singer and wacky host Martin Nievera interviewed showbiz personalities, often teasing them and forcing his guests to reveal something about their personal lives, before ending the show with a song number dedicated to his guest.

 

“Queen of Intrigues” Inday Badiday, whose real name was Lourdes Jimenez-Carvajal, handled talk entertainment with candid bluntness and evident familiarity with the ins and outs of show business that allowed her to dish out juicy scoops and exclusive interviews with celebrities and fledgling personalities alike, through the many programs she hosted in her long career. Known to many as “Ate Luds,” she hosted shows that set the template for later talk show programs, such as Nothing but the Truth, 1976, and Would You Believe?, 1978, both on BBC 2, then See-True, 1979-87, IBC 13 then on GMA, followed by Movie Patrol, 1986, Eye to Eye, 1988, and The Truth and Nothing but the Truth, 2000, all on GMA. These programs centered on showbiz gossips and scandals, with a panel of movie reporters who queried guests, mostly vulnerable young actors, aging starlets, soft-core porn actors, superstars, and showbiz personalities eyeing public office, who often lied in their answers. The Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB) admonished the show several times for what the board called trash and trivia on television. The Philippine Association of National Advertisers (PANA), badgered by concerned audiences offended by these programs, had in some instances called the attention of these programs for the guests’ and co-anchors’ foul language and rude behavior on television, and PANA members, bowing to public pressure, once withdrew their sponsorship of these shows. The MTRCB clamped down on the showbiz talk program, Rumors, Fact, and Humor, 1986-87, Channel 2, after a microphone-hitting scene that transpired in the show.

 

The longest-running showbiz talk show in the Philippines was GMA’s Startalk, “the only showbiz authority,” which was 20 years on the air from its pilot in 1995 to its final episode in 2015. Simulcast on Super Radyo DZBB, the show was topbilled by Lolit Solis, Butch Francisco, Joey de Leon, and Ricky Lo, with a roster of other names on the list of hosts it had across its long history on the airwaves. It featured segments like “Da Who,” which had blind items on big celebrities, and “Tigbak Authority,” which had commentaries on red carpet looks by known personalities.

 

The second longest-running entertainment news and talk show was The Buzz, formerly known as Buzz ng Bayan (Nation’s Buzz) and later repackaged as The Buzz 15, hosted by Boy Abunda with his characteristic no-nonsense candor. Premiering in 1999, the show capitalized primarily on celebrity gossip and showbiz news. Kris Aquino and Toni Gonzaga co-hosted the show with Boy Abunda before its termination in 2015, allegedly due to the station’s necessary adjustments to perceived changes in the showbiz talk genre. Boy Abunda also hosted Private Conversations with Boy Abunda, 2001, ANC 21, and The Bottom Line with Boy Abunda, 2009, ABS-CBN.

 

Feisty and abrasive Cristy Fermin was a political journalist before she went into tabloid writing that launched her into television talk show hosting, a lengthy career that, at one point, landed her with a libel case filed against her by Annabelle Rama and Eddie Gutierrez. She hosted notoriously juicy shows on television, such as Cristy Per Minute, 1995-99, and Showbiz Sabado, 2003-4, both on ABS-CBN, and Star Confessions, 2010-11, and Real Confessions, 2011-12, both on TV5. For radio, she did Showbiz Mismo (Showbiz Itself), 2004-10, DZMM, and Cristy FerMinute, beginning in 2010, Radyo5 92.3 News FM.

 

Perhaps one of the best talk entertainment programs was Let’s Talk Movies, 1981-83, RPN 9, hosted by Armida Siguion-Reyna, Behn Cervantes, and Mario Bautista, directed by Wilma Galvante and scripted by Oscar Miranda, which dealt with practically all aspects of moviemaking in the country, from acting to directing, producing, financing, booking, casting, lighting, and all other technical and nontechnical aspects of the industry, including issues about its stars, personalities, and crew.

 

More relevant talk entertainment programs came from Mel Tiangco and Jay Sonza, with their program Mel & Jay, 1988-96, ABS-CBN, reformatted and retitled as Partners Mel & Jay, 1996-2004, GMA. Tiangco also partnered with Joey de Leon for Mel & Joey, 2004-11, also on GMA. These shows served as a forum for ordinary people to exchange their views on a wide range of interesting topics about current issues and trends.

 

Radio talk entertainment shows returned to prominence in the years after martial law. In the early 1990s, some prominent talk show programs were RX 93.1’s Morning Rush, 103.5 K-Lite’s Talk Back and, later, Nite Lite, and NU 107’s Twisted. In the 2000s, Magic 89.9 had Good Times with Mo Twister and Boys’ Night Out. Some stations rebranded themselves into talk-oriented channels, such as music station Kiss Jazz, which converted into DWST Showbiz Tsismis (Showbiz Gossip). To appeal to the masses, mass-based programming became the vogue, with talk-oriented stations repackaging themselves with often cheesy slogans and tag lines for recall. Some of these stations were DWYS 101.1 “Yes FM,” DWRR 101.9 “For Life,” DWLS 97.1 “Barangay LS,” DWKY 91.5 Energy FM, DWOW 103.5, DWET 106.7, DZRH, and Win Radio 107.5. Station IDs became repetitions of station tag lines, with 90.7 DZMB Love Radio’s “Kailangan pa bang i-memorize ’yan?” (Do you need to memorize that?), and 106.7 Energy FM’s “Hi, Pangga!” (Hi, Love!). Mass-based radio talk entertainment, many of them hosted by two gay guys for an added fun factor, became characterized by comical and energetic banter between hosts, steady streams of jokes and witticisms, and droll exchanges with awkward yet excited guest callers, all punctuated by canned laughter and other, often cartoonish, sound effects.

 

Talk entertainment has served mainly to amuse and regale Filipino audiences, although historically they have flirted with pertinent issues and serious journalism. While many talk show programs have been criticized for exploiting controversies and for turning private issues into public spectacles, their appeal continues to stem from the voyeuristic draw of digging into lives of glitz and glamour and humanizing perceived stars and idols. Furthermore, the ruthless candor and unsanitized banter provide a welcome relief from the rigors of more formal media genres and open up spaces for more flexible public discourse as it invites audiences to participate in discussions however spontaneously. As such, talk entertainment remains an important platform for shaping opinion and dictating the loci of public attention. Greater vigilance is thus needed in contending with its continuing production and consumption. Written by Louise Jashil R. Sonido with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III, Elizabeth L. Enriquez, and Marinela M. Aseron

 

Sources

Manila Standard 1978, 1987.

text:
Teleradyo is the simultaneous transmission of a radio and/or television signal over two or more networks or stations, or two or more platforms, such as combining or blending AM, FM, television, cable, and, with the new digital technology, online streaming or webcasting. The term teleradyo is a stylized portmanteau, meaning television and radio. Its origin comes from the word simulcast, which refers to simultaneous broadcasting, a term coined in 1948 by a press agent at WCAU-TV, Philadelphia, USA (Crosby 1948). Based on the definition of this term, the simultaneous airing of programs over radio and television is not a new concept in many countries, including the Philippines. Important presidential public addresses, milestone coverages such as Congress hearings, huge rallies, and the launching of celebrities, commercial products, or network programs have been recurring depending on the importance or significance of these events.

Thus, the idea of a teleradyo, as closely identified with the Philippines’ largest broadcast network, ABS-CBN’s DZMM TeleRadyo, is not new. What makes ABS-CBN a “pioneer” in teleradyo is that it is the first radio network that simultaneously aired its entire programs, not just a portion of the day’s programming, on cable television 24 hours a day and seven days a week. Thus, DZMM, found on 630 khz on the AM band, is also available on Skycable Channel 26 in Metro Manila, and on TVplus, the network’s digital TV box, as well as in other cable stations nationwide, every day.

 

DZMM TeleRadyo, as initiated by ABS-CBN, was formally heard and seen on 12 Apr 2007. The audience simultaneously hears the radio station DZMM and sees a live-feed of the radio booth and the program hosts on television. However, no advertising content is fed into the TeleRadyo; instead, video materials promoting the station’s programs are aired.

Aside from seeing the broadcasters inside the radio booth on television, the latest news, other information relevant to the day’s current issues, and advertisements are flashed on an assigned corner of the television monitor or the computer screen. Text messaging and the use of any electronically mediated platform by the viewers and listeners are utilized for a more interactive broadcasting and livestreaming experience.

The other radio station that airs simultaneously on radio and cable TV is DZRH, the flagship AM radio station of Manila Broadcasting Company, which has the biggest number of radio stations, almost 500, in the country. DZRH is on the 666 frequency on the radio set and can be seen on Cablelink Channel 3 in Metro Manila, as well as in other cable stations nationwide.

 

It is interesting to note that DZRH claims that it is the first on-air screen channel seen on Skycable and, later, on Dream SatelliteTV and other cable TV channels nationwide with 300 cable affiliates. It was first known as TV Natin, which was launched in Dec 2008. It was then rebranded as DZRH RadioVision, and much later changed to DZRH Television (RHTV). Finally, in Oct 2013, it was renamed as DZRH News Television.

Aksyon TV of TV5 Network Inc is a hybrid news channel that broadcast its radio programs on 92.3 News FM simultaneously on UHF free TV Channel 41 in Metro Manila and Channel 1 on CIGNAL Digital TV. It was included on Skycable at Channel 59 in Apr 2011.

DZBB Super Radyo of RGMA has only online streaming just like the other AM and FM stations in the country. article.value: Teleradyo is the simultaneous transmission of a radio and/or television signal over two or more networks or stations, or two or more platforms, such as combining or blending AM, FM, television, cable, and, with the new digital technology, online streaming or webcasting. The term teleradyo is a stylized portmanteau, meaning television and radio. Its origin comes from the word simulcast, which refers to simultaneous broadcasting, a term coined in 1948 by a press agent at WCAU-TV, Philadelphia, USA (Crosby 1948). Based on the definition of this term, the simultaneous airing of programs over radio and television is not a new concept in many countries, including the Philippines. Important presidential public addresses, milestone coverages such as Congress hearings, huge rallies, and the launching of celebrities, commercial products, or network programs have been recurring depending on the importance or significance of these events.

Thus, the idea of a teleradyo, as closely identified with the Philippines’ largest broadcast network, ABS-CBN’s DZMM TeleRadyo, is not new. What makes ABS-CBN a “pioneer” in teleradyo is that it is the first radio network that simultaneously aired its entire programs, not just a portion of the day’s programming, on cable television 24 hours a day and seven days a week. Thus, DZMM, found on 630 khz on the AM band, is also available on Skycable Channel 26 in Metro Manila, and on TVplus, the network’s digital TV box, as well as in other cable stations nationwide, every day.

text:
Television specials are produced to cover or celebrate significant national or international events of high audience interest that happen rarely or only once annually, such as papal visits, beauty pageants, awards nights like the Oscars, the Olympics, and high-prize boxing matches.

They are typically longer than the one-hour weekly show, lasting anywhere between a few hours of one-time programming, such as a Christmas musical special, to several days of intermittent coverage such as that of elections. Traditionally, specials had high production value and were elaborately planned entertainment shows. Of late, the subject matter of specials has included controversial news events and issues, as in special documentaries and reportage. Not part of regular programming, specials are a product of attempts to attract the largest percentage of viewers at a specific time. In the United States, the costly extravaganza called television spectacular in the 1950s gave way to the scaled-down television special toward the end of the 1960s.

Considered the first television special in the Philippines was the live coverage by ABS DZAQ TV of the world junior lightweight boxing championship match between Filipino boxer Gabriel “The Flash” Elorde and Harold Gomes of the United States on 16 Mar 1960. With 36,000 watching inside the newly built Araneta Coliseum in Cubao, Quezon City, Elorde won the 12-round fight, and his victory made him a boxing legend in Philippine sports. Another first was the inauguration of President Ferdinand Marcos and Vice President Fernando Lopez in Dec 1965, which was promoted as a television special. Since then, all presidential and vice presidential inaugurations were covered by the television media. Also for the first time, a national election was covered live by radio and television. ABS-CBN Channel 3 conducted a 36-hour coverage of the 1967 national elections for eight Senate seats and local government positions in Halalan ’67 (Elections ’67). It covered the balloting and the first day of the canvass, benchmarking succeeding election coverages. In 1971, the Bilang ng Bayan (Count of the Nation), which covered the canvass of votes in polls for president, vice president, eight senatorial seats, congressional seats, and local government positions, was considered a special coverage that raised the bar for special election coverages first set by Halalan ’67.

 

In the 1960s, only a few specials were broadcast on Philippine television, mostly emanating from the United States, the most memorable of which were the historic twin broadcasts of the Apollo 11 lunar space launch at Cape Kennedy, Florida, on 16 Jul 1969 and the lunar landing four days later on 20 Jul 1969. Then president Marcos declared the day of the launch, a Wednesday, a special national holiday to allow the people to watch the live coverage of the liftoff. All the television channels in the Philippines carried the satellite transmission simultaneously, with Robert Stewart of RBS-TV Channel 7 as the main anchor of the Philippine segment. The following Sunday, Apollo 11 landed on the moon and the live broadcast was again carried by all Philippine TV channels.

The 1970s saw several television specials, many of which were international boxing matches between prizefighters. The most memorable is the 1 Oct 1975 match between heavyweights Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier at the Araneta Coliseum dubbed Thrilla in Manila, covered live by RPN Channel 9. With Filipino professional boxing referee Carlos Padilla Jr as the third man in the ring, the prizefight put the Philippines on the boxing map of the world. Before the Thrilla in Manila, ABC Channel 5 brought to Filipino audiences the 5 Apr 1970 fight between Japanese Yoshiaki Numata and Filipino Rene Barrientos for the World Boxing Council super featherweight title at the Metropolitan Gym in Tokyo, Japan. Barrientos lost the fight, which was aired as a television special, although not broadcast live.

Three decades later, boxing matches again became the subject of television special productions. The first several international title bouts of Filipino boxing champion Emmanuel “Manny” Pacquiao were aired as television specials, including those held abroad, mostly in the United States. One of the best remembered is his bout with Oscar Larios of Mexico for the World Boxing Champion Super Featherweight title on 2 Jul 2006 at the Araneta Coliseum. It was broadcast live to Philippine audiences as Pacquiao won the 12-round match. Later Pacquiao matches, however, were watched by viewers through specialized cable channels and, by the second decade of the 21st century, over pay-per-view facilities. This meant that boxing matches no longer met the definition of the traditional television special, but became a new type of program format.

Television specials featuring beauty pageants, particularly the Miss Universe, Miss International, and Miss World pageants and their local counterparts, have generally enjoyed good audience ratings from past to present. In 1974, RPN Channel 9 covered the first Miss Universe pageant hosted by the Philippines. Held at the Folk Arts Theater in Manila, Amparo Muñoz of Spain won the title. Twenty years later, in 1994, the Philippines hosted the pageant anew, this time at the Philippine International Convention Center in Pasay City. The crown went to Sushmita Sen of India. Since the 1970s, international beauty contests were aired via satellite through local TV stations. In the 2010s, the consecutive victories of Filipino contestants in many international beauty competitions made the latter a lucrative TV production venture. Audiences were glued to the live or recorded telecast to witness how Philippine candidates successfully competed. In the Miss Universe pageant, Venus Raj was fourth runner-up in 2010; Shamcey Supsup and Ariella Arida were third runners-up in 2011 and in 2013, respectively; Janine Tugonon was first runner-up in 2012; and Pia Wurtzbach won the crown in 2015. In 2013, Megan Young won the Miss World contest, Bea Rose Santiago got the Miss International crown, and Mutya Datul won the title of Miss Supranational (Rappler 2013).

Celebrity marriage proposals and weddings are made into specials owing to the kilig (thrill) factor as well as the glamour of these events. The wedding of Richard Gomez and Lucy Torres was produced into a special by ABS-CBN in 1998. Zoren Legaspi’s surprise marriage proposal to Carmina Villaroel was aired on ABS-CBN in 2012. Blurring the lines between fact and fiction was the special feature on the wedding reception of Maya and Richard “Sir Chief” Lim, played by actors Jodi Sta. Maria and Richard Yap, who were the romantic couple in the serial drama Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, ABS-CBN. The much-awaited wedding of Dingdong Dantes and Marian Rivera in 2014 was aired over GMA Network in early 2015. In the same year, GMA released a special coverage on the island wedding of politician Chiz Escudero and Heart Evangelista.

Papal visits to the Philippines, which have happened only four times in a span of 45 years, are also the subject of television specials. The first pope to visit was Paul VI in Nov 1970, but the news was transmitted only through the regular newscasts. When John Paul II came in Feb 1981 and Jan 1995, the coverage was extensive, and regularly scheduled programs had to give way. The same happened when Francis came in Jan 2015. Predominantly Catholic, audiences in record numbers watched the live television specials and the replays of the several events Francis attended while in the Philippines.

Among the television specials that air once a year are the various media awards, such as the American Oscars for cinema, Emmy Awards for television, Grammy Awards for the recording industry, and Tony Awards for stage arts and sciences. Local award-giving bodies that produce coverage of awarding ceremonies are the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, the Film Academy of the Phlippines, the Philippine Movie Press Club, and the Metro Manila Film Festival.

Apart from the traditional Christmas specials, there are yearly specials during designated times of the year. Eat Bulaga! (Peek-a-Boo!) departs from its daily variety show and produces a dramatic series with a moral or religious theme during Holy Week. News and public affairs departments of broadcast networks produce yearender retrospectives to highlight the big issues and to summarize the newsmakers of the departing year.

Some TV specials are produced to influence public opinion on national and international issues. Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan (Dear Sam … Yours, Juan), 1989, was an anti-US bases documentary that exposed the negative social, cultural, and political effects of the presence of the US military bases in the Philippines. It was censored by the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board under the Cory Aquino administration. Its suppression escalated into a heated public issue and became the subject of a Senate hearing. The TV special was finally aired in 1990 over ABS-CBN. The anti-US bases special won Best TV Special of the Year in the 1990 Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon. Then in 1991, the Philippine Senate voted to end the presence of American military bases in the country.

Never-to-be-repeated occurrence, such as the turn of the new millennium in 2000, was a big media event. All TV and radio networks aired how peoples and nations all over the world celebrated the coming of the year 2000. News events also end up as television specials, both as special coverage of breaking news and as subjects of documentary specials. These include the declaration of martial law in 1972, the EDSA Revolt of 1986, the coup d’etat attempts against the administration of Corazon Aquino in 1987 and 1989, the impeachment of President Joseph Estrada in 2000-1 that led to EDSA 2 in 2001, and the trial of Supreme Court Chief Justice Renato Corona in Jan 2012. In 2013, the Lahad Datu standoff in Sabah revived the issue of the Sultanate of Sulu’s historic claim over Sabah. This was followed by the confrontation between the Moro National Liberation Front and the Philippine military in Zamboanga City in the same year (Medina 2013). Government functions, such as state visits, have all been the subject of special television specials. Every year, there are special live coverages and features on the annual State of the Nation Address of the incumbent president of the Republic of the Philippines.

Natural disasters and calamities have been the subject of TV special reports since the time of the 1968 earthquake that reduced Manila Chinatown’s Ruby Tower into rubble, killing hundreds of people. Other major calamities that were the topic of special reportage on radio and TV were the 1990 earthquake, the 1991 Mount Pinatubo explosion, and the 2009 deluge caused by Typhoon Ondoy. As climate change ushers in extreme weather disturbances, the phenomenon became a tragic reality in 2013 with the advent of super typhoon Yolanda, which came right after the earthquake that damaged many parts of the Visayas.

Developments in broadcast cable television, the impact of digital technologies, and the consequent rise in pay-per-view television service have reduced the value of the television special as a programming strategy. By the second decade of the 21st century, the only specials left on television apart from the news and documentary specials are the traditional international beauty pageants and annual awards ceremonies. The lucrative pay-per-view boxing specials are no longer aired live; they are still aired on television but only by way of delayed telecast or replay. Although the television special is still around, the competition presented by specialized cable television channels and the on-line media has taken away some of the splendor originally associated first with the television spectacular, and later with the television special. Written by Victor C. Avecilla and Rosalie Matilac

 

Sources

Medina 2013; Rappler 2013.

text:
Variety shows are entertainment programs that combine a series of unrelated acts, such as dance and music performances, literary readings, comedy skits, comic repartees, interviews, sponsored promotional segments, and all sorts of games, quizzes, competitions, and contests.

 

The format in Philippine broadcast in the 1930s came from the bodabil (vaudeville). Both the show and the performers were sponsored by blocktimers, which were commercial products that bought blocks of airtime. These sponsors included a wet market, a shopping center, and brands of automobiles, delivery truck, battery, cooking lard, alcoholic drink, toothpaste, milk, cigar, juice drink, oatmeal, and bath soap. These shows had live performances and had fans inside the radio studio to provide live laughter and applause. Examples include Chevrolet Jamboree on KZRM, Purico Troubadors, Camay Theater of the Air, and Glossy Merrymakers on KZIB, and The San Miguel Brewery Hour on KZRF. Other notable variety shows were University of the Air and Horacio de la Costa’s Common Weal Hour. Some popular variety show performers of the period were Francisco “Frankie” Gomez, Remigio Mat Castro, Conde Ubaldo, Chichay, Tolindoy, the husband-and-wife team of Alejandro Villegas (aka Andoy Balun-balunan) and Adela Fernando (aka Dely Atay-atayan), and the tandems of Pugo and Togo, German San Jose and Leonora Reyes, and Vicente Ocampo and Diana Toy, most of whom were bodabil actors (Enriquez 2008).

 

The format gained more popularity as a quiz show in the 1950s, such as Radio Schoolhouse, DZPI, Knowledge Unlimited, DZRH, Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse), DZBB, Campus Capers, DZPI, and Professor Quiz, DZMB (Aniceto 2007, 505-31). The mélange of different acts became the signature of other popular variety shows, such as Darigold Jumbo Jamboree, DZXL, which introduced the comic duo Dolphy and Panchito, and the gag-filled The Big Broadcast, DZRH, featuring the stars of the film studio Sampaguita Pictures. A memorable show was Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks), DZRH, which interviewed on the air five female members of the studio audience who each were asked to share their unique experiences. The one who was applauded the loudest was declared the reyna (queen) for a day (Aniceto 2007, 505-31; Enriquez 2003, 25-29).

 

Memorable late afternoon-early evening variety shows on TV that had more comedy were ABS-CBN Channel 3’s Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), 1964-72, with Dolphy and Panchito, and Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), 1965-71, hosted by Sylvia La Torre, Oscar Obligacion, and Eddie San Jose.

 

The radio show that transformed the noontime variety format was the daily show CBN Canteen, 1957, first hosted by Kolynos girl Priscilla Aristorenas, then replaced by Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, and Leila Benitez in 1958. It was so popular with the student population that the CBN management decided to rename the show Student Canteen. The next year, Student Canteen became a noontime television program on DZXL-TV Channel 9. The show consistently topped the ratings in noontime programming until 1964, and during its return to Philippine television in 1975, GMA. It had its final run in 1990 on RPN 9.

 

The show that beat Student Canteen was Eat Bulaga! (Peek-a-Boo!), which premiered in 1979 and continues to dominate the noontime slot. It is hosted by the comic trio of Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon. It first aired on RPN 9, then on ABS-CBN, and has been airing since 1994 on GMA. Eat Bulaga! follows the conventional segments of a variety show, but periodically introduces new concepts that have helped maintain its popularity to audiences nationwide. Examples are “Bulagaan” (Joke Time), “Little Miss Philippines,” “Laban o Bawi” (Wager or Take Back), “Pinoy Henyo” (Genius Filipino), “Juan for All, All for Juan,” and “Kalyeserye” (Street Drama Serial) that created the monster hit “Al-Dub” phenomenon, a tongue-in-cheek comic sketch that mixes the scripted and the unscripted, as well as reality, hilarity, and virtuality. The show has been franchised by a leading television network in Indonesia, to which it exports all its contests and segments.

 

The public has hurled numerous criticisms at the program, mainly for the “old-school” mode of comedy of its main hosts, and the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board has either admonished or suspended members of the cast for various instances of below-the-belt and sexist innuendos.

 

Formidable competitors of Eat Bulaga! were variety shows produced by ABS-CBN, which included ’Sang Linggo nAPO Sila (The APO Now Runs for a Week), 1995-98, Magandang Tanghali, Bayan (Good Noon, Nation), 1998-2005, Wowowee, 2005-10, and It’s Showtime, which began in 2009.

 

A very popular host of the talk variety program was Ariel Ureta, who captured the hearts of the Filipino audience via the noontime show called 12 O’Clock High on BBC 2. From Noontime Matinee and For the Boys on IBC 13, Ureta moved back to BBC 2 with Ariel con Tina (Ariel with Tina), and the early-evening variety show Ariel & Co. After Six, BBC 2, with a child co-host, then child superstar Niño Muhlach.

 

Many variety shows on television were also music programs, one of the pioneers of which was The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965-72, ABS-CBN Channel 3. Established showbiz personalities also took on the challenge of handling their own musical variety shows. Nora Aunor had Superstar, 1971-89, RPN 9; Vilma Santos had Vilma!, 1986-95, first on BBC 2, then on GMA; Alma Moreno had Loveliness, 1988-89, IBC 13; Sharon Cuneta had The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1986-97, IBC then ABC-CBN; and Maricel Soriano had Maricel, Live!, 1986, IBC 13.

 

German Moreno had his extravagant variety programs on GMA, beginning with the Sunday show Germside, retitled Germspesyal then The GMA Supershow, 1978-97. His shows were top-raters during the post-EDSA period, including the daily late afternoon program That’s Entertainment, 1986-96, which featured Moreno’s stable of young stars, and the weekend programs Saturday Entertainment, 1986-95, GMA Supershow, 1984-97, and Master Showman, which debuted in 1997, later renamed Walang Tulugan with the Master Showman (Without Sleep with the Master Showman), a late-night Saturday program that ends on Sunday morning. Moreno’s shows were rivaled by variety shows from ABS-CBN, like Sa Linggo nAPO Sila (The APO Are Now on Sunday), 1990-95, All-Star Sunday Afternoon Party (ASAP), which premiered in 1995, and Ang TV (The TV), 1992-97, which showcased the network’s crop of young talents.

 

Important variety show directors were Mitos Villareal, whose productions became synonymous with elegance; choreographer Al Quinn, whose productions were visually stunning; and Fritz Ynfante, whose works were extravagant and draw mainly from the world of big musicals. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Elizabeth L. Enriquez with notes from Vladimeir B. Gonzales

article.value: Variety shows are entertainment programs that combine a series of unrelated acts, such as dance and music performances, literary readings, comedy skits, comic repartees, interviews, sponsored promotional segments, and all sorts of games, quizzes, competitions, and contests.

The format in Philippine broadcast in the 1930s came from the bodabil (vaudeville). Both the show and the performers were sponsored by blocktimers, which were commercial products that bought blocks of airtime. These sponsors included a wet market, a shopping center, and brands of automobiles, delivery truck, battery, cooking lard, alcoholic drink, toothpaste, milk, cigar, juice drink, oatmeal, and bath soap. These shows had live performances and had fans inside the radio studio to provide live laughter and applause. Examples include Chevrolet Jamboree on KZRM, Purico Troubadors, Camay Theater of the Air, and Glossy Merrymakers on KZIB, and The San Miguel Brewery Hour on KZRF.
